story:
Improv Stimulus Package

The Improv Network wants to support the improv community as best as we can during the COVID-19 shut downs. Improv and comedy theaters and Festivals around the world are being financially impacted, so we wanted to raise funds to help keep theaters afloat. Please donate to help keep your favorite theaters in business! 

THEATER APPLICATIONS

We have received many applications and have closed our application process. All money raised will be distributed to theaters that have already applied. If we raise substantially more money and can help more theaters, we will re-open our applications. 

 

ABOUT THE IMPROV NETWORK

The Improv Network is an online community that brings improvisers together from all over the world. We offer theatres, festivals, improvisers, troupes, and instructors a wide array of services and resources, along with a way to connect and communicate. Our ever-expanding resources include easy, quick, and organized festival submissions for both teams and festival organizers, teacher and workshop listings, and pertinent blogs. Our mission is to connect improvisers and provide every team, theater, and performer, anywhere in the world, access to the support, information, tools, and resources they need to create outstanding improv and run positive, safe, and diverse theaters and festivals.

story:
About In This Place 

Hello there! Thanks for being here and following along as we produce a play! In This Place is scheduled to premier at the Broadway Bound Festival in NYC February 2021. Though we don't know if we'll be able to pull that date off due to COVID-19, I can promise you that this play will be produced—whenever we can, no matter what! 

Here's what your contributions will cover: 

- Pay for actors 

- Pay for our director 

- Pay for lighting designer and set design 

- Marketing costs 

- Music composition

- Musicians

- Rehearsal space 

- Props

- Printing of scripts and programs 

- Travel

Thank you 

This project is special to me, and I've been overwhelmed by the support you've already shown. Art matters, and you financial contributions here will help our team of artists create something great! 

Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. 

- Molly

story:
Savannah Shakes

Since 2015, Savannah Shakes has been committed to serving as a home to William Shakespeare in the Lowcountry. Our goal was always been to champion the accessibility,  relevance, and entertainment of the Bard's works. At our founding, we developed the idea to set our productions in consecutive decades, traveling through the latter half of the 20th Century. 

First, the genesis of it all, was a 1940s THE TAMING OF THE SHREW. We wanted to explore the dynamic between soldiers returning home from WW2 clashing with the women who had taken their places in the factories. It was like Rosie the Riveter vs. Captain America! 

Next came our Beatnik HAMLET, where the Prince of Denmark's legendary introspection and philosophy found a home within the tortured minds of the Beat Generation. Hamlet's struggle to avenge his father was especially grueling up against the picket-fence (seeming) perfection of the rest of his family. 

For the 1960s, Mad Men met Laugh-In in MUCH ADO ABOUT NOTHING with the suave ladies' men meeting their match with the headstrong and witty women in their lives. 

Moving into the late 60s, things took a darker turn for HENRY V inspired by the Vietnam War. We sought to explore the murky morality of Henry V's conquest of France through the lens of one of the most controversial wars this country has ever known.

The 1970s were a great time for Disco! Drawing heavy inspiration from the recently passed on legend David Bowie, we set THE TEMPEST in a psychedelic dance club, complete with knee-high boots, lots of sequins, and a Blues Brother or two. This was our first time tailoring our venue to the concept; we got to do this one on everyone's favorite drag stage at Club One's Bay Street Theatre!

The late 1970s and early 1980s meant a plunge into the bloody excess of Grindhouse Horror and there's no better show for it than TITUS ANDRONICUS. It was a revenge cycle for the ages, pitting the morally ambiguous small-town police headed by Titus against the savage Goths led by their fearless queen, Tamora. Our second site-specific show: we did this in an actual movie theater with a guerilla theatre style set.

Our third and last (so far!) site-specific venture took a John Hughes style approach to the college comedy with TWELFTH NIGHT. Produced on the stage of Savannah State University, the hijinks in pursuit of love were just as confusing as they were for all of us. 

Finishing off the 20th Century, KING LEAR took place in a mysterious and dangerous cult community as the world-ending Y2K approached. Our Lear, played by Savannah favorite and Equity actor Dennis Elkins, threw his peaceful commune into disarray with his abdication of his power to his ruthless daughters. This was our first show working with our very good friends at Savannah Repertory Theatre!

And finally, last summer, we landed in the present with MEASURE FOR MEASURE, using it to explore the harrowing amount of abuse of power in our world today. Judge Angelo hides his depravity behind a virtuous mask and uses his power to force a young woman to submit to him to save her brother's life.

Now we are all caught up! But that's not the end of this cycle, oh no. 

Having caught up with the current timeline, we are taking our next production, MACBETH, into the future and outer space! The Tragedy of Macbeth is the story of a noble warrior who turns to the dark side. Sound familiar?  It has long been a dream of founder Chris Soucy to follow the story of Macbeth to a galaxy far, far away. Shakespeare packed this play with mysteries, intrigues, betrayals, and magic. And now we sit at our TENTH production and we'd like to go all out!

Your contribution would go to making Macbeth the biggest and most complex theatrical experience Savannah Shakes has ever undertaken. Our goal has always been to produce Shakespeare that can be enjoyed by academics and casual viewers alike. We are wanting to pool all our resources to make this a once-in-a-lifetime production.  We have long lived by the simple mantra, "We don't produce shows to make money, we make money to produce shows." So it is in that spirit, that we ask you for your generous help in presenting this show with FREE ADMISSION. If we can cover the costumes, the tech, the venue, and the talent through your donations, we will not charge for our tickets. Shakespeare for everyone because Shakespeare is for everyone! Admission is often one of the largest obstacles for people to take part in the magic of theatre so we'd love to remove that obstacle altogether!

What's on the table?

Savannah Shakes modestly figures a $5000 budget to produce this show. With that budget, we will pay the rental of the venue,  pay technicians and our director, and purchase costumes and props. Lightsabers aren't cheap! We are naturally producing the show regardless of meeting this projected goal. We will use whatever you graciously share with us to ensure that this show is fantastic. But if we were to exceed this budget, we would set aside money to go to performers, artists, and key crew who dedicate themselves regularly with only the reward of creating great art for the community.  

And what do you get? I'm glad we asked. The tiers of perks that your donation can get you are perkaliscious. Not a real word, but Shakespeare made up words all the time. All higher tier perks also get you all the perks below it.

$5 : A "Special Thanks" online and in our program.

$15 : A Savannah Shakes postcard.

$25 : A Savannah Shakes button.

$35 : Access to Behind-the-Scenes Media from the production process.

$50 : Access to a professionally filmed video of the show

$100 : Your very own personalized sonnet! <3

$150 :  Access to our reserved front-row seating.

$250 :  A limited edition show poster signed by the entire cast.

$500 : Your very own LIGHTSABER!!

 

You don't have to donate to help!

We appreciate any and all support. Share our event. Come out and help with a build. Hype us up on social media. Give us a hearty huzzah! Our goal is to illustrate the relevance and vibrance of Shakespeare's works and it doesn't take a dime for you to help us do that. We really love this community and there's no place we'd rather be producing Shakespeare than Savannah, GA.

story:
Short Summary

  • We are The Passage Theatre (TPT) a small, non-equity theatre company operating out of Chicago, IL.
  • We are raising funds for our second season, and we're being matched dollar for dollar up to $1,000, so your contribution goes twice as far!

  • See our website for more information about us: www.thepassagetheatre.com

 

What We Need & What You Get

  • We need to reach at least $1,000 (which will turn into $2,000 with the matched donation) to produce our second season of plays.
  • Depending on the size of your donation, there are various perks you can receive, including stickers (a coveted item amongst our peers and fans), VIP tickets, and a shout-out in 2019-20 programs' donors list.

 

The Impact

  • TPT is striving to make great work that challenges the standards of Chicago Theatre and ushers in a new direction of theatre focused on creativity, sustainability, and community.
  • Our highly successful first season was considered by reviewers to be an "auspicious beginning"  showcasing a "stellar ensemble" (Chicago Reader, Picture This Post).
  • Moving into our second season, we are taking on many new challenges to revitalize Chicago theatre, producing our first world premiere, our first commission, and a new play reading series called The Current.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Boosting the signal by sharing this campaign with your friends and family.

  • Following us on social media (www.facebook.com/thepassagetheatre and www.instagram.com/thepassagetheatre) and signing up for our email list.

  • Attending HAPPY BIRTHDAY MARS ROVER (we have Pay-What-You-Can previews!).

story:
What is Goldfish?

It was my acting teacher, Ray Virta, during my last semester of school at AMDA NY that first recommended the play to me. Upon meeting me he immediately told me to check out this play, and I think that very same evening after class I ran to the Drama Book Shop in NYC to pick up a copy...

"A young man raises his father. Then he leaves home. He meets a young woman who undoes him. The young woman has her own story: a mother who is a force of nature. It's a play about legacy-how do we become who we are?-and it's about leaving home. We raise our children to leave us, to walk out into the world. But then they do." 

I instantly fell in love with the play.

Cut to last spring, we are rehearsing for the LA Collegiate Playwright Festival. A fellow cast member sees me reading my copy of my beloved "Goldfish", and she snatches it out of my hand. After reading a few scenes while I rehearsed onstage, she proclaimed, "I want to do this. We're doing this. When can we do it?" That crazy woman was my now co-star and co-producer, Jessica Abrams. After I convinced my other castmate, Damon Mckinnis to get onboard, it was decided--we had to do this play!

What we need to raise--

We're trying to raise $3,000. This is needed to cover all production costs including the rights to the play, the venue for five shows and a tech rehearsal, all crew and tech, our costumes and set, and the access to perform as part of the Los Angeles Fringe Festival this June.  

We're offering some perks for those of you who are willing to help us out : ) 

And don't forget if you're in the LA area this June to come see the play that YOU helped make possible!!!!

--your girl, Sami Henry

story:
What’s all this?

Three actors, alike in insanity,

In fair Lake Villa, where we lay our scene,

From this website ask you for your money

Where civil folks give civil shows more green.

From forth the fatal coins of you, our friends,

A cast of star-crossed actors make their show,

Whose misadventured, piteous ambitions

Do, with their art, try not to have it blow.

 

For never was there a story of more glee,

Than this of Dean, Tara, and Jamie Lee.

 

The Complete Works of William Shakespeare (abridged) is about three actors (Jamie, Dean, and Tara) who decide to do every single Shakespeare play in 97 minutes. They quickly realize that this was a bad idea. Mayhem, comical emotional breakdowns, rare moments of lucidity, and loads and loads of fake vomiting ensue, and the audience gets to be an active part of the chaos!

Our first performances are in July at Terminus Theatre.

What are you doing with my money, you hooligans?

Your money goes to performance rights, venue use, props, costumes, posters, and other show-related expenses. Every penny goes towards helping make this show a reality and a success.

What’s in it for me?

Starting at only $5, you start getting some cool rewards, like having your name included in our “Thank You” video, being thanked LIVE at a curtain call of your choice, an autographed photo of the cast, and first dibs on sitting in the first few rows of one of the shows!

Plus, you get a great show put on by a talented director and cast (and Jamie), and you get to help make dreams come true! And isn’t that what Shakespeare’s all about? (No really, isn’t it? We let Jamie research that part, so we’re not sure.)

And just who do you think you are?

Jamie Lee (Actor/“Accidental Producer”) doesn’t know what she’s doing here with all these amazingly talented people, but she’s excited to be here! Jamie’s worked with Second City, iO, PM&L Theatre, Six Flags, The Kirk Players, Donley’s Wild West Town, and more. She hosts a radio show, “Jammin’ with Jamie,” Saturdays 6-7am CT on 89.3 WNUR FM. A writer, director, punster, and more, Jamie double majored in Radio/TV/Film and Political Science at Northwestern. Jamie hopes Dean and Tara like working with her! … They’re saying good things about her in their bios, right?

Dean J. Griffiths (Actor) has worked in over 40 stage productions with PM&L Theatre, The Kirk Players, Round Lake Area Park District, and College of Lake County Theatre—mostly in roles like (old) Scrooge, The Cat in the Hat, and Igor (pronounced “EYE-gore”), but also as musician. A teacher, Six Flags Great America Scare Actor, church organist, science/math junkie, and Heaven-only-knows-what-else, Dean hopes that this show runs smoothly and that, if Tara must kill Jamie, the former waits until the curtain call.

Tara Petrozelli (Actor) has acted Off-Broadway with The Players Theatre and with Manhattan Repertory Theatre. (We have no idea what she’s doing here with us, either.) Around these parts, Tara’s worked with PM&L Theatre, Lakeside Players, The Haylofters, and more. A preeminent Shakespearean scholar (with a certificate from preeminentshakespeareanscholar.com), Tara hopes she gets to shine and pay proper tribute to Shakespeare’s genius and that Dean can keep Jamie in line.

Jim Behr (Director) has directed many farces with very talented casts. So obviously, this is a stretch for him. Jim’s worked with Three Brothers Theatre, PM&L Theatre, The Kirk Players, and more. An active director and actor who’s done everything from musicals, to drama, to farce, Jim just hopes the cast doesn’t suck. That would look really bad for him as a director.

But what if it all goes horribly, horribly wrong?

Since when has a farcical idea ever gone horribly, horribly wrong?

Every penny we raise will go towards making the show a resounding success, so even if we don’t make our full budget, every little bit helps. If we don’t make our budget, we will stretch what we do get as far as we can.

How else can I help?

You can share this! Twitter, Facebook, proclaiming it in the town square, get the word out!

And come see what your funds hath wrought this July at Terminus Theatre in Lake Villa, IL!

May the Bard be with you!

story:
"CALL ME DIANA" is a long-awaited stage musical tribute and a celebration of the love for the remarkable Diana, Princess of Wales.

The "CALL ME DIANA" Showcase will be presented at The Leicester Square Theatre with two performances on 19 September 2019.  For over 12 years the writers of "CALL ME DIANA", David Smart and Brian Watson have collaborated on this spectacular musical project. Their relationship was forged over many, many years working together, creating award-winning UK advertising campaigns. Our Story Editor, ex-Royal Correspondent, Richard Kay, was a personal friend of the Princess. With Richard, we knew he would not only give us the real story, but he would make sure we stayed faithful to the word 'tribute'.

The star of "CALL ME DIANA" is Natasha John, one of the 'Unexpected Stars' of Michael McIntyre's BIG SHOW. The production will be directed by John DeGaetano from the United States, along with his entire North Bay Stage Company team at The Leicester Square Theatre. 

Diana, Princess of Wales was, and still is one of the greatest icons of our time. With your pledge, you could help give more people the opportunity to savour the memory and the legacy of the People's Princess.

Why are we looking to raise more funds?

As we have already mentioned, the "CALL ME DIANA" Showcase will be staged, in the Leicester Square Theatre on the 19th of September 2019, using our existing funds. However, in all honesty, another £4,500 would enable us to achieve a far better Showcase. Your additional support would give us the opportunity to perform the show's original music tracks with a  larger orchestra, enhancing the presentation of the entire performance.

As encouragement, we are offering several exciting incentives! From getting your name in all  "CALL ME DIANA" show programmes, or for a little extra you might prefer a show T'Shirt or two (2) tickets to the Showcase. There are many ways in which you can join in the excitement of presenting the "CALL ME DIANA" Showcase. 

Even if we don't reach our goal here, our Showcase will go on, due to the generous contributors to our previous fundraising efforts. We can't thank you enough, and any new contributors will help us add the shine to the Showcase fit for a Princess.

We understand if a contribution isn't possible for you, but there is another way you can be instrumental in helping us reach this goal. You can help us get the word out about this campaign, by sharing it on social media or by telling your friends.

Thank you for helping make this a truly special Showcase, leading us closer to the spectacular full two and a half hour production, of the long-awaited tribute to the remarkable Diana, Princess of Wales. One day audiences across the globe will be thanking you too.

Biography's 

 David Smart: Composer & Book

David became one of the most prolific composers in TV advertising in the UK, with over 250 original scores. His music tracks help grow some of the country’s biggest brands, including Samsung, Johnson & Johnson and Birdseye. David also composed DVD trailers to blockbuster films including 'The Chronicles of Narnia', 'Troy' and 'The Aviator'. Living and working in Nashville Tennessee, David has written and produced a host of new artists including up and coming country star, Julienne Irwin, pop artist Natalie Estes, and 'Soul2Soul's' Charlotte Kelly. David has sung with Placido Domingo, Jose Carrreras, Dame Kiri Te Kanawa and has performed over 100 times at the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden, London.

Brian Watson: Lyricist & Book 

Brian is a successful and award-winning Writer/Director/Author/Lyricist, working in the advertising industry. As Creative Director of International agencies, Brian has helped grow some of the world's biggest brands, British Airways, Toyota, and Dulux being among them. Brian also has a Guinness world record, he's made more TV ads than anyone else in the world. He has also written many winning comedy scripts for UK artists. Brian has also directed some of the world's biggest artists, Joan Collins, Michael Caine, Sir Bruce Forsyth to name drop a few. Pre-Christmas 2011, Brian's book, 'Black Jacks, Fruit Salads, Cricket Stumps On The Wall', sold out due to the many excellent reviews in the UK press. One of the songs Brian and David wrote and produced tore apart the British justice system, in the style of the 1960s protest songs. The song picked up two Bronze Awards in the Global Music Awards in California in July 2015. 

Richard Kay: Ex-Royal Correspondent

Story Editor: “Call Me Diana”

Richard, having been a personal friend and confidant of the late Princess of Wales gives this spectacular show such an amazing insight into the woman who, 21 years after her death is still the world's favourite lady, she’s still empowering woman the world over. When Diana left her Royal marriage and became a global figure, it was Richard in whom she confided and the two became close friends. One of the last telephone calls Diana made on the day of her untimely death in August 1997 was to Richard. Making sure we have our facts right and helping us create the perfect tribute to Diana, Princess of Wales has been Richard's priority. Richard brings our show such a wonderful, unique credentials.

John DeGaetano: Director

John, a resident of San Francisco along with the North Bay Stage Company team will produce the production. John has worked for more than 30 years in theatre and film. A Broadwayworld Award nominee, John has an amazing list of directorial credits to his name, 'JOSEPH AND THE AMAZING TECHNICOLOUR DREAM COAT'. Two productions of Andrew Lloyd Webber's musical 'CATS'. Victor Hugo's 'LES MISERABLES'. A limited run of the musical 'CHICAGO'. A crazy version of 'PIRATES OF PENZANCE'. An intimate production of 'CABARET'. A. R. Gurney's 'LOVE LETTERS'. The world premier of 'THE ANGEL OF CHATHAM SQUARE'. More recently 'WEST SIDE STORY' and Gilbert & Sullivan's 'THE MIKADO'. In 2013 John directed the acclaimed production of 'EVITA' with a cast and crew of over 100. John is no stranger to London audiences, his series of 'SHERLOCK HOLMES PLAYS' had audiences glued to their seats at the Leicester Square Theatre in London's West End.

story:
Hey there!

Thanks for stopping by!

Here's the quick version. My mom is an artist, living in the Pacific Northwest. I care about her (naturally) and want to get her work into the world. It's been on my mind for a while. Now, I'm a choreographer... And one day, the idea came to me to make her work into costumes (and other things).

So, this is what this campaign is about: making art from art, page to stage, and supporting the creativity of two people -- a mother & a son.

More specifically, if you want to see the work in action:

I'm choreographing a >10 minute dance for RAW Artists' Washington D.C. event, "Stella," on Thursday, October 24th and will be using these funds to offset the production costs, including: printing art on 5+ yards of material ($350+); working with two DC dancers for the performance ($300+); time in the rehearsal studio ($250+); and, additional marketing  & production costs.

The great news is that your support of this project will make it possible for me to bring her work out into the world in a unique way. And, the impact will be far greater than a single performance. This is really an opportunity for me to develop an audience (+ platform) for her work, so that we can create an engine that will foster support for more art to show up in the world.

Love & Gratitude,

Mathew Heggem
Artist, Curator, Choreographer, etc.
#ArtsMeetsBiz

story:
Announcing Our THEATER 2020: 2018-2019 mainstage productions!

2 Musicals in 1 “Stand Together” Season!

INTO THE WOODS and THE CRADLE WILL ROCK

As we enter our 9th Season, in a year so ripe with controversy, we believe it is paramount that we all “Stand Together.” Our 2 musicals both represent the power of the many over the individual, whether it's working together to overcome a “Giant”, or uniting to rock the cradle of the 1%! 

First up, the marvelous Sondheim/Lapine hit Into the Woods, where the characters in the fairy tales of Grimm, come alive wishing for a better life, first looking out only to their own self-interest, but learning in the end that true happiness comes from a collective caring about others. Slippers, golden eggs, towers, witches, princes, all just amount to a handful of beans without friends. Told in a hilarious book by James Lapine with glorious music and lyrics by the master Stephen Sondheim, we discover that while we may lament our lot, we can do something about it, just remembering “No One Is Alone!”

Then, well, we love Shakespeare, but feel it’s time to shake things up, so our Shakespeare at Sunset for this year will be Sunset Shakes when we bring you the historic American musical, Marc Blitzstein’s The Cradle will Rock. Born in 1937 during the Great Depression, Cradle sings a tale of the downtrodden, the 99%, who ultimately rise together. In Cradle we see artists selling out to the wealthy, healthcare influenced by big money, the press owned by big business, the church controlled by its donors and war encouraged for corporate greed. Sound familiar? We laugh at the lampooned stereotypes, all the while discovering what our hero Larry Foreman knows: together that “Cradle Will Rock!”

Both productions will be directed by David Fuller, with choreography by Judith Jarosz. This award-winning team brings to Brooklyn the high quality of professional theater which you have seen in other Theater 2020 ventures, such as Candide,A Little Night Music,Sweeney Todd, and last year’s Assassins.  

Theater 2020, Visions for a new Millennium is guided by award winning theater artists David Fuller and Judith Jarosz who have produced and directed well over a hundred shows, Regionally, Off Broadway, and in NYC’s Indie Theatre (Off Off Broadway). They have been recognized with multiple awards and nominations including The National GLAAD awards, OOBR Awards, NYtheatre.com People of the Year, and New York Innovative Theater Awards.

We believe live performance is an important part of a healthy culture and we are committed to diversity, remaining dedicated to our multi-cultural Brooklyn audiences and artists alike. Please help us to continue this vital work by making a tax-deductible donation today and play a huge part in supporting Theater 2020’s continuing vision!

WHAT WE NEED & WHAT YOU GET

We need your help to pay the rent on our theater space in Brooklyn Heights! Last season, through your generosity we were able to secure the beautiful Founders Hall Theater at St. Frances College for Sondheim's ASSASSINS -- and the critically acclaimed production was wonderful! This year we are again going back to Founders Hall Theater, but the the costs are equally high, and we are producing two musicals! Other past venues are still being renovated from storm damage or otherwise unavailable this season, so as rental costs continue to rise everywhere we need your help to cover the rent for our 2019  season!

Theater 2020, Inc. is officially incorporated as a 501(c)(3) non-profit, so ANY donation you make to us a TAX DEDUCTIBLE contribution for you! We are also offering all kinds of “thank you” incentives at multiple levels of giving! Check them out!

YOUR IMPACT

Thanks to you - thousands of people can continue to see low cost or FREE Theater 2020 professional level events and productions and we would be able to continue our support for emerging performers, diversity in our community and greater opportunities for women artists.

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

If you are unable to contribute even $10, there are many other ways that you can still help! Help spread the word about our campaign to others, follow Theater 2020 on Facebook, Instagram and Twitter, or just attend an event!  We would love to have you be a part of our community. 

We are always looking for volunteers for various aspects of our productions. Additionally if you have any services, materials, or other in-kind donations in lieu of monetary contributions, please email us at theater2020 at gmail.com to learn more!

MORE ABOUT US

Theater 2020 is the only professional Equity theater based in Brooklyn Heights. Founded in 2010, Theater 2020’s mission is dedicated to reaching out to the community and to producing quality theater that is affordable or FREE, utilizing established professionals and fostering young artists as they emerge into the theatrical mainstream.

We are committed to diversity and inclusion, always seeking ways to cast, as our union says, “Non-traditionally,” and we are particularly aware of the gender disparity in our profession, so we have a particular emphasis on providing more opportunities for women in theater.

We produce classic and contemporary plays and musicals for a 21st Century audience and provide a nurturing atmosphere for emerging artists to work alongside seasoned professionals in a positive program of creativity.

We founded “Shakespeare at Sunset,” in 2011 and we continue to- provide FREE performances outdoors for our community, now in Cadman Plaza Park. We present our FREE “Hearthside Reading Series,” stage readings of new plays and neglected classics, every few months at the Brooklyn Heights Public Library. We produce a full scale musical each winter in our neighborhood, offering tickets at prices well below Off Broadway, including deeply discounted tickets to seniors and students, plus FREE tickets to certain groups as well. Our recent musicals: the multi-nominated and award winning, audience adored and critically acclaimed “A Little Night Music” in 2016, “Sweeney Todd” in 2017 and "Assassins" in 2018. We plan to continue our foray into the world of Sondheim with “Into The Woods” in 2018. But we need your help to continue!

story:
Here For Now is thrilled to be producing the world premiere of a new play by Stratford's own Mark Weatherley. Our companies focus is on new or underproduced plays that centre around complex, imperfect female protagonists. Speaking of which.....

Whack! is based on the true story of Angelina Napolitano; a young Italian immigrant who murdered her abusive husband in 1911, igniting a public debate about domestic violence and the death penalty. She was the first woman in Canada to use the battered woman defense on a murder charge. Whack! tells this story in a series of fast paced, kaleidoscopic scenes that are at once gut wrenching, gripping, sometimes funny and always fascinating. We are so excited to bring this story to Stratford, but WE NEED YOUR HELP TO PULL IT OFF. 

Donating to this project will enable us to pay wages to the professional artists we have hired, rent the rehearsal/ performance space, market the play through sponsored facebook ads, rent equipment and pay for the design elements of the show. Our goal is to simply break even, so we can continue to produce new plays and do the work that we love.

We are hoping to raise 1/3 of the cost of this production through this campaign and any size donation is greatly appreciated. What's in it for me you ask? Check out the cool perks that come with donating! Treat yourself to a fabulous dinner, gift basket, some yoga, or even a trip to The Morhaven all while feeling great about helping us get this baby off the ground.

Another great way to support us is to come and see the show! Performances are Oct 24th to Nov 3rd at the Knox church amphitheatre space in Stratford. Get your tickets at whack.simpletix.com or in person at Pazzo pizzeria.

story:
What We Need & What You Get

Funding our project will help us with the following:

  • Booking affordable rehearsal space for our cast, musicians and dancer to practice learning music, staging and choreography.
  • Helping pay our amazing designers, creators, musicians, and actors for the time and love they put into this project. 
  • Obtaining production elements such as sets, period costumes, props and more. 
  • With certain donation levels you qualify for certain perks such as off-Broadway tickets to shows, Corkscrew Festival passes, a video thank you from the cast, or producer credit in all festival programs.

The Impact 

  • Your support will bring a diverse set of theatremakers and opera talent to the NYC stage. A rarity in today's age and something that our team and production are desperately trying to change in the opera canon. 

  • Allowing a new work that challenges a classic theatrical text to exist at the Corkscrew Theatre Festival and Rites of Spring Theatre Festival. 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • If you can't contribute at this time we would still love to see you at the show. You can get tickets a the Rites of Spring Festival or at the Corkscrew Festival. Both website are posted below:
    • http://www.ritesmusic.org/
    • https://corkscrewfestival.org/

Short Summary 

Inspired by the continuing relevance of Nora's plight, A Doll's House: A New Opera, composed by Grace Oberhofer and directed by Allison Benko follows the structure of Henrik Ibsen's original play, but uses music an extension of Nora's "gilded cage." Although Nora's domestic life honors manipulation over authenticity, she is forced to find her own voice when the masquerade ends. It is then that her musical confines begin to unravel.

story:
HOWDY!

My name is Maryanna. In 2017 I worked on a ranch in Wyoming and discovered a grave belonging to 'The Woman in Blue'. I found letters and criminal statements that told her story and wrote a play about her. Now I want to share it with you.

 

“What I am about to write is true

So help me God

Though I don’t think I got the time

To say it all..”

 

*

About The Show

Arland Town. Wyoming. The year of our Lord 1888.

Five brothel girls meet to play a dangerous game. They are telling the true story of the Woman in Blue, what was done to her, and what she did in revenge. Who plays who is down to chance.

Critically-acclaimed all-female theatre company Old School Players brings us an Old West tale of vengeance and love, treading softly on the graves of those whose everyday existence was a dance with death.

With 120 possible casting combinations, our five players decide who steps into whose boots with a spinning gun at each performance.

*

Six Serpents and a Tarantula challenges the outdated and frankly untrue stereotypes perpetuated by Westerns since the 1930s- between now and then 99.7% of western films have been directed by men. The show explores topics such as domestic violence and abortion with delicacy, skill and humanity from an entirely female perspective, giving a fresh view of this normally machismo-fuelled setting. The characters' experiences in the play are not a historical relic but a reality for women in poverty and places where those who seek contraception or work as sex-workers are legally unprotected/outlawed.

*

RESPECT UK

https://www.respect.uk.net

We will be collaborating with charity partner Respect to continue the discussion of domestic abuse in the UK. Respect is a pioneering UK domestic abuse organisation leading the development of safe, effective work with perpetrators, male victims and young people using violence in their close relationships. Respect supports frontline organisations across the UK, so that together we can end domestic abuse.

We want to explore these issues in Six Serpents and a Tarantula whilst raising awareness  for a charity that tackles domestic abuse at its roots.

10% of all funds raised here will donated to Respect to further support their vital work.

 

*

Our Company

“I feel most complimented that my play inaugurated the use of the amphitheatre as a playhouse.  I had a good review!  I mean, you did. Well done all!”    -Tom Stoppard, playwright

“Enchanting. You have really good young actors there. Altogether a memorable occasion.”                 - Roger Graef, theatre director and film maker

 

Old School Players was born out of the March 2020 lockdown. We were three actors isolating at an Old School with a captive audience of frustrated locked-down locals. We exploded into action.

Our critically-acclaimed productions in summer 2020 brought much-needed entertainment and sense of community to local people. These included 'On Dover Beach' by Tom Stoppard and Brian Friel’s 'Afterplay'. We are Players because we put on Plays, Playfully, like the ‘strolling players’ from Shakespeare’s time, who adapted to plagues by roaming the country spreading light and laughter. As offspring of those dark days in Lockdown #1, we are keen to follow in their footsteps and keep people’s imaginations burning in whatever way we can.

 

*

 

Cast

 

*

 

Creatives

 

 

*

 

This is where YOU come in!

Thanks to your contributions, monetary or spiritual...

10% of what we raise here will go to our charity partner Respect, helping to enable the work they do with perpetrators of domestic violence and abuse. That's £500, should we achieve our goal.

Our play will be able to tour the UK this Summer, appearing at rural venues as well as at the Camden Fringe. You will be releasing five actors, a writer/director, a movement director and a costume designer back into their natural habitat. 

 

*

 

What are we gonna do with the money?

Here’s where we get y’all involved in this here venture. Raising a sum of £5000 is no mean feat in today’s economic climate. You see, we were cookin ourselves up a lil idear involving a train robbery, a stagecoach and pistols- simple n’ straightforward, you know, the normal way of raisin’ some dough. However, we have been advised that this would cause alarm to the general public as well as hostile resentment towards our venture. We are reluctantly taking this advice… for now, dangnabbit.

 

  • Marketing. As part of the original idear involving robbing a train we thought we were being very clever cos we knew our wanted posters would be plastered all over the streets up and down the country. However… a social media campaign and unique Six Serpents merchandise is, so we are told, a more “Bona Fide” method of gettin’ a show on the road nowadays... but it comes at a cost. Consider dippin’ into yer pockets friends, to help spread the word!

 

  • Venue Hire. An amphitheatre. A church. An earthouse.  A pub. A bona fide saloon lurking in east London. These are just some of the locations where you will be able to come and immerse yourself in the gunsmoke n’ whisky world of Belle’s Wild West. Help us to kindly support these fantastic venues in hosting us.

 

  • Transport. Now, we got it on good, sound, medical, legal advice that tearin’ down the M25 highway in a stagecoach pulled by five, snorting, maniacal horses/members of the cast is simply unfeasible given “road safety laws” and whatnot.  Therefore, we humbly ask your help in funding journeys between venues via them new-fangled automobiles and locomotives everbody’s usin’ these days. 

 

  • Props/Costume. Now. The thing about makin’ a show about the Wild West is that everbody’s gotta look like they’re in the Wild West, darn it. And its not everbody got spurs n’ hats n’ corsets hangin’ in their closet (more’s the pity). On board the project we have costume designer Talia Le Sueur, who is an expert in clothing of the American Frontier and a first-class corsetiere.  (https://www.instagram.com/talia_le_sueur/?hl=en) Help us to bring these characters to life with Talia’s amazing creations.

 

  • Perks. Now we got some mighty unique PERKS as a thank-you-kindly for all you generous-hearted donors, including Six Serpents and a Tarantula T-shirts and bags with artwork designed by artist Hermione Fenton. (https://www.instagram.com/hfillustration/) We are also offering (our favourite) a post-show whisky with the cast, and the opportunity to have your name in the play itself... Yee-ha!

 

  • Digital Future Recording a digital version of the story means that it can reach a wider audience, those who are unable to attend in person, and show potential venue partners around the world our work. 

 

Even if we are unable to reach our goal of £5000, 10% of what we have will go to Respect UK, and the rest towards the most essential costs – whatever we need most to get this show in the road.

 

*

 

The Impact

  • 10% of what we raise with this campaign will go to our charity partner Respect, who are leading the development of safe, effective work with perpetrators, male victims and young people using domestic violence and abuse.

 

  • Alongside our performances we will be running free workshops in theatre-making at local 6th form colleges and Uni drama societies to engage young people in the arts - something that is more vital than ever in our beloved, struggling industry.

 

  • This project will offer our company the chance to reach new audiences, professional connections and also to secure future writing/performing opportunities. We want to excel in making theatre that can thrive in a pandemic and bring audiences entertaining, thought provoking and pertinent work, particularly in rural areas where this kind of entertainment and culture is currently lacking.

 

  • Your kind and generous contributions will make it possible for our debut play to premiere this summer and help us to take our work to a more accomplished and ambitious level. 

 

  • This project represents a pivotal moment in our careers as we are on the cusp of establishing ourselves as an emerging company with it, and we’re looking towards touring it more widely in the future, as well as bringing other projects we are developing to life.

 

*

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that during these strange times folks have got bigger priorities than a project like ours.

If this is you, thanks for reading all the way down. We hope this made you excited about what we are doing! If it did, go tell your neighbour about us. Get out on the streets and yell about us to startled passers-by. Tell yer grandma. Tell yer horse. Share this campaign on the interweb hocus-pocus: Instagram, Twitter, the Book of Faces. 

If you’ve got a coin or two to spare – consider spendin’ it on us. Don’t make us resort to robbin’ innocent members of the public at gun-point for funding. We don’t want it to come to that. No one does. We can’t go to the Camden Fringe if we’re Outlaws.

Whoever you are, thank you kindly for taking the time to read this missive. We’ll see you on the horizon, friend.

story:
2016 Update!

We are now crowdfunding for an international tour go to igg.me/at/faun for more 
 
Follow The Faun is now booked into the Arts Theatre West End for 1 week only!
www.thefaun.com for more info and tickets!!

 

 

THANK YOU!

Due to the generosity, support and enthusiam of a lovely tribe of cosmic light-beings. We now have the funds to front the venue, accomodation and insurance for the Edinburgh Fringe! 
Tickets for the show are now on sale here:

 https://tickets.edfringe.com/whats-on/follow-the-faun

There are still opportunities to support this project financially and in kind. Please take a look at our list and if there is something that you can assist with then please contact andyfaunblack@gmail.com

Marketing:
 Flyers & posters- design & printing, web design, web- hosting. Filming/photography/editing 
Press contacts!
Production:
Event production assistance for August 1st London show & launch. 

Rehearsals:
 Studio Space, dancers to workshop material, flash-mob attendees. Perhaps you know a dance group who would enjoy a workshop?

Equipment:
 Headset Radiomic & Portable PA system, 
 
Edinburgh Contacts:
Please put us in touch with magical creatures you think will be in Edinburgh during August. Locals and visitors and performers. 
 
PUNTERS!
Buy a ticket to the show in August at the Fringe.
We are working to secure a flat for the month with a spare room in which  crew and visitors may stay. 
 
Looking to the Future... ideas of other venues, festivals and gigs elsewhere in the world to take the show to.
 

The Show.

Andy Black (Billy Elliot, Young Hearts Run Free) has teamed up with internationally renowned director Molly Molloy and composer Richard Gallagher to create a high-octane immersive theatre piece peppered with fairy tale characters, pseudo-spiritual experiences and the occasional 30-second rave!

“Ludicrous, giddy and strangely intoxicating”    Matt Trueman, Whatsonstage.com

Think… the Pied Piper. On acid.  In heels.

You have been summoned!

A multidimensional light-being on a mission of love and pleasure would like to take you higher than the mortal man can measure.

Follow the Faun on a shamagical journey to move your body, blow your mind, open your heart and tickle your fancy!

The Faun is an ancient archetype who taps into our wild nature, fertility and primal desire to dance freely. A heady mix of raunchy dancefloor enlightenment, community cohesion, psychic liberation, and personal transformation.

Morning Gloryville's 2nd Birthday following FatBoySlim.
 

London Launch

Follow The Faun will launch in London on August 1st- there will be a very special event filled with a whole host of magical creatures and cosmic light-beings! One of them could be you! 
 

The Faun at The Fringe

Every year tens of thousands flock to Edinburgh Festival Fringe to see the cutting edge of new comedy, theatre, dance, and performance art.

For 26 shows back to back this August, Spotlites at the Merchants Hall will become the magical grove of the Faun and his followers. Each 45-minute performance integrates the spiritual, visceral, theatrical and comical and includes high energy disco, musical theatre ballads, and rousing anthems for a Love Revolution. 

The audience become the cast as they are taken on an interactive magical dance adventure with The Faun as their guide, narrator and choreographer. Each will experience a joy ride of emotions as they dance their way through a fairytale kingdom of delights. 

This is choral theatre, meets dance workshop, meets shamanic journey, meets stand-up comedy.

 

“A lighthearted, interactive workout... fun & entertaining, energising... A cosmic roller-coaster of a journey filled with sexual frivolity” Marc Pasternack aka The Funky Dubster
 

The Faun's Tale

 

 

The Faun at Secret Garden Party.
 

Thousands have witnessed the The Faun bring his powerful blend of dance, drama and laughter to the UK festival scene including Glastonbury, Secret Garden Party, Shambala, & Morning Gloryville. Many have attended his unique dance classes and workshops with Urdang, Onetaste and Artful Badger to experience the collective joy, healing and the ancient, tribal ecstasy which only those who truly Follow The Faun experience.

“The Faun. He is something truly fun and magical to behold! He will lighten and liven up any space he enters with his enchanted charisma and glittery escapades. Follow The Faun...it will be entrancing!” Debbie Zeffman, Onetaste
 

Join the adventure

Please support this exciting project and take advantage of the many participatory perks. This is a fully immersive adventure; supporters will have exclusive behind the scenes access, updates and the chance to help shape the story, songs and structure of an exciting new piece of theatre.

 

 

"It was an extraordinary experience as every sense was drawn into the movement, sound, light and images of the show. Putting it into words can’t do this piece of performance art justice, so you had better go and experience it yourself."
ELKE WIEBALCK
Everything Theatre
 

 

At The Vaults Festival as part of Artful Badgers Wild Worlds: Darksides which won "Spirit of The Festival award 2015"
 
Target Audience:
We wish to attract a traditional theatre audience, who would not neccesarily have experienced a 'rave' situation and give them the experience of dancefloor unity, fun and physical freedom. 
We also aim to bring the ravers and clubbers into a theatrical context, to make live storytelling accessible and attractive as well as presenting dance & play as a healthy 'high'.
 

UPDATE

Check out two pieces of music from the show, the first, a Disco inspired piece called 'Are You Coming With Me" here it is as instrumental but will be performed with lyrics AYCWM4.5 - PreMaster13instrumental by TheFaun   
 
 
And here is a video of Mama Knows... a lullaby that comes about halfway through the piece...
 
Dates and Places:
June/July
London-based work-shopping and development including performances at Morning Gloryville, Lyrically Challenged, Pride etc

August:
London Launch Event - August 1st
The Edinburgh Fringe 
September

Once crafted, the performance will go on tour around the UK, then Europe, and 2016 will see appearances all over the globe with provisional dates already set in Ibiza, Berlin, Adelaide, New Zealand, Sydney, LA, San Fransisco & New York.

 

Supporting this project will help to establish the show in a way that will help to create a sustainable future for the company and lead to the development of a large scale interactive musical.

follow us on twitter @The_Faun

story:
About this project

LCP Dance Theatre was formed in 2006 in London, is lead by artistic director Joanna Puchala. LCP is a multimedia and multiethnic dance company, which emphasizes on human rights issues mainly human trafficking. The aim is to bring awareness of inequality and violation of human rights around the world through the performing arts. 

With support of BBC Performing Arts fund 2011 for the best choreography awarded to Mimmo Miccolis, LCP created a unique human rights based dance performance "Rights(?)'. In collaboration with African Dance Company Tavaziva Dance and Bernie Grant Arts Centre, LCP stood for rights of equal race, gender, social and economic status. www.youtube.com/watch?v=iHOdkC48zTM

LCP has been invited to Edinburgh Fringe Festival 2013 and 2014 with very succesful dance production "AM I". The performance was a manifests against human trafficking to prevent it from happening. 27 millions of people worldwide are trafficked mainly for labor and sexual slavery and only 1% starts a new life in a safe environment. LCP returns to Edinburgh Fringe 2015 with a new multimedia dance performance ‘I AM' to stand up for human rights to be respected.  https://youtu.be/K66URIShWbI

LCP is an organization with opened networks to various artists and institutions, which through different forms of art and other recourses manifest against violated rights. LCP partnerships with Sophie Hayes Foundation, which supports victims of human trafficking. Collaborates also with Minded Institute - leader in neuroscience, psychotherapy and body - mind approach to an alternative therapy of mental health. Integrates its principles in a perception of survivors mind and what triggers it. Links it in the community settings of victims of human trafficking by providing them with a movement therapy and choreography. Our aim is to offer the victims an opportunity to be involved in dance theatre, which we are creating. In association with higher education in London (LeSoCo College), LCP runs the educational scheme to support dance students in their professional training by facilitating them with additional dance company classes/workshops and merging their skills with the company’s repertoire. 

The majority of LCP’s collaborators are volunteering. In response to our aim of bringing awareness of global human trafficking issue we are currently creating a new dance production “I AM” with a premier in Edinburgh Fringe festival 2015. The performance will take place at the Spotlites @ The Merchants' Hall in Edinburgh for 9 days from 23rd to 31st August 2015. 8 dancers of different multicultural background will perform. 

The outcome of this online fund-raising campaign is to cover some of the expenses of participating in Edinburgh Fringe Festival 2015 such as travel expenses, the cost of publicity and venue’s hire. The estimated cost of 8 people: dancers/technician, traveling to Edinburgh and returning back, publicity and the venue’s hire is 7500$. We are putting on a pledge just part of it 2500$ wishing that the rest of it will be funded by the other third parties sources. We would appreciate if you could support us by any donation of 10, 20, 30£/$/€. Please see another options listed by special sponsorhip pacages available and do not hestitate to contact us for more details. 

We are very grateful to all volunteers who have been supporting our activities by providing us with their unique artistic, intellectual and administrative skills. Without them and LeSoCo College, this and other projects wouldn’t be possible to happen.

We have a very limited time before the Edinburgh Fringe Festival in August 2015, however we believe that with your donation we will be able to proceed with our campaign of ‘dance stops trafficking’ through performing arts. This can only happen with your support. We would appreciate your help and involvement in the project. Thank you!

Find out more about us www.lcpdancetheatre.com

Best Regards,

LCP Dance Theatre

dance stops trafficking

info@lcpdancetheatre.com

www.lcpdancetheatre.com

-------------------------------------------------------------------------

"(..) visually arresting and so spellbinding troupe's energy and choreographer's interestingly off-beat approach" Dancing Times 

"Taking steps to freedom-an ambitious dance piece explores human rights violations around the world" - The Independent
story_txt:
About this project


LCP Dance Theatre was formed in 2006 in London, is lead by artistic director Joanna Puchala. LCP is a multimedia and multiethnic dance company, which emphasizes on human rights issues mainly human trafficking. The aim is to bring awareness of inequality and violation of human rights around the world through the performing arts. 
With support of BBC Performing Arts fund 2011 for the best choreography awarded to Mimmo Miccolis, LCP created a unique human rights based dance performance "Rights(?)'. In collaboration with African Dance Company Tavaziva Dance and Bernie Grant Arts Centre, LCP stood for rights of equal race, gender, social and economic status. www.youtube.com/watch?v=iHOdkC48zTM
LCP has been invited to Edinburgh Fringe Festival 2013 and 2014 with very succesful dance production "AM I". The performance was a manifests against human trafficking to prevent it from happening. 27 millions of people worldwide are trafficked mainly for labor and sexual slavery and only 1% starts a new life in a safe environment. LCP returns to Edinburgh Fringe 2015 with a new multimedia dance performance ‘I AM' to stand up for human rights to be respected.  https://youtu.be/K66URIShWbI
LCP is an organization with opened networks to various artists and institutions, which through different forms of art and other recourses manifest against violated rights. LCP partnerships with Sophie Hayes Foundation, which supports victims of human trafficking. Collaborates also with Minded Institute - leader in neuroscience, psychotherapy and body - mind approach to an alternative therapy of mental health. Integrates its principles in a perception of survivors mind and what triggers it. Links it in the community settings of victims of human trafficking by providing them with a movement therapy and choreography. Our aim is to offer the victims an opportunity to be involved in dance theatre, which we are creating. story:
Vous pouvez également nous soutenir depuis notre site web directement: http://www.killaflow.com/contact/don


En résumé:

KFM Crew est un groupe de danse créé en 2002 à Aigle, une petite ville de Suisse romande. Formés de personnes de tous âges de sept à trente ans, cela va faire treize ans que nous pratiquons le Break Dance et le Hip Hop. Plusieurs fois champions suisses, nous sommes également bien classés au niveau européen et avons déjà remporté plus d'une cinquantaine de titres depuis nos débuts. Lorsque que nous avons débuté en 2002 nous étions seulement cinq membres pour arriver aujourd'hui, après des années de persévérance et d'acharnement, à une soixantaine de personnes.

Nous nous entraînons de quinze à vingt heures par semaine et avons aujourd'hui besoin de votre soutien pour évoluer et avoir notre propre école de danse. Notre crew est une famille, nous sommes fiers de le représenter depuis si longtemps, d'avoir grandi ensemble et de nous être battus pour en arriver là où nous en sommes actuellement.

A l'époque, nous faisions nos répétitions dans le centre de jeune de Aigle, lieu qui n'est désormais plus adapté car il a déménagé dans un local trop petit. Nous sommes actuellement locataires dans une maison paroissiale, qui va malheureusement être détruite fin juin 2015 et nous faire nous retrouver à nouveau sans salle d'entrainement fixe, chose que nous ne pouvons plus nous permettre. Notre objectif serait d'avoir un endroit stable et fixe où pouvoir danser librement sans se soucier des horaires et faire partager à tous nos jeunes notre amour pour la danse dans les meilleures conditions. Nous souhaiterions ouvrir un centre de danse dans la région d'Aigle, une salle avec un bon parquet, des miroirs, des vestiaires ect, enfin tout ce qui pourrait nous faire nous sentir chez nous et améliorer notre entrainement. Notre art est souvent trop peu respecté par le manque de subventions qu'on lui propose ici et nous aimerions avec nos cours, notre générosité et notre envie de transmission, apporter aux jeunes, aux plus âgés, aux élèves et à tous ceux qui y trouveraient de l'intérêt, un moyen d'expression qui est le notre, qui nous a soudé et fait la force de notre crew depuis toutes ces années.

Aigle, notre propre ville natale ne dispose malheureusement d'aucune autre salle pour nous aider pour la suite et nous devons trouver une solution pour éviter de se retrouver à la rue avec nos danseurs, car nous savons tous que notre vie est liée à la danse, que cette passion ne nous quittera jamais et que devons la préserver. Nous avons tenté de faire de nombreuses démarches pour obtenir du soutien mais à chaque fois, nous obtenons la même réponse négative car notre sport ne correspondrait soit-disant pas aux critères sportifs traditionnels que ces entreprises soutiennent et dans lesquels le break dance n'a pas encore pu trouver sa place. Pourtant nous le savons, nous sommes tous les mêmes sportifs, avec le même travail et investissement même s'il n'est pas encore reconnu correctement en Suisse. En effet, la Suisse manque de compétition, de publicité pour que la danse se démocratise, et c'est à nous les danseurs, que revient la tâche de faire découvrir notre monde, le Hip-Hop et ouvrir les voies aux jeunes talents encore cachés et de partager notre savoir de cette culture.

Avec l'école de danse KFM SCHOOL nous voulons changer notre rêve amateur en avenir professionnel en liant notre passion et les besoins qu'a la jeunesse de s'exprimer aujourd'hui, à travers la danse notammenr. La danse avec trois petits points car la danse, c'est une langue universelle qui réunit dans la paix et le partage.

Ceci est mon challenge personnel et celui de mon groupe, car je suis fier d'eux et j'ai envie que notre travail ne soit jamais vain. Plusieurs fois durant l'année on s'est retrouvé à l'extérieur pour nos répétitions avant des grands championnats mondiaux et des prestations importantes dans de mauvaises conditions et j'aimerais vraiment éviter que ce genre de chose se reproduise. Si ce rêve de salle de danse se réalise, nous serions ravis de le partager avec d'autres types de danses dans la région qui sont à la recherche de salle, toujours dans l'esprit du hip-hop, du partage. J'espère que tout cela vous touchera autant que cela nous touche chaque jour de notre vie, lorsque nous écoutons la musique et qu'on sait qu'on est là où on doit être pour être nous-mêmes.

Michel Du 

Président de l'association KFMLIFE et leadeur du groupe KFM

  www.kfmcrew.com

story:
Short Summary

Minimum wage job, no girlfriend – how, James wonders, did it come to this? Maybe it was something to do with the three women with whom he had intense unrequited one-sided affairs. Maybe it wasall David Cameron's fault. Maybe if he hadn't spent so much time watching Gilmore Girls. Jake Westow Miller’s new play is a comedy about relationships, coming of age in Cameron's Britain, and a man who discovers that his one true love might just turn out to be television.

Love in the Time of Gilmore Girls, is a new play written and directed by Jake Westow Miller and starring Thomas Wingfield and will premier this year at Just the Tonic at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival.

What We Need and What You Get
A large chunk of the money will be used to pay towards accommodation for ourselves during the four weeks of the Edinburgh Festival. The rest will be used for props, transporting us to Edinburgh  and on printing and publicity. We have already raised a decent amount of the money ourselves through our own money and through other fundraising and we are hoping that this page will give us the extra push we need to help us achieve our goals. 

In return for helping us you'll get exclusive updates on the play's progress as well as being able to get copies of the script and signed posters and flyers. There are also opportunities to gain exclusive access with complementary tickets to performances in Edinburgh and the chance attend previews and dress rehearsals.

Who's involved? 

Jake Westow Miller (Writer Director)

Jake Westow Miller is a writer/director and comedian. Originally from Leeds, he studied at the University of East Anglia and has an MA for Writing for Stage and Broadcast Media from The Royal Central School of Speech and Drama. He has performed stand-up in various venues in and around Norwich, London and Edinburgh and his play The State of the Nation was longlisted for the Theatre 503 2014 Playwriting Award. As part of My Mate Dave Theatre he was the co-producer of the play Sex, With Benefits at Sweet Venues during last year’s Edinburgh Fringe Festival. 

Thomas Wingfield (Performer)

Originally from Leeds, Thomas is now currently based in Walthamstow, London. In 2013 he graduated from Mountview Academy of Theatre Arts, completing the acting course for which he’d won a DADA award. Before training he studied Drama at the University of East Anglia (2009-2012), where he performed in a wide spectrum of productions with various theatre companies. In order to complement his acting work, Thomas has become an accomplished baritone singer and a proficient musician, playing the trombone, piano, euphonium and guitar. His recent credits include Margaret Thatcher Queen of Soho at Theatre 503 and Robert in the webseries Citizen Z.

Thomas is represented by Janet Welch Personal Management.

What we hope to achieve

We have both graduated from drama school in the past couple of years. We are   attempting to make the leap from students to full time professionals. Although we do not expect to make any money out of this production we hope that it will give us experience of putting on a play in one of the largest and diverse performing arts environments on earth and allow us to gain contacts and exposure that will be useful in our future careers.

story:
« Un simple geste peut faire beaucoup. Ensemble, construisons une société meilleure fondée sur le partage et l’échange. »

               Guylaine Tremblay, comédienne et présidente d'honneur de la campagne


Votre soutien nous permet de briser l'isolement

En plus de 25 ans d'existence, Circuit-Est centre chorégraphique s'est imposé comme un pôle central de la danse contemporaine et un acteur dynamique du milieu culturel. Depuis plusieurs années, Circuit-Est mène des actions de médiations culturelles ancrées dans la rencontre avec l'autre, ouvert à l'ensemble de la communauté et à l'écoute de ses besoins. Nous croyons que la création est un merveilleux outil d'épanouissement personnel, que la danse est capable de briser les frontières de l'isolement, de l'âge, des classes sociales. Et c'est pourquoi nous nous mobilisons pour offrir chaque année une expérience de création unique capable de transformer ceux et celles qui la vivent.


Votre soutien nous permet de nous engager

Après trois projets destinés aux personnes aveugles, aux femmes d'ici et d'ailleurs et aux adolescents, nous ouvrons maintenant nos portes aux aînés. 

Et si on dansait ? leur permettra de revisiter — en tandem avec des jeunes — la pièce CINQ HUMEURS du chorégraphe Emmanuel Jouthe. Une pièce inspirée du chef-d’œuvre Les Quatres Saisons de Vivaldi. En créant des liens hors du commun avec la jeune génération, cette expérience leur permettra de briser l'isolement. Ce sont deux mondes qui s’interpénètrent, se découvrent et s’ouvrent à de nouvelles réalités. La danse est ici une invitation à communiquer, à partager.

Ce projet se déroulera la saison prochaine et culminera au printemps 2016 par une présentation publique.


Aidez-nous à atteindre notre objectif

  > soutenez notre projet avec un don
  > partagez le projet sur Facebook, twitter, et autres plateformes

Vous contribuez ainsi à promouvoir la pratique de la danse contemporaine auprès du plus grand nombre tout en ouvrant un espace de réflexion sur le rôle social de l'art. Vous contribuez à la promotion d'un projet d'intégration sociale portant des valeurs de partage, d'échanges et de tolérance.


Pour tout don de 20 $ et plus, un reçu de don sera délivré au nom de la personne émettrice du paiement.

story:
Our Story

“Record deals, headlining tours, t-shirts with your face on. It’s gonna happen and when it does you won’t ever have to send out another CV again” 

Unsigned is a new play with music written and composed by Stephen Lloyd. Based on true events, the story follows a band of South London musicians who, quite suddenly, find themselves on the road to success. For some the success is far from welcome and the natural dynamics of the group soon become strained and fractured.

The piece explores unemployment amongst young adults, the power of social media and the ever-changing cogs of the music industry. 

A unique, multi-media experience mixing theatre, digital video projections and live original music. 

Unsigned has been in development since August 2013. It was originally written as a TV Pilot but was soon altered for the stage. 

In January 2015, Unsigned was selected from nearly 200 applicants to appear at the Black Box Festival in Camden Town. The show performed to sell-out audiences under the company name Amplified Theatre. 

The piece received favourable reviews from both the press and audiences:

 "Unsigned is an engaging, enjoyable and funny story full of relatable themes and sentiment." - Everything Theatre.

“The characters and their separate plights were well written by Stephen Lloyd and well defined by a cast who created a loveable motley crew whose lives were easy to invest in for an hour and a half and enjoyable to watch.” - Everything Theatre.

"A funny and heartfelt play about the ups and downs of band life" - Jamie West, winner of the first Young Busker of the Year.

After the final performance, the cast took to the stage at an open mic event in a local bar and played through all of the songs from the show to an enthusiastic audience.

Following Unsigned's debut at the Black Box Festival, the piece was picked up by Kevin Sutherland from KDB Media and Ben Claybon, Associate Producer of the New Theatre Royal in Portsmouth. Together, along with Amplified Theatre, we aim to bring the piece back for this year's Camden Fringe following an offer from the Tristan Bates Theatre in London's West End. 

The plan is to produce the play on a bigger scale, adding more songs and more video projections, sharing the piece with a wider audience. We want to make theatre that is affordable, accessible and attractive for the next generation of theatre-goers; creating work for a diverse audience of both music lovers and frequent theatre audiences. 

The piece will also allow us to showcase some of the city's best undiscovered talent, both on stage and off.

This new production of Unsigned is due to run at the Tristan Bates Theatre on Monday 3rd to Saturday 8th August 2015 at 9.15pm and will last approximately 70 minutes with no interval.

Unsigned is kindly supported by the New Theatre Royal and the Academy of Live and Recorded Arts.

 

What We Need & What You Get

In order to successfully bring Unsigned back we need funding. Funding will pay for props, the set, costumes, instruments, marketing, wages for the actors and crew and the hire fee of the venue.

By helping fund this exciting project, you will be part of a unique theatrical experience; an original piece of new writing that we hope will inspire others to be creative during this current artistic recession where less and less new work is being commercially produced.

It is important that new voices are heard and that risks are being taken on new ideas. By supporting Unsigned, you are supporting the future of contemporary British theatre. 

There are plenty of exciting rewards on offer as a thank you for your contribution including meeting the cast, signed scripts, programmes and even a guitar. There is also an opportunity to visit rehearsals and watch a VIP preview of the production.

 

Risks & Challenges

When Unsigned debuted at the Black Box Festival, the project was produced entirely by Stephen Lloyd. He designed all of the marketing material, ran the social media pages, sent out casting breakdowns, made trailers, filmed and edited all of the scenes which are shown during the show, all whilst continuing to work on the script, compose and record the music, direct the show and organise all technical requirements. He even carried a bass drum on four different buses across London. 

There were quite a few hurdles, mainly logistical. Now that the piece is being co-produced by KDB Media and Ben Claybon, this work can be evenly shared out.

Like every production, especially with original work, the risks lie in box office takings. Will the show sell? Will we get an audience? There is never a guarantee. Many commercial West End productions close early for this very reason and new, original productions experience this most. To avoid this we plan to launch a strong marketing campaign through social media, the distribution of posters and flyers, radio broadcasts and a number of 'pop-up' gigs, giving potential audiences a taste of the show.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to contribute financially but would still like to help us fund our project, there are many things that you can do. You can help us get the word out and make some noise about our campaign; Sharing, liking and following us online is very effective and we are beyond thankful to anyone who does.

You can also become and ambassador of Amplified Theatre and help spread the word of Unsigned on the streets with us.

 

Those who contribute £5 or more should email us to receive your MP3 song and personal video message on amplifiedtheatre@outlook.com.


Get in touch for more information!


Thank you.
story_txt:
Our
Story
“Record
deals, headlining tours, t-shirts with your face on. It’s gonna happen and when
it does you won’t ever have to send out another CV again” 
Unsigned is a
new play with music written and composed by Stephen Lloyd. Based on true
events, the story follows a band of South London musicians who, quite suddenly,
find themselves on the road to success. For some the success is far from
welcome and the natural dynamics of the group soon become strained and
fractured.
The piece
explores unemployment amongst young adults, the power of social media and
the ever-changing cogs of the music industry. 
A unique,
multi-media experience mixing theatre, digital video projections and live
original music. 
Unsigned has
been in development since August 2013. It was originally written as a TV Pilot
but was soon altered for the stage. 
In January
2015, Unsigned was selected from nearly 200 applicants to appear at the Black
Box Festival in Camden Town. The show performed to sell-out audiences under the company name Amplified Theatre. 
The piece received favourable reviews from
both the press and audiences:
 "Unsigned
is an engaging, enjoyable and funny story full of relatable themes and
sentiment." - Everything Theatre.
“The
characters and their separate plights were well written by Stephen Lloyd and
well defined by a cast who created a loveable motley crew whose lives were easy
to invest in for an hour and a half and enjoyable to watch.” - Everything
Theatre.
"A
funny and heartfelt play about the ups and downs of band life" - Jamie
West, winner of the first Young Busker of the Year.
After the final performance, the cast took to the stage at an open mic event in a local bar and played through all of the songs from the show to an enthusiastic audience.
Following Unsigned's debut
at the Black Box Festival, the piece was picked up by Kevin Sutherland from KDB
Media and Ben Claybon, Associate Producer of the New Theatre Royal in
Portsmouth. Together, along with Amplified Theatre, we aim to bring the piece back for this year's Camden Fringe following an offer from the Tristan Bates Theatre
in London's West End. 
The plan is to produce the
play on a bigger scale, adding more songs and more video projections, sharing
the piece with a wider audience. We want to make theatre that is affordable,
accessible and attractive for the next generation of theatre-goers; creating
work for a diverse audience of both music lovers and frequent theatre
audiences. 
The piece will also allow us to showcase some of the city's best undiscovered talent, both on stage and off.
This new production of
Unsigned is due to run at the Tristan Bates Theatre on Monday 3rd to Saturday
8th August 2015 at 9.15pm and will last approximately 70 minutes with no
interval.
Unsigned is kindly
supported by the New Theatre Royal and the Academy of Live and Recorded Arts.
 
What We
Need & What You Get
In order to successfully bring Unsigned
back we need funding. Funding will pay for props, the set, costumes,
instruments, marketing, wages for the actors and crew and the hire fee of the
venue.
By helping fund this
exciting project, you will be part of a unique theatrical experience; an
original piece of new writing that we hope will inspire others to be creative during this current artistic recession where less and less
new work is being commercially produced.
It is important that new
voices are heard and that risks are being taken on new ideas.
By supporting Unsigned, you are supporting the future of contemporary British theatre. 
There are plenty of
exciting rewards on offer as a thank you for your contribution including
meeting the cast, signed scripts, programmes and even a guitar. There is also
an opportunity to visit rehearsals and watch a VIP preview of the production.
 
Risks
& Challenges
When Unsigned debuted at
the Black Box Festival, the project was produced entirely by Stephen Lloyd. He
designed all of the marketing material, ran the social media pages, sent out
casting breakdowns, made trailers, filmed and edited all of the scenes which
are shown during the show, all whilst continuing to work on the script, compose

He even carried a bass drum on four different buses across London.

Like every production,
especially with original work, the risks lie in box office takings. Will the show
sell? Will we get an audience? There is never a guarantee. Many commercial West
End productions close early for this very reason and new, original productions experience this most. To avoid this we plan to launch a strong marketing campaign through social
media, the distribution of posters and flyers, radio broadcasts and a number of 'pop-up' gigs, giving potential audiences a taste of the
show.

contribute financially but would still like to help us fund our project, there

noise about our campaign; Sharing, liking and following us online is very
