story:
From the company that brought you Bear Ass and The Witch and Bitch Sessions comes a campy and incredibly fun musical with a distinctly female voice: The Inconquerable Faith of Gladys Struthers and Others written by Kelly McTaggart and with music by Miranda Hughes at the 2017 Saskatoon Fringe Theatre Festival in Victoria Upstairs from August 3rd - August 12th.

This quirky play centres around the rivalry of two suburban neighbours, Gladys and Patti, and their teenagers, Joanie and Skyler. At the upcoming talent show, both mothers plan to out-parent the other with the amazing talent of their progeny. With the weight of their mother's expectations on their shoulders, Joanie and Skyler hope to “just get by”, someday move out, and maybe even share a first kiss.

Who are we?

EvilStick Productions is a female-run company in Saskatoon that strives to bring heartwarming and provocative entertainment to the Canadian theatre scene in our own particular shade of silly. We believe in delivering irreverent humour while providing opportunities for women and emerging artists of all genders, ages, disabilities, or ethno-cultural identities.

The Team

Jillian Borrowman is a founding member of EvilStick Productions and will be directing Gladys. Her select directing credits include With Glowing Hearts for Obiz Productions, Dr. Frightful Presents: Dead Air for Neverending Highway Productions, and Bear Ass for EvilStick Productions. She also stage managed The River for Channel Theatre, With Glowing Hearts for Obiz Productions, Bear Ass for EvilStick Productions, and Into The Woods for Greystone Theatre. 

Miranda Hughes is a founding member of EvilStick Productions and will be playing Patti in Gladys. Select acting credits include Straight Up for Small But Mighty, The River for Channel Theatre, Danny King of the Basement and Undercover for Persephone Theatre, Bear Ass for EvilStick Productions, and Madama Butterfly and Carmen for the Saskatoon Opera. 

Lauren May is a founding member of EvilStick Productions and will be playing Joanie in Gladys. Her select credits include Peter and the Starcatcher for Globe Theatre, Hypneurosis for It's Not a Box Theatre, Bear Ass for EvilStick Productions, Madama Butterfly for the Saskatoon Opera, Downstream for the Global Institute for Water Security, and Money Don't Grow on Trees for Neverending Highway Productions. 

Mitchell Larsen is joining EvilStick Productions for the first time as Skyler in Gladys. Mitchell's select acting credits include Narrow Path and You're a Good Man Charlie Brown for Prairie Skies Theatre. Along with being a company member of Free Flow Dance Centre, Mitchell is a poet and musician in the Saskatoon arts community who loves to collaborate and create new work and was a finalist in Saskatoon's Tonight It's Poetry 2016.

Kelly McTaggart is a founding member of EvilStick Productions and will be playing the title role in Gladys. Select acting credits include Munsch It Up for Wide Open Children's Theatre, Hypneurosis for It's Not a Box Theatre, Bear Ass for EvilStick Productions, The Loveseat for Scantily Glad Theatre, Madama Butterfly for the Saskatoon Opera, and Downstream for the Global Institute for Water Secutiry. 

More About the Show

Kelly wrote The Inconquerable Faith of Gladys Struthers and Others over 2 years ago during the Saskatchewan Playwright Centre’s 24 Hour Playwriting Competition, where her work earned her 1st place in the student category and 2nd overall. Since then, Gladys has been worked on with Saskatchewan theatre professionals and emerging artists, and was most recently workshopped at the 2016 Spring Festival of New Plays where it was well received.

Come see Gladys at the 2017 Saskatoon Fringe Theatre Festival in Victoria Upstairs:

Thursday, August 3  – 8:50pm-9:50pm

Saturday, August 5 –  4:10pm-5:10pm

Sunday, August 6 –  7:40pm-8:40pm

Tuesday, August 8 – 9:35pm-10:35pm

Thursday, August 10 –  5:55pm-6:55pm

Friday, August 11 – 7:40pm-8:40pm

Saturday, August 12 – 5:55pm-6:55pm

What are we using the money for?

We're making theatre, which means buying costumes, building a set, covering production costs, promoting the hell out of our show, and *hopefully* feeding our artists who are working tirelessly to make this the best EvilStick production yet! If we go above and beyond our fundraising goals, the leftover money will be going toward touring Gladys around Canada next year and building a nest egg for our company. 

Below is a breakdown on some of the costs associated with this production:

Posters $65 through Vistaprint

Handbills $75 through Vistaprint 

Rehearsal Space $50 non-refundable deposit for a key to our rehearsal space

Props $100 

Costume Design $300 as designed by Miranda Hughes

Set Design $400 as designed by Jillian Borrowman

Travel $1,385 to cover the flights from Toronto to Saskatoon for Miranda and Kelly as estimated through WestJet

Saskatoon Fringe Administration Fee $730

Artist Fees* $13,970 

We are proud to say that we are partnering with The Open Storefront Project, which has allowed us a free space to rehearse throughout the month of July. If you aren't familiar with them, please check them out! They provide amazing opportunities for artists in Saskatoon.

* Artist fees are estimated using CAEA "G" House wage guidelines at $628/week for our four actors throughout our 4 weeks of rehearsals and one week of shows. In addition, our director would be paid a sum of $1,409.50 using CAEA "G" House wage guidelines. This is very important to us because it means paying our artists a living wage. We are hoping to get as close to this goal as possible through our fundraising efforts and are happy to answer any questions you may have regarding the work of an actor, director, designer, etc. and how the Canadian Actor's Equity Association comes up with their numbers. 

What will you get out of it?

Other than that great feeling you get when supporting local art, you will be helping us produce our show - this won't only help to build a strong theatre community, but it will make you a valuable part of it. You will also be the first to receive perks and information on upcoming EvilStick events and shows.  Speaking of perks, we will be accepting contributions up until the end of our run at the 2017 YXE Fringe, and boy do we have some cool things up for grabs:

  • EvilStick/Gladys buttons
  • Signed Gladys posters
  • EvilStick T-shirts (yes, they will be tie dyed)
  • Tickets to our show
  • A portrait painted of your beautiful mug by one of EvilStick's founding members
  • Shout outs at our show and on social media
  • Producer status
  • A private show (and get this) anywhere you want
  • Our undying love and support <3

Why should you support this show?

EvilStick Productions is proudly in its third season, which means we have a solid past together where we have written, directed, and acted in successful shows. This year, we are stepping up our game, and with a fully formed script written by Kelly McTaggart, music by Miranda Hughes, and the wonderful Jillian Borrowman directing us, we are set up for our best year ever. Having already workshopped this script with the Saskatoon and Regina theatre communities, we have had successful feedback and are now ready and excited to bring this show to life at the 2017 Saskatoon Fringe. We have our show, we have a strong bond as a group of hard-working individuals, and we have a fully-formed vision. All we need is your contribution!

But *gasp* what about the risks!?

With any art venture, there are bound to be risks! We have faced many of them over the last two years, and are well on our way to overcoming a few that have already been thrown at us this year. With that being said, we have a fully-formed show, a strong vision, and we have our spot at the Saskatoon Fringe. There is nothing stopping us from putting up an amazing show, but what will bring it to the next level is the community support needed to make it truly shine (paper bag costumes and cardboard instruments will not stop us from putting this show up, but we would appreciate some real clothes, thx).

Other Fundraising

We have already raised a bit of money with an amazing Karaoke Steak Night we held in May, we are actively seeking sponsorships and donations of any kind, and we will be holding a Lip Synch for Your Life battle at the end of July (follow us on social media for more information on our upcoming events)! We have a successful track record and want to keep the momentum going up until our show in August. We want you to know just how much it means to us to make this project our best yet. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Are you not able to contribute but want to help us out? We would love you to make some noise about our campaign! Feel free to share this page, like and follow us on social media, and tell all your friends about the awesomeness that is EvilStick Productions. Most importantly, come out to the Saskatoon Fringe and let us entertain you!

Facebook

Instagram

Signed Gladys posters
EvilStick T-shirts (yes, they will be tie dyed)
Tickets to our show
A portrait painted of your beautiful mug by one of EvilStick's founding members
Shout outs at our show and on social media
Producer status
A private show (and get this) anywhere you want
Our undying love and support <3

Why should you support this show?
EvilStick Productions is proudly in its third season, which means we have a solid past together where we have written, directed, and acted in successful shows. This year, we are stepping up our game, and with a fully formed script written by Kelly McTaggart, music by Miranda Hughes, and the wonderful Jillian Borrowman directing us, we are set up for our best year ever. Having already workshopped this script with the Saskatoon and Regina theatre communities, we have had successful feedback and are now ready and excited to bring this show to life at the 2017 Saskatoon Fringe. We have our show, we have a strong bond as a group of hard-working individuals, and we have a fully-formed vision. All we need is your contribution!
But *gasp* what about the risks!?
With any art venture, there are bound to be risks! We have faced many of them over the last two years, and are well on our way to overcoming a few that have already been thrown at us this year. With that being said, we have a fully-formed show, a strong vision, and we have our spot at the Saskatoon Fringe. There is nothing stopping us from putting up an amazing show, but what will bring it to the next level is the community support needed to make it truly shine (paper bag costumes and cardboard instruments will not stop us from putting this show up, but we would appreciate some real clothes, thx).

Other Fundraising
We have already raised a bit of money with an amazing Karaoke Steak Night we held in May, we are actively seeking sponsorships and donations of any kind, and we will be holding a Lip Synch for Your Life battle at the end of July (follow us on social media for more information on our upcoming events)! We have a successful track record and want to keep the momentum going up until our show in August. We want you to know just how much it means to us to make this project our best yet. 
Other Ways You Can Help
Are you not able to contribute but want to help us out? We would love you to make some noise about our campaign! Feel free to share this page, like and follow us on social media, and tell all your friends about the awesomeness that is EvilStick Productions. Most importantly, come out to the Saskatoon Fringe and let us entertain you!
Facebook
Instagram

story:
Who We Are

Bad Neighbour Theatre is a young experimental company based in New York. Since 2016, we have produced five shows, two internationally (Saint Petersburg, Russia; Edinburgh, Scotland).

What We’re Doing

Our first offering this autumn season will be an adaptation of “The Toupee Artist”, a short story by noted Russian realist, Nikolai Leskov (1831-95). The piece is directed by Vyacheslav Komarnitsky, a final year directing student from Saint Petersburg Theatre Academy, as part of his thesis work.

Leskov’s story is set at the beginning of the 19th Century in the provincial town of Oryol. It concerns the real-life serf theatre of Count Sergei Kamenskii, where enslaved actors were forced to perform against their will. It is a story of great talent – that of a prodigy hair and makeup artist – buried and lost under serfdom.

What We Need

We are raising $3100 this fall to cover rehearsal and production costs.

  • Audition space rental and advertising: $84.99
  • Rehearsal space rental: $1500
    • 30 rehearsals at an average $50/rehearsal
  • Production: $500
    • Costumes ($300), props and scenery ($200)
  • Performance venue rental: $1000
    • Three days of performances in Brooklyn or Manhattan

Why Your Donation Counts

In a time of international political turmoil, Bad Neighbour Theatre is bridging a cultural divide. Ourselves the product of multinational cooperation - our troupe now comprises actors, directors and designers from seven countries - we are providing American audiences with a fresh take on Russian literary classics, and a new window into Russian culture. We translate, we educate, we work tirelessly, and we want to make your world a better place.

In exchange for donations of $100 or more we are offering two free tickets to any performance of “The Toupee Artist”.

Donors of $300 or more are eligible to receive an original drawing by director Vyacheslav Komarnitsky.

We greatly value contributions of *any size*: $5, $10, $20. All contributors will be sent a personalised video-serenade, along with a message of thanks.

story:
Who are we and what are we doing?

We are a group of actors based in Los Angeles currently producing the theatrical Production of  "Italian American Reconciliation", by John Patrick Shanley, to be performed in November 2018. Our production team is formed by the actors;  Cassandra Jones, David Pesce and Marilia Colturato.

What is the play about?

"Italian American Reconciliation" takes place in Little Italy in New York City. Huey Maximilian Bonfigliano was married to Janice, who is described as being an evil person - she even shot his dog while they were together. Huey feels like he's lost his "manhood" and the only way he could regain it would be by having Janice back. Aldo Scalicki, Huey's best friend, tries to convince him with no success, to forget about his plan with Janice and says he should start a new life with his lady friend Teresa, who is not happy at all when she hears about what Huey is up to. Aldo, against his will, agrees on going to Janice's house to help his friend and try to make things better between them, or...make things worse...

  

What We Need & What You Get

In order for us to have a successful run, we need your support! Our team truly believes that no one involved should work for free. YES! - that includes actors, who usually are asked to work for free or in exchange of anything else that is not money. Being actors for so many years, and having had that kind of experience so many times, we think that attitude it absolutely unacceptable! Work is work and you have to be payed for it!   

Here we go! The funds will go to:

  • $2,750 - Actors
  • $550 - Director
  • $550 - Stage Manager
  • $550 - Technician 
  • $880 - License/Rights
  • $3,320 - Venue
  • $400 - Costumes + Set design + Props
  • $200 - Video editing 
  • $300 - Marketing  (banners, flyers,ticketing)

The Impact

Theater isn't exactly something that is sought after in Los Angeles. When thinking of Los Angeles, you don't necessarily think of theater. It's going to take extra time and effort to promote and drive people to come out and see theater. Theater is the foundation to performing. Before film, there was live theater. It seems to be a dying art in Los Angeles. We are all actors that got our start in theater and have worked on stage as well as back stage. We know what goes into pulling a production together so every cent will go towards making this the best production possible. On top of it all, we are paying our actors as well as director, stage manager, and technicians. We believe that no one should work for free. This is a passion project, however, our passion doesn't always pay the bills.

Risks & Challenges

We will be taking quite a bit of time off from our "survival jobs" to make this happen.  I don't know how an actor can be more dedicated to their craft than to try and produce a play in Los Angeles, right!?!?!? 

 

Our Team

   MARILIA COLTURATO

PRODUCER/ DIRECTOR/ ACTOR (Janice)

Marília Colturato was born and raised in Brazil. She started acting at the age of ten and performed with many theatre companies. She also worked as a circus performer. After attending one the most prestigious drama schools in São Paulo (Teatro-Escola Célia Helena) for three years and graduating as a Bachelor of Fine Artist at Fundação Armando Alvares Penteado (FAAP) São Paulo, she moved to Los Angeles where she studied at the famous Stella Adler Academy of Acting, completing the two year acting conservatory program.

https://www.imdb.me/mariliacolturato  

 

   CASSANDRA JONES

PRODUCER/ACTOR (Teresa)

Cassandra was born and raised in the "middle of nowhere" Illinois. She started studying musical theatre at a young age and later went on to study at Columbia College in Chicago and I.O (Improv Olympics).

https://www.imdb.me/cassandrajones

 

  DAVID PESCE  

PRODUCER/ ACTOR (Aldo Scalicki)

David was born and raised in Dearborn Heights, Michigan. He studied acting at numerous institutions including Eastern Michigan University and New York Film Academy in Manhattan, NY.   

https://www.imdb.me/davidpesce

 

  OWEN CONWAY

ACTOR (Huey Maximilian Bonfigliano)

Owen Conway has been living and working in Los Angeles since 2006. Credits include "FEUD: Bette and Joan" and "Sympathy for Delicious".

https://www.imdb.com/name/nm2760527/

 

      JO DELLAPINA

ACTOR (Aunt May)

Jo is from both Pennsylvania and Kentucky (Pennsyltucky?) and studied at UCLA and Upright Citizens Brigade. Credits include The Christmas Spirit (Surf City Theatre), Macbeth (Unlikely Shakespeare Company) and a whole bunch of student and short films.

https://www.imdb.com/name/nm8069298/?ref_=fn_al...

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't afford a donation, you can still help us by sharing this page across social media! PLEASE SHARE!

               GRAZIE!!!

           THANK YOU!!!

story:
THE LEGEND OF BONNY ANNE

 

OF ANNE BONNY:

So hear a grand Tale of the fearsome and bold;

For a Legend lives only because it is told.

Anne Bonny was a real person—a Pyrate, a Lover, a Murderer, a Mother—as notoriously brutal as she was beautiful. The very history itself is a drama that I never could claim to have written.

What precious shreds of her existence we have come from A General History of the Pyrates, a fantastically suspect historical text, penned in 1724 by Captain Charles Johnson, a suspected alias of the famed fiction novelist Daniel Defoe.  It seems a fitting twist that like Anne herself, her legend was born of a convoluted love affair, one between myth and reality. This liminal space is precisely where the play lives; in the shadow between Art and History, between what was and what could have been.

Fearsome, wild, and free at last, Anne Bonny plays her Part

in the eternal Drama of Fact and Myth; Her Story made Legend by Art.

Though an Age has ended, her Day has flown, her Fate is still disputed.

What became of her since, only this is known; She was never executed.

 

ABOUT THIS PLAY:

I was six years old when I first heard Anne Bonny’s story. Sitting on a porch, deep in the swamps of Charleston, South Carolina, my great uncle Deryl puffed his tobacco pipe and told me a most remarkable tale. One of Passion, of Courage, of Strength, of Honor—the Legend of my Ancestor. Though her Fate is unknown, this Legend survives. It ripples across the centuries, passed through generations like blood through family lines.

You see, my great uncle Deryl was an expert in local Charleston lore and genealogy. I grew up believing that we were related to this fearsome Pyrate Queen (which Deryl insisted until the day he died) and I became obsessed with the idea that Anne Bonny only survives if her story is told. I’ve spent the last decade studying dramaturgy and playwriting so that I would have the tools to do justice to this woman’s life. What resulted since is a swashbuckling epic pyrate adventure—written in rhyming verse, no less—with an equally epic musical score, written by the incomparable Steven Schmidt.

We feel it is our duty to help her Legend live, and we can only hope that you will join us in the Adventure.

ABOUT THIS PRODUCTION: WHAT WE NEED

We have a story that deserves to be told,

and we are finally ready to tell it.

I’ve spent the last six years doing dramaturgical research on this subject, and the last four developing the script. There have been two staged readings, one youth adaptation, and a radio play. Currently, there is a student adaptation being produced at the University of Southern Oregon. Through these various amateur iterations, we have concentrated solely on storytelling, and doing justice to this incredible Tale. Some of you may have even donated to previous incarnations of this project in the past; the incredibly informative staged readings that took this play from infancy to maturity and helped to shape what we have today; a play that is finally ready to be fully and professionally realized.

For the first time, we have the full force of a professional theatre company behind us, which gives us the legitimization we so desperately needed to take this project to the next level. We will be performing as part of the SheLA Summer Theatre Festival, the west coast arm of the SheNYC organization, which is devoted to producing theatrical works by women. You can find more information about this wonderful organization here: https://www.shenycarts.org/

Though we have their support in terms of marketing and performance venue, it is up to our production team to actually produce our play. That’s where you come in! If we were truly method actors, we would simply pillage the money we need for sets, costumes, musicians, and rehearsal spaces. But since we cannot, we have no choice but to do the 21st century equivalent of piracy: begging for money on the internet!!

This Festival is a chance to perform for a wide array of industry professionals, who—if they like what they see—have the potential to truly elevate this show. SO. For all of these reasons, we want our production the best that it could possibly be, and for that we need yer dubloons!

It would be difficult to exaggerate the talent of our creative team, and it is almost impossible to quickly convey the intricate and profound ideas they have for this production.  Suffice it to say, your donations would go towards realizing the artistic vision of our entire team, and would allow us to truly honor the spirit of this unbelievable Pyrate. 

So come, come my friends! Take up your ale.

Bear witness to this most Gruesome Tale

of Guts and Gold, of Blood and Man

Thus is the Legend of Bonny Anne!

story:
About The Dream Factory

The Dream Factory: The 60 Most Fascinating People is the first immersive and interactive experience from the upcoming company, Silver Dream Projects. The show has been created through a collaborative devised process by students of the SUNY Purchase College Theatre & Performance program. This project is made up of three major shows: Femme Fatale, The Exploding Plastic Inevitable, and The 60 Most Fascinating People.

            Femme Fatale just finished its premiere at The Dixon Place. Vulva, one of Drellas rising stars, put on a hell of a performance art piece which was preceded and followed by immersive and interactive pre and post shows featuring some of the other major Superstars including Taxine, the Duchess, Whips and IV, just to name a few. As does everything in the Drellas Factory, drama erupted when it was discovered that Gerard, Drellas right hand man, would be leaving the factory.

            The Exploding Plastic Inevitable, set for Fall, will feature one of the first major live performances of Sonic Daydream, a band with whom Drella has been working very closely for the last few months. This performance will also feature immersive and interactive elements that will continue to pursue the lengths to which the Superstars will go to earn their 15 minutes.

            The 60 Most Fascinating People, set for April 17th – April 20th 2019, will be the grand finale to the saga. It will be performed in the Purchase College Center for Media, Film, and Theater.  Drella will be throwing a huge party to announce and celebrate his newest set of Superstars, an astounding 60 of them. This final installment will push the Superstars to their breaking points as some will risk it all in order to be Drellas favorite.

Check out our website by clicking here.

About Silver Dream Projects

            Silver Dream Projects (S.D.P) was founded in 2017 by Andrew Wehnke and currently is comprised of over 20 Purchase College students from varying majors including Theatre & Performance, Dance, Film, Arts Management, Visual Arts, and Studio Production.

            S.D.P. is devoted to creating cutting edge Mixed Reality Performance, specializing in Immersive, Environmental, Transmedia, and Multimedia performance existing in the realm of Nostalgia.

           As S.D.P. is strongly influenced by the Pop Art Movement of the 1960’s, we consider ourselves pioneers of Pop Theater, a new experiential look at theater as it relates to Pop Culture and Pop Art.

Your Contribution

            The majority of our costs are found in the set design. We will be extensively redesigning 3 – 5 rooms, one of which is a 65’ x 55’ black box theatre, and 2 hallways. Approximately $3500 of the budget will be allocated to the set design, $1000 will be used for extensive costume design, and $500 will be set aside for marketing materials and purposes including merchandising. Aside from money we will also be happy to take noncash donations if you think you have something that will act as a great set piece or prop.

            We have a list of great perks with some exceptional rewards including interviews with the creative team, and special merchandise opportunities so be sure to check those out and see if your contribution matches any of the rewards.

            Finally, your contribution is going to help breathe new life into theatre. We at S.D.P. firmly believe that immersive and interactive experiences such as ours is where the world of theatre is heading. We see this with other great shows such as Sleep No More as well as Then She Fell. You can help us achieve the same level of success.

Have any questions or a noncash donation? Email us at SilverDreamProjects@Gmail.com with the subject line DONATION INQUIRY

Approximately $3500 of the budget will be allocated to the set design, $1000 will be used for extensive costume design, and $500 will be set aside for marketing materials and purposes including merchandising. Aside from money we will also be happy to take noncash donations if you think you have something that will act as a great set piece or prop.
            We have a list of great perks with some exceptional rewards including interviews with the creative team, and special merchandise opportunities so be sure to check those out and see if your contribution matches any of the rewards.
            Finally, your contribution is going to help breathe new life into theatre. We at S.D.P. firmly believe that immersive and interactive experiences such as ours is where the world of theatre is heading. We see this with other great shows such as Sleep No More as well as Then She Fell. You can help us achieve the same level of success.
Have any questions or a noncash donation? Email us at SilverDreamProjects@Gmail.com with the subject line DONATION INQUIRY

story:
The Baffling Adventures of Question-Mark Man is an exciting upcoming Edinburgh Fringe show that needs your help.

We've now entered phase three of fundraising, check out our poster!

The show is a lighthearted family-friendly comedy that follows the baffling superhero Question-Mark Man and his amnesic side-kick Forgotten Boy in a series of hilarious adventures. Taking inspiration from the Marvel Films, the 1960s Batman and Robin and a variety of comic book tropes, this show features physical comedy, word play and crazy characters played by a talented cast. 

We're up in Edinburgh for two weeks, from the 15th to the 27th of August at 12:00. Our venue is The Space on the Mile venue located at Radisson Blu, 80 High Street, Edinburgh, EH1 1TH.

Produced by Bottled Spider Productions, this upcoming production has all the right ingredients for a comic success at Edinburgh and we hope your generosity will help us wow the Fringe-goers.  

Here's a little bit about us as a theatre company: Bottled Spider Productions is an emerging theatre company dedicated to producing new work and revitalising classic works with a contemporary focus. Based in Norwich, Bottled Spider boasts an array of Fringe experience, and we believe we have the skills and experience to make our latest show a hit success. Both our director and writer were involved in a show in last year's fringe and we want to utilise this experience, and a pool of skilled actors from the University of East Anglia to create a five-star show.

It is our goal to bring an engaging, funny and poignant show to the Edinburgh Fringe this year and set a foundation for Bottled Spider to expand into more ambitious projects.

Your money will go towards Fringe Registration costs, venue hire and accommodation whilst in Edinburgh. It will also fund important theatrical elements such as costume, set and make-up, helping this promising project fufill its potential. Your support will allow an emerging theatre company to develop into a home of consistently excellent theatre for years to come.

We can also offer a set of exclusive rewards to generous individuals who are willing to help us out, including a DVD of the show that will be filmed in Edinburgh in front of a live audience and many other exciting gifts.

Thank you so much for taking the time to read our pledge, please share the word and give generously, every pound will be cherished. We look forward to seeing you in Edinburgh!

Fond regards, 

Alec Mann and Scott Younger

 (Director and Writer of The Baffling Adventures of Question-Mark Man.)

story:
Most of us have loved, searched for love, given up on love, loved love, and hated love. This journey is not linear, it weaves, it reflects, it moves forward, and it looks back. In one night, two-pieces explore different relationships with love. On one hand we’ve lost love, and can’t get away, on the other, we search, we get down, and dig. In both these pieces, love drives action, love drives emotion, love is in charge.  As humans, there is something in us that needs another half, this search isn’t always pretty, it doesn’t always feel good, but there is always something to learn.  

With that all said: We are doing it again! Movement in C is in the process of putting up another season! Two nights of original works. Both Salma Allam & Cathy Richards are reviving favorite pieces to share with you. We proudly present Original Love? On Thursday, May 5th 2016, & Friday, May 6th 2016 at 7:30 pm (doors open @ 7:00pm) at The Brooklyn Music School, 126 Saint Felix Street btw Hanson Pl. & Lafayette Ave Tickets are $10 @www.MovementinC.org. $20 (Cash Only) at the door. This show is made possible by the support of The Brooklyn Music School & Playhouse.

It is with our complete passion and joy that we embark on another journey of creation and sharing. All our blood, sweat and tears have started running, for our next show. Help us put the band-aids on, get the towels ready, and have plenty of tissue. Your donations will go towards renting rehearsal space, costumes, paying performers, and marketing the show. 

We need your help in making this show happen, and in getting the performers & crew compensated!!!

We invite you to be a part of a journey through the trenches of love. Is there a happily ever after? Donate, so that you can come watch and find out. Together we are one half of a heart, with your help we can complete our love.

We appreciate any donations that you send our way, but we also need you to share our campaign on all mediums. If you can't give a dollar, share this instead!! The more you share, the more we get. Like us on Facebook - https://www.facebook.com/movementinc2010/ or follow us on Twitter - @movement_in_c

Movement in C is a sponsored artist with Performance Zone Inc (dba The Field), a not-for-profit, tax-exempt, 501(c)(3) organization serving the performing arts community. Contributions to The Field earmarked for Movement in C are tax-deductible to the extent allowed by law. For more information about The Field contact: The Field, 75 Maiden Lane, Suite 906 New York, NY 10038, phone: 212-691-6969 or fax: 212-255-2053 or for our national charities registration, see details. A copy of our latest financial report may be obtained from The Field or from the Office of Attorney General, Charities Bureau, 120 Broadway, New York, NY 10271.

story:
What is the show?

The Miserables is a parody of Les Miserables which is set in an office. Instead of loads of rioting French revolutionaries the story follows two unhappy administrators and their workaholic boss.

The show takes some tunes that will be very familiar to any Les Mis fan and brings them into the modern day, and specifically, into the head office of Land of Laminates, where we find Claire, Beth, and Mr Williams, who are all just trying to get through the day.

Having produced a short preview run at the Etcetera Theatre in London in February we know this show has legs, and gets a really positive audience reaction, but we need help to raise the money to get us to the Fringe.

What do we need & what do you get?

What the costs look like:

  • Fringe registration: £393.60
  • Venue costs: £1100
  • Insurance: £182.50
  • Online marketing: £250
  • Print marketing: £250
  • Clothes (branded clothing for the team to wear while flyering): £250
  • Set: £70
  • Accommodation for five people for the duration of the festival: £3000
  • London previews: £170
  • Pre-Edinburgh rehearsal day: £115
  • Travel: £400
  • Contingency money: £820 (To cover Indiegogo's commission and any unexpected emergencies. If not used this will go towards compensating the cast and creative team for their time.)
Any funds raised over £7000 will be used to ensure that all cast and creatives involved in the show can be paid for taking a full month away from their day jobs.
What we're offering:
We talked to our audiences a lot after our first preview, and we know lots of them have an axe to grind with their bad workplaces and/or colleagues. We want to give people that opportunity. As well as things like exclusive newsletters and party invitations, we're also offering the chance to contribute items to our set and even to name the terrible boss in our show after your own terrible boss. It'll be our little secret, but you'll get to spend the whole of August happy in the knowledge that they're being taken down a peg or two and they don't even realise it.

The Impact

We really didn't expect to have a lot to write here, apart from 'we make people laugh', but we were wrong. When we did our early preview shows we were struck by the number of people who approached the cast and creative team afterwards to tell them how true to life the show was. Everybody has a job - whether it's the one they're in at the moment, or one from the past that they've tried to forget about - that they've hated. This show allows the audience to open up a dialogue about those experiences and really laugh at the quirks and idiosyncrasies of those workplaces, instead of allowing them to fester and become something they can't even bear to think about any more.

Of course, it does also simply make people laugh in the moment, and that is absolutely what we're going for too.

But wait - Are you even allowed to do this show?

In a word? Yes. 

For a long time parodies were illegal in the UK. In fact, they were illegal right up to the end of 2014. That was kind of stupid, and it's a whole other issue. It means that they're not common, even now, because people are scared of the wrath of rights-holders. But parodies are legal today, as long as the original work is dealt with fairly. That means no straightforward stealing of material, no stealing of potential audiences or profits, and no using the source material to promote any kind of offensive opinion. And we're not doing any of that.

We'll be performing The Miserables 400 miles away from the original musical, and - while our tiny, 57-seat, Fringe show is really, really good - nobody who goes in with an urge to see the original Les Mis is going to leave and think 'actually, I don't think I need to see the original musical any more'. If anything, we think it will get more people wanting to go!
We're not replacing the original work that we're all huge fans of, and we're not using it to push any kind of agenda - we're simply making fair use of it in order to make a show that a lot of people will enjoy and identify with.

Other Ways You Can Help

We totally get it if you're not able to contribute to making this happen, but if you'd still like to help we'd be thrilled to let you:

  • Get the word out and make some noise about the campaign - If you have any friends, co-workers, family, or anyone else who you think would get a kick out of getting involved and having their stuff appear in our show, then let them know about us. Don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools, too.
  • Come and see us in Edinburgh - We'll be at Just The Tonic at The Caves, at 12pm from 4th-28th of August (Not the 15th). Come and say hi!
  • Come and see us in London - We'll be doing two preview shows in London before we head to Scotland. We'll be at the Etcetera Theatre on July 25th and 26th, at 8pm. You should be there too.

story:
Giwayen Mata is DELIGHTED to be celebrating 23 years of wowing audiences here in Atlanta and at special appearances in other U.S. cities. Now it’s time to take this show on the road with our first ever GIWA multi-city TOUR!!! Giwayen Mata is ON THE MOVE and we invite you to join us on the ride!!

Giwayen Mata has continually shared in Dance Africa appearances and she has traveled to multiple states across the country to teach classes, lead residences at universities, and perform original and traditional artistic works.

You can assist Giwayen Mata in preserving and sharing African culture, music, and dance by becoming an Ambassador through your tax-deductible donation.

We want our feet to touch and bless all the corners of the U.S. and everywhere in between. And we would love to travel beyond for International appearances as well – wherever our spirits and resources will take us.

Your contributions will help us make this dream come true as we raise seed funds to support our multi-city tour. Will you be our next Giwa ambassador? Donate today! We look forward the journey!


HURRY! DONATE NOW TO RECEIVE YOUR DONATION PERKS!

We want to give you a token of our appreciation for your support. Choose your support level and receive one or more of these fun party favors (aka perks*):

• Dance Class Passes

•Giwayen Mata Merchandise

•Concert Tickets

•and more.....

*Perks are subject to change and are limited to availability.


ABOUT US

GIWAYEN MATA, is Atlanta’s own award-winning, all-sistah dance, percussion, and vocal ensemble. Performing dynamic and soul-stirring issue oriented work from the diaspora, Giwayen Mata educates audiences about matters pertaining to people of color, women, and the environment.

For over twenty years Giwayen Mata has been performing their original pieces that have reached and touched audiences around the globe. Click here to read more about the company and the powerful work Giwayen Mata is doing worldwide.

                              

Giwayen Mata wants to thank you in advance for your support. As we continue our new year of programs, classes, and concerts, we are counting on the charitable giving of our individual supporters to help us continue to produce dynamic and impactful work. We are asking that you not only show your support by making a generous contribution, but also by sharing this page with others and introducing the work of Giwayen Mata to new audiences. This is the season to be thankful and we thank you in advance for your support!


THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT!

story:
Short Summary

I am an actor and theatre professor at the University of Southern Maine. I have also directed for several Portland, Maine area theatres including Acorn Productions, Schoolhouse Arts and the Crowbait Club.

The purpose of this campaign is to raise money to help cover the costs of a staged reading and production of three short plays  I have written over the course of three years. The plays are set in Span during the Spanish Civil War. They were developed at the Maine Playwrights 24 hour theatre festival and the Snowlion repertory companies Playlab. 

Contributions will be used to pay for actors, props, costumes and theater space.

Your contributions will help launch these plays to a successful performance.

Please help spread the word!

story:
Theatrefullstop have teamed up with both the Etcetera Theatre and Lion and Unicorn Theatre to present the first Pub Theatre Festival set to be staged in April 2017.

The aim is to encourage current drama school and university students, as well as graduates to stage their works to a paying audience. The festival will take place over 2 weekends in April (Friday and Saturday) and will allow for groups with a max of 3 performers to showcase 30minutes of work.

story:
Our Story

“Cockroaches” is an original translation and production of Bulgakov’s play “Flight”; his first draft, written before it was censored by the Soviet theatres and Stalin’s censorship committee; translated by Anastasiya Sosis for London audiences.

Set in a war-torn Russia at the beginning of the 20th century, this is a story of five refugees, fleeing the Soviet regime in hope of finding a better life only to become aliens in an indifferent country. It is a bittersweet tragedy introducing us to events long gone that are as relevant today as they were 100 years ago.

“Cockroaches” explores the modern day issue of the refugee crisis, showing how people are reduced to the very basic forms of themselves by the disdain of their homeland and the indifference of the rest of the world, truly becoming cockroaches.

Ukrainian-born director, Anastasiya Sosis, has first-hand experience of the ongoing civil war in her home country. She brings to the stage her personal angle and understanding of what it’s like to lose one’s home and have no certainty of the future.

She produced the short film “Seagull Boy”, about an old woman who befriends an autistic man believing himself to be a seagull. This film was broadcast on Georgian National Television in 2013 and won the best lead actor in a short film at the Madrid International Film Festival 2014.


Director's Statement

Before the civil war in Ukraine I used to watch the news reports on other countries and feel… nothing. Pity maybe. It was images of women and children crying and news headlines along the lines of “Another bomb hit the city of-“. I did not understand their horror.

But in May 2014 I was in Donetsk, my hometown, watching people prepare for the inevitable war, watching the civilians, who had no say in what was to happen, try and deal with the anxiety that took over the city. And when the war started I listened to the news reports, our own country’s politicians throwing dirt at my friends and family, as if it was their personal fault that the war happened. I felt angry, sad, devastated. I watched my loved ones drown in the never ending days of waiting for the war to end, hopes of returning to our home dying with every new day of news reports. And I felt betrayed. By my own country, by the media of other countries. I felt betrayed by the world, totally indifferent to the unfairness and the death happening in my homeland.

When I read Bulgakov’s play “Flight” I was shocked at how perfectly it reflected all the chaos, the confusion, and ugliness of war, and how the war affects people, forced to flee their own country. I thought that this is the perfect text to demonstrate not the indifferent facts, but the personal experiences of people.

I want to use this play to share my feelings with the audience, to hopefully achieve a greater understanding of the experience of civil war and fleeing one’s country, and being an alien everywhere you go. All the characters in the play have different fates, and yet, they are all irreversibly marked by their shared journey, and no matter where they go, they only have each other in this world.


What We Need & What You Get

How can you help us make Cockroaches a reality? To producer this play, we need £2,500.

Here's a breakdown of things we need to pay for in the preparation for the play:

  • Costumes. Cockroaches is not a period drama, but as Cockroaches is set in 1920-s we are looking to create an atmosphere of the 20th century Russia through some interesting costume details. 
  • Set Design and Props. As this is an independent production and we are working on a limited budget, we have come up with some creative ideas on props and set design. For example instead of using actual furniture we'll have suitcases. Plus, it's a great metaphor for fleeing!  To create a dream-like atmosphere we are incorporating shadow puppetry as a background for the action. And... you get to see cockroaches racing through shadows!
  • Venue. Great space is a key for any successful production.
  • Marketing. Posters, brochures, flyers, advertising space... you name it. We want as many people as possible to hear about Cockroaches and see it!
What you get is an interesting play performed in its uncensored version for the first time in London. Plus a great variety of perks - check them out! 

Why Cockroaches?

Everybody gets to see a bad news report but nobody gets to understand the struggle of an individual.
Nobody expects to become a refugee, and it can happen to people from any social class which is shown in our production.
With Cockroaches we want to open a discussion on what history can teach us and how certain political changes affect the lives of regular people.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Come and see the play! You can buy tickets at http://www.thecockpit.org.uk/show/cockroaches
  • Tell your friends and colleagues about us, share our campaign on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram... your local coffee shop!
  • Check out our website.
  • Like/Follow us on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram.
story_txt:
Our Story

“Cockroaches” is an original translation and production of Bulgakov’s play “Flight”; his first draft, written before it was censored by the Soviet theatres and Stalin’s censorship committee; translated by Anastasiya Sosis for London audiences.
Set in a war-torn Russia at the beginning of the 20th century, this is a story of five refugees, fleeing the Soviet regime in hope of finding a better life only to become aliens in an indifferent country. It is a bittersweet tragedy introducing us to events long gone that are as relevant today as they were 100 years ago.
“Cockroaches” explores the modern day issue of the refugee crisis, showing how people are reduced to the very basic forms of themselves by the disdain of their homeland and the indifference of the rest of the world, truly becoming cockroaches.
Ukrainian-born director, Anastasiya Sosis, has first-hand experience of the ongoing civil war in her home country. She brings to the stage her personal angle and understanding of what it’s like to lose one’s home and have no certainty of the future.
She produced the short film “Seagull Boy”, about an old woman who befriends an autistic man believing himself to be a seagull. This film was broadcast on Georgian National Television in 2013 and won the best lead actor in a short film at the Madrid International Film Festival 2014.


Director's Statement
Before the civil war in Ukraine I used to watch the news reports on other countries and feel… nothing. Pity maybe. It was images of women and children crying and news headlines along the lines of “Another bomb hit the city of-“. I did not understand their horror.
But in May 2014 I was in Donetsk, my hometown, watching people prepare for the inevitable war, watching the civilians, who had no say in what was to happen, try and deal with the anxiety that took over the city. And when the war started I listened to the news reports, our own country’s politicians throwing dirt at my friends and family, as if it was their personal fault that the war happened. I felt angry, sad, devastated. I watched my loved ones drown in the never ending days of waiting for the war to end, hopes of returning to our home dying with every new day of news reports. And I felt betrayed. By my own country, by the media of other countries. I felt betrayed by the world, totally indifferent to the unfairness and the death happening in my homeland.
When I read Bulgakov’s play “Flight” I was shocked at how perfectly it reflected all the chaos, the confusion, and ugliness of war, and how the war affects people, forced to flee their own country. I thought that this is the perfect text to demonstrate not the indifferent facts, but the personal experiences of people.
I want to use this play to share my feelings with the audience, to hopefully achieve a greater understanding of the experience of civil war and fleeing one’s country, and being an alien everywhere you go. All the characters in the play have different fates, and yet, they are all irreversibly marked by their shared journey, and no matter where they go, they only have each other in this world.



What We Need & What You Get
How can you help us make Cockroaches a reality? To producer this play, we need £2,500.
Here's a breakdown of things we need to pay for in the preparation for the play:


Costumes. Cockroaches is not a period drama, but as Cockroaches is set in 1920-s we are looking to create an atmosphere of the 20th century Russia through some interesting costume details. 

Set Design and Props. As this is an independent production and we are working on a limited budget, we have come up with some creative ideas on props and set design. For example instead of using actual furniture we'll have suitcases. Plus, it's a great metaphor for fleeing!  To create a dream-like atmosphere we are incorporating shadow puppetry as a background for the action. And... you get to see cockroaches racing through shadows!

Venue. Great space is a key for any successful production.

Marketing. Posters, brochures, flyers, advertising space... you name it. We want as many people as possible to hear about Cockroaches and see it!


What you get is an interesting play performed in its uncensored version for the first time in London. Plus a great variety of perks - check them out! 
Why Cockroaches?
Everybody gets to see a bad news report but nobody gets to understand the struggle of an individual.
Nobody expects to become a refugee, and it can happen to people from any social class which is shown in our production.

With Cockroaches we want to open a discussion on what history can teach us and how certain political changes affect the lives of regular people.


Other Ways You Can Help
Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:


Come and see the play! You can buy tickets at http://www.thecockpit.org.uk/show/cockroaches

Tell your friends and colleagues about us, share our campaign on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram... your local coffee shop!
Check out our website.
Like/Follow us on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram.

story:
Community & Art

Disappearing everywhere are the local community theatres, however in our small town the State Theatre has been the heart of the community for over a century. Designed by the incomparable theatre architect David Supowitz, The State is one of only 5 of his 22 still remaining. The interior murals are the only known remaining art by the R.E. Greco Co. of Philadelphia and depict the rich cultural heritage of farming and agriculture that embodies our community.   They could have been ripped out and sold.  Luckily our beneficiary chose to let them remain where they belong and they fall to us to take care of along with our “State”.  

However, the State Theatre is more than art and architects; it is our  community's gathering place.  When the Theatre went up for sale, a group of like minded individuals from all walks of life came together to start a non-profit.  We were lucky the Maguire Family Foundation saved the building, added air conditioning, new electric service, and made it structurally safe but the rest is up to us.  The State Theatre Preservation Society (STPS) will lease the theatre from the Maguire Family Foundation.  The theatre needs to be able to play digital movies and have audio equipment to support movies as well as live performances be them Shakespeare or local bands. 

The State Theatre Preservation Society is a registered Pennsylvania non-profit and our 501(c)3 is pending . Our mission is to preserve and operate the historic 1912 theatre through a broad array of quality films, performing arts, and education, thereby enriching the cultural life of the local community and surrounding areas.We will update our campaign so if you are in the USA and contribute save the receipt for tax time.  

We have come so far in such a short time just within our community - now we are reaching out to ask that you help us make the final steps.  When it was suggested we use Crowd funding to help us it took a lot of explaining of what it was and that there were people out there who would be willing to help.  You can help make new memories for our current and future generations and show previous generations what the new generations can do with this "crowd funding thing".  

By donating to this campaign, you are helping to gently usher yesterday’s small town dreams into our modern time’s hopes.  You are helping to relight the brightest beacon of art and community for our town and the surrounding areas. You are allowing artistry to thrive in a supportive small town. You are giving a child a memory of a first movie, a young couple a first date, a soon to be star a place to find the stage, and you are reminding the world of a simpler time. 

What We Need & What You Get

The basis of this campaign is to get the theatre back into a condition where we can get it open and back into the community.  The biggest hurdle now that we have the building saved is obtaining digital, audio and lighting equipment that works.  That is why we have a specific amount listed.  The $132,500 will cover the digital, audio and lighting needed.

What if we pass our funding amount?  If we are that blessed there are a lot of other items that need to be updated so if we get more funds than required we will put the money towards making those repairs.  Either way we promise to keep the site updated so folks know what is going on and where the money is going.   

The Impact

Full restoration of the Theatre will provide:

  •  A place for our seniors, families and youth to have a low cost, safe alternative to spend their time enjoying a movie or live performance 
  • A local theatre group to introduce people of all ages about live theatre whether it be acting or enjoying a performance.  Where did you see / do your first live performance?  Let us be theirs.
  • A meeting place for friends and community to catch up and keep connected
  • Sharing music - it doesn't matter what genre but sharing it with the community and sharing our community with others who come in to see us.
  • A real-life outlet for our local students to connect with the community and showcase their creativity and talents, be it graphic and digital arts, music, or poetry reading

    Other Ways You Can Help

    We understand that sometimes financially people can't help but maybe you or someone you know has a lot of social media followers and can help spread the word..  If you are in the area we will be having painting, cleaning and volunteer activities.  It's not all about the money - it's about the community and keeping art and culture in the small towns.

    What's Happening Now

    We are all about transparency - and well we love our State Theatre so even though we have just started this funding campaign we continue to push in our community to make progress. Here's what's currently going on:

    • Murals & seats covered with plastic for the scraping and painting
    • The ceiling - has had major repairs completed and is now painted!!!
    • Updated electrical service has been installed
    • Air conditioning has been added along with improvements to the heating system
    • Carpeting has been replaced and the lobby painted

    The State Theatre of Boyertown thanks YOU for making dreams possible.

story:
FAMALEE will have its world premier on the 21st of October of 2016 at the Ivory Theatre, in St Louis Mo.  

Most would say that FAMALEE is a play about a gay couple, but we would say that FAMALEE is so much more. It can be anyone's family or relationship.

FAMALEE, explores the topical and very real issues of adoption, fear, same-sex marriage, religion, love & loss, and the courage it takes to be an unconventional family. 

Can you imagine yourself living for 24 hours with a opinionated mother in law? How about a week? a month? Now imagine living with an opinionated, racist, bigoted, religious mother in law that no matter how successful you are or how much you love her child, or the fact that you and your spouse have given her a grandson son, you will never be good enough for her. Well, that is the life Raul is forced to have. You see, after a shocking misfortune, the grieving Raul is forced to care for his opinionated, feisty mother-in-law, Emma, who turns Raul’s life upside down and that is the beginning of it all. But the story does not end there. 

We've had a few readings of the script across the united states and here are a few of the reviews...

 "Oh my God, I laughed, I cried, I laughed."

"I went through half of box of Kleenex."

"My coworkers thought I was having a breakdown."

"I laughed so hard I forgot I was sick."

"Made me want to forgive my in-laws."

"Lord have mercy I want a relationship now."

"I loved it from page one to page 94, okay I loved every page."

"I finished reading and I'm still crying."

"Damn you Joe, really? You should have warned me."

"Oh my gosh!!! I'm all choked up!!! That was beautifully woven. I mean amAzing. I don't quite know what to say."

This indiegogo campaign is for the first phase of production including but not limited to pay or set designer, builder, lighting, sound, stage manager, director, actors and theater and more. Your contribution to our FAMALEE will make things possible and you made it happen. Your name will appear in credit on our program, website and any media.  In advance the staff and crew of “Famalee,” gives you a BIG THANK YOU and STANDING OVATION!

To sum it up, making art can be a crazy business, with a lot of unknown factors. We started with a script that we are really proud of. Then, we assemble the best team possible, and make contingency plans. It's impossible to guarantee everything will come together exactly as planned, but in the end, we will have created an incredible stage production that hopefully all of us can be proud of. It's a great journey, and I thank you in advance if you can help make this ride possible.

story:
About the show

Hi everyone, Anna here. I have been working on MYTHO? Lure of Wildness on and off for almost three years now. Starting the project with my incredible director, Caleb Hammond, it has grown and grown to include four other performers and a production team of ten! It is an ambitious production but already it is looking beautiful and I can't wait to share it with you. 

We want to create something really special with this production, a jewel of sensations, a heightened world, a sensory experience of enhanced stimuli and vivid images.

Our weekend of performances in Boston will be he first time this version of MYTHO? will be in front of an audience and is an incredibly important part of this process. You can find out more about the show itself (and buy tickets) here or about my other work, here.

What are we asking for?

Although I have received some support from grants these only cover a portion of our total costs. In Boston we're running a campaign for $2000 and this money will go towards production basics like set and costumes and also some of the costs associated with transporting and housing our New York based performers and designers. 

You can donate any amount you like, from $5 to the whole $2000, just type it in. Any contribution you can make will count and we will be incredibly grateful!

How we can thank you

First and foremost we would love to have you at one of our performances so every donation of $40 and over will also receive a ticket to the show. There are also a number of other perks available including thanks in our program and even a producing credit! Take a look over on the right and see what takes your fancy.

The Impact

The money we can raise here is going to have a real, tangible impact on the look and feel of the show and on how comfortable we can make our team - both these things are key to the success of our production!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you know anyone who might be interested in contributing or in attending the show - spread the word! Send them an email and include this link: https://igg.me/at/mythoboston

story:
UPDATE - Donate by 11:59PM on Sunday, October 30 and you will be entered to win one of five FREE parking passes at the NBC lot directly across the street from the theatre!
 

"A compelling evening of malicious wit." - The New York Times

"An evening of high comedy, high drama and surprising passion." - New York Post

"Perfect." - New York Daily News

New Fortune is proudly committed to presenting Great Plays, Rarely Done. We program for intelligent audiences. For the highest quality of art. And a higher quality of life for artists. Our inaugural production, Shakespeare’s Henry V went on to win Outstanding Direction and Outstanding Lead Actor in San Diego. Our second, Harold Pinter’s The Birthday Party, won for the crowded category of Outstanding Featured Actress.

 

Now we turn our sights to the San Diego PREMIERE of Christopher Hampton’s Les Liaisons Dangereuses.

It's not a battle between the sexes. It's war.

Let's make this Olivier and Academy Award-winning story absolutely gorgeous, and share it with as many people as possible!

EXPERIENCING NEW FORTUNE THEATRE

"Some of San Diego’s most talented artists are collaborating in the launch of New Fortune." -  UT San Diego

"Impressive" - San Diego Reader

"Altogether excellent" - San Diego Story

"Breathtaking... Outstanding ensemble" - JAZZ88.3

"Do not miss" - Gay San Diego

“A first rate ensemble”-  UT San Diego

"Expertly acted and directed" - Times of San Diego

“Terrific performances…Excellent company” - SDGLN

“So well cast, produced and directed” - Charlene Baldridge

“Marvelous” - SD City Beat

“Five stars” - The Examiner

CLAIM YOUR PERK

When you claim a perk, your generosity will be shared with everyone you're giving this gift to; you'll be in our programs, on our website/social media; you'll be a very important part of the entire production both on-stage and in the audience!

You'll also be entered in a DRAWING TO WIN the listed perk. And even if you don't win the BIG PRIZE, you'll receive a gift from us to show you how much we appreciate you; theatre doesn't work without you!

OTHER WAYS TO PLAY A PART

There are lots of ways for you to be involved. You can TALK, you can SHARE. Use the IndieGoGo share tools to spread the word about this campaign, and this production!

Les Liaisons Dangereuses

Plays January 10-28 at the Lyceum Space, 79 Horton Plaza

www.newfortunetheatre.com

Tickets available at 619.544.1000

story:
About us?

We are In The Quirks Theatre (ITQT), and are a London Based Physical Theatre Company in Twickenham. We are made up of 6 actors who have all studied Drama and Physical theatre at St Mary's University Twickenham. We all have a great passion in performing arts and an even bigger passion for story telling. We are always engaged and hungry to create something new and exciting on stage. We performed 'The Missing Girl Of Grigglewood' during our last term of University and since then have always dreamed in taking the production further, even to Edinburgh Fringe.

Our Campaign means a lot to us as we have a great ambition in performing this witty yet dark comedy to as much audience possible and also show to our audiences how much fun it can be to let loose on stage and invite them in on the fun. We are touring this show; starting at Salisbury, Twickenham, Wandsworth Town, Kingston and Edinburgh! As a new and young theatre company, we are learning that starting out without  support and funding is difficult. So we are in search of finding any support possible to help us accomplish our ambition in touring this show around England this Year. We appreciate every single penny as it enables us to cover costs of venue hire, travel and equipment used for the show as we have provided this out of our own pockets so far. To get this show on the road will be a dream come true and we can't do it without your support.

What do you get out of it?

For anyone who donates, know we are truly appreciative!! And as a gift in return we would love nothing more than returning the favour. We are a very friendly and interactive bunch a people who love to connect, So we would love to hear your thoughts and would like to keep in contact! Not to mention offer you perks if we receive big donations! We will send you a postcard from our next show location, dedicate a friendly shout out and post on our Facebook page and Instagram, or even take you out for dinner! lets mingle.

Why all the risk taking?

Our company is brand new and very fresh out of the box. We understand building the company takes a lot of determination and along the way, some mega risk taking and struggle. Nevertheless we have prepared to take the bull by the horns and are charging at every opportunity at full pelt. We have already worked so hard since forming the company in January and are adoring every minute of the journey with In The Quirks Theatre even though times can be hard in spreading the word about our new production. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you cant donate, we totally understand too.
But please, spread the word, share this very page and we will still thank you personally. Any additional information about our show and journey can also be found on our twitter, facebook page and instagram so follow and share there too.

 

Thank you.

We are In The Quirks Theatre (ITQT), and are a London Based Physical Theatre Company in Twickenham. We are made up of 6 actors who have all studied Drama and Physical theatre at St Mary's University Twickenham. We all have a great passion in performing arts and an even bigger passion for story telling. We are always engaged and hungry to create something new and exciting on stage. We performed 'The Missing Girl Of Grigglewood' during our last term of University and since then have always dreamed in taking the production further, even to Edinburgh Fringe.
Our Campaign means a lot to us as we have a great ambition in performing this witty yet dark comedy to as much audience possible and also show to our audiences how much fun it can be to let loose on stage and invite them in on the fun. We are touring this show; starting at Salisbury, Twickenham, Wandsworth Town, Kingston and Edinburgh! As a new and young theatre company, we are learning that starting out without  support and funding is difficult. So we are in search of finding any support possible to help us accomplish our ambition in touring this show around England this Year. We appreciate every single penny as it enables us to cover costs of venue hire, travel and equipment used for the show as we have provided this out of our own pockets so far. To get this show on the road will be a dream come true and we can't do it without your support.
What do you get out of it?
For anyone who donates, know we are truly appreciative!! And as a gift in return we would love nothing more than returning the favour. We are a very friendly and interactive bunch a people who love to connect, So we would love to hear your thoughts and would like to keep in contact! Not to mention offer you perks if we receive big donations! We will send you a postcard from our next show location, dedicate a friendly shout out and post on our Facebook page and Instagram, or even take you out for dinner! lets mingle.

Why all the risk taking?
Our company is brand new and very fresh out of the box. We understand building the company takes a lot of determination and along the way, some mega risk taking and struggle. Nevertheless we have prepared to take the bull by the horns and are charging at every opportunity at full pelt. We have already worked so hard since forming the company in January and are adoring every minute of the journey with In The Quirks Theatre even though times can be hard in spreading the word about our new production. 

Other Ways You Can Help
Even if you cant donate, we totally understand too.But please, spread the word, share this very page and we will still thank you personally. Any additional information about our show and journey can also be found on our twitter, facebook page and instagram so follow and share there too.
 
Thank you.

story:
WE ARE BLACKBIRD DANCE!

WHO ARE WE: Based in New York City, our project-based dance company looks to bring meaningful and relevant dance to today's audience, while enticing you on an emotional journey of what influences you through your daily journeys. We seek to do this through a beautiful language that only a few speak, but one that all understand. 

WHAT IS THIS CAMPAIGN AND WHY IS IT IMPORTANT? This campaign is to raise funds for our dancers and the artistic director to travel to the Edinburgh Fringe Festival in 2017. We will be SELF-PRODUCING A SHOW (please see WHY we are having this change below) in August of **2017**. Self-producing a show is a HUGE task, but one we know we can do, especially with Mindi's extensive experience of producing shows for the past 16 years!

This is important to us due to the magnitude of returning to Edinburgh and the Edinburgh Fringe! Mindi, our artistic director, was the only one who could travel and perform in 2013. This opportunity allows our company members to attend, as well as Mindi, and allows us to perform in the LARGEST FRINGE FESTIVAL in the WORLD! We will also gain major International exposure as an entire dance company! We will be bringing our New Orleans premiere dances "The Pleasure & The Pain" AND re-setting "The Starving Faithful"  which originally premiered in Lafayette, LA, with our southern company, Oiseau Noir Danse.

The magnitude of what your contribution would help us achieve is enormous: You would allow our dancers to travel and perform internationally, which has never happened professionally for most them yet. This opportunity would send the Blackbirds FLYING higher than we've ever flown, and we are trying to spread our general message across the world: The investigation of social justice issues, cultural struggles via a socio-economic lens while looking at human relationships and the emotions that ensure make us ask the ultimate question of WHY? 

WE BELIEVE There is NO LIMIT to HUMAN TRANSFORMATION.

The Blackbird is the symbol of life in the heavens (higher ideals, a higher path of knowing) and the color black is symbolic of pure potential. Between the two, we can achieve anything. 

What We Need & What You Get

Here is our breakdown! 


We need -- $12,480. Yes, it's a lot. But we are NOW Self-Producing our show, and our profit will be minimal. This is for exposure for the company, not about us making a profit. What IS important is that the dancers have amazing experience on their resumes and they are getting paid while doing so (which is something VERY important to me as an artistic director). This opportunity gives them BOTH! A paying international gig from a small dance company! YES!

THE PERKS!!!

We LOVE giving back! Here are the perks of giving to us!

  • Personally signed Thank you Letter's from the Company (and a little "happy")
  • Acknowledgement and Thanks in all performance programs
  • Starbucks Gift Baskets (limited amount)
  • Signed Photos of the Dancers in front of the Edinburgh Castle
  • Blackbird Dance Long Sleeve T-shirt or Hoodie
  • "The Pleasure & The Pain" video
  • Attendance to an open dance rehearsal with the dancers (NYC) and one ticket to "Rex", date TBA. 
  • We are working on other amazing perks - Stay tuned for updates! 
IF we do not reach our goal: (but we know that won't happen) the funds will be disbursed to cover production costs and dancer pay while we continue to fundraise to cover housing expenses. It is UTTERLY important that we cover the festival fees, which are broken down: renting the venue, fringe society program fee, box office commission, all advertising fees, costumes/props/etc., liability insurance (international), music licensing fees, venue marketing, flyers/posters, and publicity photos, and any miscellaneous costs we may not have covered. 


EDITED INFO: VERY IMPORTANT UPDATE!!
We were recently notified that we would not be participating in the Edinburgh Fringe Festival 2016 with Booking Dance. Due to a major miscommunication with Booking Dance and us not receiving very important information from them, they are no longer doing the 2016 Fringe (per their statement to us on April 27th, 2016). We were not notified of this prior to us starting the indiegogo fundraising page. We have updated all of our sponsors who donated prior to April 27th of this, and we have decided to self produce our own show for the 2017 Edinburgh Fringe. We will continue our Fundraising efforts and continue to run this page to help us raise the necessary funds. We apologize for the inconvenience and frustration that this may cause for everyone. We are working diligently to fix this and show our patrons that we appreciate them and will not disappoint!

BRIEF BIO OF BLACKBIRD DANCE:

  • DUMBO Dance Festival, Brooklyn, NY
  • Edinburgh Fringe Festival, Edinburgh, Scotland
  • International Choreographers Showcase, Guatemala City, Guatemala
  • HOT! 24th Annual NYC Celebration of Queer Culture - Dixon Place, NYC
  • Mindi has shown other original choreographic work around the country as well!

Risks & Challenges

We understand that sometimes funding does not come through completely. With this scale of a production we are participating in, we are confident we can raise the funds needed to go to Scotland. Not only are we doing this campaign, but we are also doing a t-shirt campaign, sending in our information to major magazines, and reaching out to local organizations for help (Updates about this coming!). Every dollar counts. We are also interested in establishing long term sponsors who can help us out at this time, and who are interested in having a seat on our board so we can continue to spread our message of awareness. 

Join us on our journey.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot help us monetarily, please join us in spreading the message. 

  • Share the hashtag: #BBD2Scotland
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools
  • And SPREAD THE WORD IN EVERY WAY POSSIBLE! We can't do this without YOU!

story:
Dear friends, family, and lovers of art!

We are incredibly excited to announce that Brookes Stage Company is FINALLY coming out of hibernation and kicking off our next season with "Definitions: A Play on Love"! This fall, we teamed with alumni from the past four graduating classes of Circle in the Square Theatre School to piece together six One Act Plays for an awesome night of theatre!

What makes our show so special?

Each play has been selected because it highlights a specific genre of theatre unlike any other. The commonality between these six plays is the theme of love. Join us as we explore how the energy of love abstracts into new stories and definitions through different styles of theatre, whether it is satire, farce, or drama!

What We Need & What You Get

You may have already noticed that we have incorporated all kinds of special perks that are attached to the generous donations to show our gratitude. We have perks that range from a special THANK YOU in our program, to an invitation to an appreciation dinner with the cast and crew!

Our goal is to raise $2,000

This will allow us to…

•Pay for the licensing rights to SIX ONE ACTS

•Secure our performance venue

•Provide insurance for our cast and crew during the event!

• Supply costumes for our actors

•Afford rehearsal space

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute, that doesn't mean you can't help! Get the word out to folks, and make some noise about the campaign by following us on our social media platform!

FB: www.facebook.com/BrookesStage

IG: @BrookesStageCo

Twitter: @BrookesStageCo


Who we are:

 Brookes Stage Company, a new company based out of New York City that consists of trained artists from across the globe joining together to create theatre.
BrookesStage Company was given its name in honor of a professor, friend and inspiration the late Jaqueline Brookes. Her talent, support, wisdom, love and moxie pushed hundreds of young actors to find something in themselves. She believed it was important for artists to nurture their talent, stay connected to the world and
be true to themselves. What separated Jackie’s teachings from the norm was
she proposed the idea that in life, there are no disappointments, and that
there is no right or wrong. There are only exciting discoveries!

Our Mission Statement: To foster artists in their growth, and encourage discoveries
on stage.
