story:
Help us create this important film!

COMANCHE: Accessing the Legacy of Coast Guardsman Charles W. David Jr.

We need to raise $2500!

Your help is important. Please contribute to the development of a live performance work and short film that sheds light on the ultimate contribution made by military serviceman Charles W David Jr.

Comanche: Accessing the Legacy of Coast Guardsman Charles W. David Jr. is a live dance work that includes choreography by Duane Cyrus and music composed by Richard Bennett as well as film. It documents and explores the history of Coast Guardsman Charles W. David Jr. It is a dynamic multimedia work performed by an ensemble of dancers who carry the audience through the journey, pride, and self sacrifice often made by military servicemen. The title, Comanche is the name of the Coast Guard Cutter that David served on during WW II and where he demonstrated unprecedented heroism during a rescue mission to pluck survivors from the torpedoed ship, Dorchester. David later died from exposure due to repeatedly plunging into the North Atlantic to rescue survivors.

We need to raise $2500!

There are considerable costs associated with this project. Your contribution will help make the completion of this work possible. The film will be made available online and will also be part of the live performance. Duane Cyrus (director and choreographer) and a range of artists from other disciplines will work on this project throughout the summer and fall of 2016.
UPDATES:
We attended the Experimental Film Virginia festival June 26-July 10 in Cape Charles, VA. We worked there to explore the idea of "Rescue" on  film. While this is not the final product. It's an example of one way to explore the idea. Here's a link to the result of that exploration: https://vimeo.com/174346134

Duane Cyrus attended the Swampfest summer dance intensive and shared the story of Charles W. David Jr. with the students. They also explored the idea of "Rescue"––this time through choreography and improvisation for a live dance. Examples of these explorations can be found on this site or on Vimeo: https://vimeo.com/174949854
Here's a list of what you will receive for the following suggested contributions:
  • Any amount is greatly appreciated. We will be sure to send you a personal thank you regardless of how much you donate!
  • $100 and above: (all of the above plus) Acknowledgement in our printed programs for performances/presentations
  • $250 and above: (all of the above plus) 2 tickets to live performance or screening of "Comanche" (Dates and Locations TBA)
  • $500 and above: (all of the above plus) Backstage tour at performance of "Comanche" or meet and greet with artists (where possible) or signed copy of "Dancing a Dream" poster by Duane Cyrus and Joanne Savio.
  • $1000 and above: (all of the above plus) Recognition in film credits as sponsor helping to make this work possible and signed copy of "Vital Grace: The Black Male Dancer" by Duane Cyrus and Joanne Savio.
  • $2500 and above: (all of the above plus)  gift certificate for dinner for 2 on us! 

Who is the director?

Duane Cyrus is the director of Theatre of Movement, a performing and visual arts collective. He is also associate professor at the University of North Carolina at Greensboro where he teaches dance technique, entrepreneurship, repertory, and other courses focused on the development of well-rounded dance artists. Duane holds a BFA from the Juilliard School and an MFA from University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign. In between, he danced with the Martha Graham Dance Company and Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, in musical theater (including the original London production of Disney’s The Lion King), on television, and in a variety of other venues. He has worked as an independent artist and director of Cyrus Art Production LLC (2006-14) throughout the United States, Europe, and Asia as teacher, performer, and choreographer, and was also a visiting lecturer at the University of Illinois. Duane Cyrus consistently shares his knowledge and experience through his method for creating live performance called Accessing the Theatre of Movement. He has developed curricula for community outreach, intensives and arts-in-education programs for New Jersey Performing Arts Center, Circuit Productions, Museum of the City of New York, Charlotte Ballet, Ailey Camp and American Ballet Theater among others. Duane has received commissions and developed projects for American Dance Festival, Nannette Bearden, Martha Connerton, Noriko Hara Ballet, Masako Sakamura, and the Puffin Foundation. He has received grants from the Princess

Foundation, the National Endowment for the Arts, North Carolina Arts Council's Choreographer Fellowship (2012), Arts Greensboro and The Bossak Heilbron Foundation. He was selected as the 2009 University/College Educator of the Year by the North Carolina Alliance for Athletics, Health, Physical Education, Recreation, and Dance and is a 2012 Coleman Entrepreneurship Fellow. He is the co-author (with Joanne Savio) and editor of the book Vital Grace––The Black Male Dancer, a photographic essay on male dancers of color including interviews with Gregory Hines, Bill T. Jones and Evander Holyfield published by Edition Stemmle. Cyrus and co-author Savio also published their work as a poster and calendar from Pomegranate titled Dancing a Dream. Duane is currently an MBA candidate at the Bryan Business School at University of North Carolina.

The Impact

Historic Significance

Charles W. David Jr. is a WWII hero who is described as “Stewards-Mate First Class Charles Walter David, Jr., an African American Coast Guardsman who served on board CGC Comanche on North Atlantic convoy duty during World War II…On the night of 3 February 1943 the U.S. Army transport USS Dorchester was torpedoed by a German U-boat off the coast of Greenland.  When the Comanche came to the aid of the survivors of Dorchester in the frigid waters, David was one of the few Comanche crewmen who volunteered to dive overboard to help rescue those in need… David died a few days later from pneumonia contracted during his heroic efforts to save the stricken survivors of the Dorchester.  He was posthumously awarded the Navy and Marine Corps Medal for his bravery.” (http://www.uscg.mil/history/people/Charles_David.asp)

Charles David Jr. is the uncle of Duane Cyrus who has known of Charles W. David since childhood but only began exploring his history in depth in 2013 when a fast response Coast Guard Cutter was commissioned in his honor in Key West, FL. Cyrus attended the commissioning ceremony and has been motivated to use his expertise as an artist and scholar to honor the military contributions of his uncle. This project also has significance on a number of scholarly, creative, and academic levels. First, the work developed will use an interdisciplinary approach to the performing arts to shed light on contributions made by African Americans through military service. 

The outcomes in music, dance and film will serve our nation by highlighting important contribution made by servicemen that may have gone unnoticed. Audiences will also benefit from the exposure to arts programming and historical research while engaging creative artists.

Risks & Challenges

We have gathered attention and some support for this project. Most of the support is in terms of the talent available and the space to rehearse. We need funds to complete the film and pay performers for rehearsal. The other challenges are in finding more avenues of exposure for the work (performances, lectures, etc.,) and ensuring that the outcome is engaging and impactful. 

Other Ways You Can Help

You can also help by: 

  • Spreading the word
  • Invite us to perform or screen the completed film
  • Share your own important military story with us
  • Please be sure to share this link with your friends. Every little bit helps!

Charles David Jr. is the uncle of Duane
Cyrus who has known of Charles W. David since childhood but only began exploring his history in depth in 2013 when a fast
response Coast Guard Cutter was commissioned in his honor in Key West, FL.
Cyrus attended the commissioning ceremony and has been motivated to use his
expertise as an artist and scholar to honor the military contributions of his
uncle. This project also has significance on a number of scholarly, creative,
and academic levels. First, the work developed will use an interdisciplinary
approach to the performing arts to shed light on contributions made by African
Americans through military service. 
The outcomes in music, dance and film will
serve our nation by highlighting important contribution made by servicemen that
may have gone unnoticed. Audiences will also benefit from the exposure to arts
programming and historical research while engaging creative artists.   Risks & Challenges We have gathered attention and some support for this project. Most of the support is in terms of the talent available and the space to rehearse. We need funds to complete the film and pay performers for rehearsal. The other challenges are in finding more avenues of exposure for the work (performances, lectures, etc.,) and ensuring that the outcome is engaging and impactful. 
    Other Ways You Can Help You can also help by: 


Spreading the word

Invite us to perform or screen the completed film
Share your own important military story with us
Please be sure to share this link with your friends. Every little bit helps!

story:
TEAM

Written & Performed by: Ashley J Hicks

Directed by: Ted Hoerl 

Presented by: St. Lou Fringe Festival

Get your tickets here!

Short Summary

Beautiful Broken Pieces explores one woman's desire to live a much bigger life than the one genetically handed to her. Ash takes the audience along on her journey to acceptance of what makes her different. Through childhood memories, the portrayal of multiple people from her life, music and movement, Ash fully embraces all of the pieces that make her who she is... ...even the ones that are broken.

*Beautiful Broken Pieces was developed at the Chicago Dramatists with Arlene Malinowski.*

Allocation of Donations

5% of the funds raised will be donated to the National Organization for Albinism and Hypopigmentation (NOAH)

$400 pays the Director 

$350 pays for posters, postcards and programs for the show.

$450 pays for the videographer. 

$400 pays for travel & lodging  *I currently do not drive, so I'll be taking the AMTRAK into STL. So that I don't have to worry about getting back and fourth from the venue, I will be staying at a hotel or airb&b  walking distance from where my performance is to take place.*

$100 pays for the rental space for the preview performance in Chicago. *This invited dress preview  will take place one or two weeks before the St. Lou Fringe Festival.*

Can't donate? You can still help!

Spreading the word is just as good as making a donation. Share this campaign on social media, and with family and friends. Remember to keep it classy! Don't spam people with this campaign.

story:
Hey guys, my name is Giancarlo Rodaz, I’m a young director and playwright living in Miami. Theater is my passion and my living, and that's why I'm opening a brand new pop up professional theatre company in South Florida, Stringlight Theatre Co.

The Impact

I've been directing and performing in plays for seven years now, and the difference I've seen in the audience and the artists alike always amazes me. Good live theatre makes such a huge difference in the lives of a local community, especially now in a world where everything happens online.

A really important aspect for me is that all tickets will be $20. This is a big deal, considering that most professional theater houses in Miami cost $50, $60, even $100 for a single ticket. Taking friends or family out to see a show can cost hundreds of dollars. That's just for a single night of entertainment.

At Stringlight, anyone can see world class plays for little more than the cost of seeing a movie.

Risks & Challenges

Building a new theatre company from the ground up is a daunting task because theater has so many complex elements. Our traveling theater setup is going to be a handmade amalgation of different contraptions that need to work in perfect harmony. 

Venues are also difficult, as we won't be performing in traditional theater spaces. We're currently securing several storefronts, warehouse spaces, and a church for our upcoming season. As you can imagine, it's a complex and expensive process.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't make a donation, that's fine! You can still help. Spread the word to your friends and family by sharing our website online, and follow us on Instagram (@stringlightco) to keep up to date with all of our programs and news!


So thank you so much guys. I’m really passionate about this and I want nothing more than to bring something fresh to the South Florida theatre scene. If you’re as passionate about theater as I am, spread the word and share this page online so we can reach our goal. Peace!

story:
Mission

Starting in 2004, this annual Hip-Hop festival focuses on women and their relationship with Hip-Hop culture. Ladies of Hip-Hop Festival  (LOHHF) exists to develop and provide women with positive roles that are present and represented within the Hip-Hop culture. Traditionally, men have dominated all facets of the hip-hop scene, but Ladies of Hip-Hop Festival changes this tradition and puts women center-stage for the entire event

The festival is an event produced by women, for women. Each year an elite group of female artists from around the world are selected to exhibit work, teach, and perform as part of the festival. The artists have extensive experience and understanding of the Hip-Hop culture and are qualified to pass on the traditions of Hip-Hop culture with accuracy and authenticity. 


Global Community Building

In March of 2011, After 7 years in existence,  Ladies of Hip-Hop Festival went to Europe! In Partnership with Urban Arts & Culture of Austria, and the KosmosTheater, LOHHF debuted internationally in Vienna, Austria to three evenings of sold out shows, a jam packed panel discussion, and great workshops. It was a tremendous experience for the eight US instructors and performers, some traveling abroad for the first time ever. In the 10 days in Vienna LOHHF director, Michele Byrd-McPhee and dancers created a collaborative piece with Austrian artists. It was overwhelming success! 

Continuing to grow our community LOHHF  is now partnering with VersaStyle Dance Company in Los Angeles to present a LA LOHHF. 



What We Need & Why We Need It

We are asking for your support for the annual festival to continue the work we do.  We are asking you to "PUT $5 ON IT" (or more!) . Please make a pledge and share with your friends! Your donation will go to support the following: 

  • Artist Fees
  • Artist Meals, Travel & Lodging
  • Documentation Fees
We are well supported! In 12-years of producing LOHHF we have maintained (or dropped) our prices. We even offer free kids programs during the event. However,  the increasing cost of venues, travel and lodging fees have become prohibitive and in order to continue this program we are asking for your help. "PUT $5 ON IT"!  Put $5 on us...

Put $5 on our Girls & Women! 

We simply don't have enough girls and women  spinning on their heads. With every donation you are helping to guarantee LOHHF continues to provide space for girls and women to  produce, create and share their work. We also providing opportunity to explore their creativity as well creating independent & critical thinkers....and much more. Take a minute to read some quotes from:   

THE CENTER FOR GIRLS' LEADERSHIP

  • Art is an amazing way for girls explore their inner selves, develop creative thinking skills, and realize their potential. The process of creating art can be a stress reliever, joy inspirer, and a confidence booster." - Mary Lenertz 
  • "I have always viewed the arts (in any form) as a true and pure form of self-expression. Honest self-expression can be a difficult thing for women as we can often be criticized for being too sensitive, or too emotional. I believe young girls embracing and exploring the arts early on in life sets a foundation for unapologetic and creative self-expression of themselves that will translate into their everyday lives and serve them well, no matter what their future endeavors may be." - Rebekah Oltmans
  • "Art teaches girls that language and numbers cannot explain everything in our universe.  It allows them to be open to creative forms of expression and it introduces the idea that there is not always one single way to explain something.  Whether an education in art sparks a lifelong career or simply helps teach these and many other lessons, it is a vital component of a young girls education." - Katie Iacarella

Put $5 on Dance! 

We are building community  through art education and cultural experiences like the ‘LADIES BATTLE!', an annual dance battle featuring the world's best of the best female dance competitors. 

Dance is a powerful ally for developing many of the attributes of a growing child. Dance helps children mature physically, emotionally, socially, and cognitively. The physical benefits of dance are widely accepted, but the emotional, social and cognitive attributes have only recently begun to be appreciated. 

Put $5 on Art!

The value and positive impact of arts study on children and adolescents is often self-evident to artists, musicians, and arts educators. Yet, the arts community is frequently called upon to justify the expenses of arts education by providing evidence that engaging in arts eduction and arts experiences make a meaningful, positive difference in the lives of students. 

Students of music and dance were significantly less likely than non-arts students to be engaged in fewer delinquent behaviors during adolescence, while visual arts students are significantly more likely to be engaged in delinquent behaviors.(*data from the National Longitudinal Study of Adolescent Health; “Add Health”)

Exactly Where does the money go?

Break'in  it down for folks (pun intended): 

  • Artist Meals, Travel & Lodging: $3000
  • Artist Fees: $1500 
  • This won't cover our entire budget but the $4900+ helps substantially! 
The remaining balance of our $25,000 annual event budget is generated via ticket sales, merchandise sales... and the love and support of me, my friends & family. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about Ladies of Hip-Hop Festival. Ask them to "PUT $5 ON IT"!
  • Please use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • We are always looking for community partnerships as well. Please contact Michele Byrd-McPhee michele@ladiesofhiphopfestival.com.

And that's all there is to it."PUT $5 ON IT"!

story:
From its opening as a Sunday school picnic ground, to its golden age as one of the country’s most popular amusement park destinations, to its heartbreaking closing in 1996, Rocky Point Park has held a special place in RI’s history.  Now, in honor of the 20th anniversary of the amusement park’s closing, and in celebration of Rocky Point’s rebirth as a coastal state park, we are looking to celebrate the history, stories, and resilience of this gem by the sea by presenting a brand new musical revue.

Award-Winning, Original Youth Theatre

Since opening our doors in 1987, Rhode Island Youth Theatre (RIYT) has been making theatre magic by providing thousands of children and teens the opportunity to CREATE, PERFORM, and EXPERIENCE exceptional theatre.  Last year, RIYT took a huge leap forward presenting its first full length, student written musical, The Outcast of Sherwood Forest, which was developed by teens through our Young PlayRIYTs program, in collaboration with a host of Broadway and other professional collaborators.  The production was an audience favorite, even receiving the prestigious Moss Hart Award from the New England Theatre Conference.

The Spirit of Rocky Point

We ask for your support to produce another original show this summer!  Mitchell Cardone, the 17 year-old writer of last year’s award-winning show, has teamed up with RIYT alumnus Christopher Lysik to create a brand-new, 90-minute musical revue about RI’s most famous landmark of yesteryear, Rocky Point Park!  The show, developed through our Young PlayRIYTs program, includes such diverse hits as “Wind of Change,” “Space Oddity,” “Buffalo Gals,” and “By the Beautiful Sea,” and celebrates an amusement park loved by generations of Rhode Islanders.  

Your Turn!

To help with funding, we are looking to raise at least $3,500 to help pay for this premiere production. Rhode Island Youth Theater is a non-profit theater organization devoted to bringing theater to children at very low cost. Your tax-deductible donation will go to:

  • Venue rental
  • Performance rights

We need YOUR help in producing this show. Together, we can create a piece of theater worthy of the great Rocky Point Park!

How to Help!

Can’t contribute right now? Don’t worry, we understand. That being said, you can still help out!

  • Buy tickets! Purchase your seats ahead of time online at our website, http://www.riyt.org/, or get them the night of the show at the door.
  • Spread the word! Post on Facebook! Send out an email blast! Knock door to door! Anything to let the world know that we are coming at you with a night of great fun and nostalgia!
  • Like us on Facebook at https://www.facebook.com/RIYouthTheatre/ for tons of updates and photos!
  • Know someone age 9-18 who wants to sign up to be a part of this magical show? Click here for the registration form! 
  • Would you like to play a part in the writing of our show? We are looking for personal stories, family photos, and home videos taken at Rocky Point Park for use in our production. Send your memories to rockypointRIYT@gmail.com-- with your permission, it will be featured in the show!

The Spirit of Rocky Point will be presented by children and teens at 10 am and 7 pm, Friday, July 8th; and at 7 pm, Saturday, July 9th at the Scottish Rite Auditorium, 2115 Broad Street in Cranston, RI. 

See ya there!

story:
Short Summary

Like most adventures, that of "The Odd Couple" started with an encounter.

Actually, a very unlikely encounter as the protagonists had four different nationalities and lived in three different countries (France, Canada and Belgium).

However, their paths did cross during a master class organised by Frank Totino, and soon enough their wish to work together took over all the (somewhat justified) reasons why this project might be slightly complicated.

Frank's choice of playing "The Odd Couple" was met with unanimous approval, not only because Neil Simon was an extremely talented dialogue writer with great wit and repartee that hits the spot with each retort but also because the humour and rhythm of this play inspired most of the modern American TV series.

After a rock and roll kick off in Lyon, right after the terrorist attacks in Paris and theatre lovers preferring to stay at home. We're bringing this play to the Low Lands. First we take Amsterdam, than we take Antwerp!

The Play

So what happens when a cleaning freak, a depressive whose wife just left him and a freshly divorced poker fan who only thinks about having a good time find themselves in the same apartment? 

A comedy by Neil Simon. Directed by Frank Totino (Canada), The odd couple boasts an European cast, one Englishman (Keith Farquhar), two Dutch speaking Belgians (Jan Debski and Evelien Den Tandt) and six French actors (Yannick Farquhar, Maxime Plaisantin, Emanuel Courtieu, Victor Gelis, Seth Young Ruiz, Romain Bressy).


What We Need & What You Get

What will the donations be used for?

This ambitious international project, Lyon (théâtre acte 2, November 20-21 2015) is only the start of the adventure. We will also perform the play in Amsterdam (March 14-15-16 2016 at the Polantheater) and in Antwerp (March 24-25-26 2016 at the Fakkelteater).

With your contribution, you will help support a company who doesn't benefit from any public or sponsor-based subventions.

Hence the self-production of the Lyons shows and the tour for The Odd Couple, which means that the risk taking only rests on our frail shoulders.

Technically, this is why we're asking for your help:

Rental for the Polanentheater  1348€ 

Rental Fakkelteater: 1539€

Rental van (to bring the scenery and actors from Lyon to Amsterdam): 1147€

Hence a total cost of: 4034€

By supporting us you are also supporting the company Moment to Moment, and more generally live shows and the spirit of creation.


The Impact

As a theatre company we believe that cultural differences enrich life, that no terrorist attack should make people small and frightened and that theatre and humor makes our lives more beautiful. That's why we want to bring this incredibly funny play to you


Other Ways You Can Help

Just come and watch this play and have a good night!

Amsterdam: Polanentheater: March 14, 15, 16

Antwerp: Fakkelteater-Zwarte Zaal: March 24, 25, 26


Cast & Director

story:
SYMPATHY IN C, a Play With Music is BROADWAY BOUND!

  • WHEN:     Fri. Aug. 11, 12:30 PM, Sun. Aug. 13, 6:30 PM, Wed. Aug.16, 7:30 PM
  • WHERE:  The Theater at the 14th Street Y, 344 East 14th Street, NYC NY

Will you help us take it all the way?

 

GREETINGS

... and thank you for your interest in Sympathy in C, a new theatrical experience with music, written and produced by Suzanne Mernyk with Direction by Terry Hanson.  We strive to create a professional theater experience that will touch the audience’s heart and celebrate the human spirit... and put it on its path toward a true Broadway production. 

 

THE INSPIRATION

Touched by cancer and its devastating impact on many personal fronts & heartsick by the encroaching threat of terrorism, Suzanne was inspired to write about the shock of experiencing the unimaginable with appreciation for all those who are called to heal and serve in the aftermath.

There’s no theatrical production like this in form.  The play delicately creates intertwining harmonies between the spoken stories of six struggling characters with the musical callings of a violist and cellist - the voices of love and continuity of life, flowing just beneath the madness.

 

YOUR SUPPORT ...

... in any way, makes a huge difference!  Arts funding is limited and it takes time, resources, and dedication to bring new theatrical works to the stage.

As a proud finalist in the new, prestigious Broadway Bound Theatre Festival, your support will provide necessary funds to present the play with full professional potential, perhaps engaging the attention of a Producer or Artistic Director who carry it forward on its commercial journey.

All funds will go directly toward covering the theater artists, designers and staging elements that are sure to move Sympathy in C on its Broadway Bound journey

 

THE GOAL

Our funding  goal of $6,400 will go toward paying for experienced and talented theater professionals -  the director, actors, musicians, lighting & sound designers - all of whom have the talent and vision to make this a truly powerful, Broadway quality, theater experience.

It's easy to participate with a contribution that works for your budget:

  • The Eighth Note              $12
  • The Quarter Note             $25
  • The Half Note                  $50
  • The Golden G-Clef         $100
  • The High Five                  $500

 

IMPACT

  • Sympathy in C is a show needed in today's world, as it taps into the personal and political conflicts around fear and love, asking the questions we all need to address.
  • Experienced and professional theater artists and musicians will make your dollars work hard to create a memorable audience experience.
  • Touch hearts and expand minds with your investment. Please contribute today!
 

OTHER WAYS TO HELP

Perhaps you just can't contribute, but there are other ways to help:

  • Get the word out and help make some noise about Sympathy in C and our campaign. It's easy to share using the Indiegogo tools!
  • Do you know industry professionals -- Artistic Directors, Theater Companies, Literary Managers or Agents -- who are looking for new, important plays?  Please invite them to attend or put us in touch at SympathyinC2017@gmail.com
story_txt:

WHEN:     Fri. Aug. 11, 12:30 PM, Sun. Aug. 13, 6:30 PM, Wed. Aug.16, 7:30 PM

WHERE:  The Theater at the 14th Street Y, 344 East 14th Street, NYC NY

Will you help us take it all the way?
 
GREETINGS
... and thank you for your interest in Sympathy in C, a new theatrical experience with music, written and produced by Suzanne Mernyk with Direction by Terry Hanson.  We strive to create a professional theater experience that will touch the audience’s heart and celebrate the human spirit... and put it on its path toward a true Broadway production.

story:
Greetings!  My name is Howard Miller, a businessman and lifelong resident of the Erie County area.  Our story begins nearly five years ago when our lovely daughter Evelyn was diagnosed with eye cancer.  It was a very difficult time in our lives, but one of the positive results was a dream to write a stage drama based on our struggles.  Our church used to produce wonderful musical dramas years ago.  I recognized a need in the Erie County Area for high-quality, reasonably priced, family-friendly theater productions.  And so, Erie Lighthouse Theater was born. 

We want to create programs and shows that have a great message that you can bring your family to and be proud of.  Please partner with us.  We want to involve the community.  Be part of something bigger than any one of us.  Let's make a positive impact in our city and community.  Get the word out, share this with your friends!

story:
Feeling blue, out of blue... "Wo looks outside dreams, who looks inside awakes" CG Jung

"It is essential to let ourselves dream and to understand our deepest dreams, as we all carry the bottomless potential to create our own reality by dreaming... Let's dream and wake up together"

The Impact

By helping us create this theatrical piece you will contribute to the beauty of innovative and feminine driven creation. We create a safe space in which we dive into the unknown and still know exactly what we want to achieve: Bring MAGIC back into the world.

The show will invite men and women to experience our visions and stories, and get a sense of the feminine way of dreaming. Is there a feminine way of dreaming? We will find out.

The theatre is a sacred space in which all miracles can happen, the miracles we are all looking for in our realities often happen in our dreams. BLAUHAUCH will be a piece in which we welcome YOU and all those who join us to experience it, to completely relax and fly back to an inner state of childlike fantasy in which anything can happen really. Because dream was there before the thought. So let's dream first and think after. Or stop thinking for a while.

Short Summary

BLAUHAUCH // Le Songe Bleu is an innovative theatre piece based on the dramaturgy of the dream. We will explore the night dream, the day dream and the lucid dream, aiming to open new doors for the theatre to dive into other realms with us.

We dream the play into being. We are working as a multidisciplinary group of female actresses, storytellers, dancers, filmmakers and circus performers. Based in Berlin and in different places in France, we aim to meet in both countries to dream and create a powerful international connection.

During the residency in November 2017 we will write the dream script for the show BLAUHAUCH that we will perform on different theatres in Europe, starting with the stages in Berlin, and also perform in female prisons, psychiatric hospitals and houses of prostitution. As we are a group of thirteen women, we aim to explore the themes of feminine sexuality in dreams, and really get a sense of the common symbols that keep on recurring in all our dreams. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

We will need a total of 20.000 Euros for us to be able to all travel to an unusual place (maybe a castle or a church or a Yurt in France, a farm in Spain or a church in Romania) and develop the script together.

We will need the money for travel costs, food, accommodation and dream specialists (Hypnosis Masters, Dream Therapists) to assist us in the process of creating BLAUHAUCH. We want to be able to leave Berlin and connect to new energies in order to have a clear mind and let the dreams visit us freely. During this time we will create another video and a short documentary about our dream circles and intuitive writing that we would love to share with you.

In exchange for the Lucid Dreamer contributions, we will set three dates during autumn in which we will organise workshops (Acting, Writing, Dreaming, Dancing). Other contribution perks for the Day-Dreamers and Night-Dreamers are recorded audio books in which we will tell some of the chosen dreams and record a guided dream meditation together.

 

Challenges

BLAUHAUCH has not been done yet, and we trust in the process, as we are all coming from very different backgrounds, and we bring different qualities.

Some of us will take care of the movement choreographies, others of the written words, others of the acting part. As a team of very different and yet so similar women, we are going to share the tasks and gather our very unique gifts to overcome obstacles during the process.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please let us know about unusual spaces, residencies, or rehearsal rooms in which we could dream, and as we speak 7 languages in the group, we are always very happy to co-produce with other countries.

We are also thankful for every piece of blue material, fabric, paint etc... that you might not need anymore, to start creating the visuals of the piece.

If you are a lighting designer, and you feel called to join our journey, please contact us! We are looking for a blue hypnotic light design that helps the piece to dive deep into dream state.

Also if you have contacts to the theatres in your city, country, wherever you might be, please help us connect to the spaces and promote this wonderful project.

We are also very happy about you sharing your dreams with us. (Please send us your dreams by email!)

THANK YOU VERY MUCH IN ADVANCE

Love

The Blauhauch Women

story:
***UPDATE!! 11/29/17***

Thanks to people making their own fundraisers for us on Facebook for Giving Tuesday, we have met and exceeded our fundraising goal! As of now, any money donated to this Indiegogo campaign will go solely toward artists' stipends. Thank you all so much!

 

1776 photos by Syrinda Sharpe / Fly By Night and Private Lives photos by Jeff Carpenter

Who We Are

I founded Reboot Theatre Company because as a nonbinary character actor, I found that many of the roles that excited me were off-limits because of how I am traditionally perceived to society, especially in theatre where "type casting" is the name of the game. I wanted to offer a chance for artists of all backgrounds and orientations to stretch their wings and try something new. As a company, we want to challenge audiences on their preconceived notions of what a particular character should look like. There is no "default" gender or color at Reboot Theatre Company.

- Jasmine Joshua, Artistic Director

 

Our Goal

After three incredible productions, including the nation's first all female production of 1776, a gender bending production of the musical Fly By Night, and a genderqueer cast of Noel Coward's brilliant Private Lives, we are looking to produce a fourth show in the spring of 2018. In order to do this, we would like to raise some extra money so that we can. . .

  • Afford higher production values
  • Have the ability to pay our artists larger stipends
  • Choose a show with a bigger cast in order to open up more roles to artists that represent the diversity we see in our community.

What We've Done So Far!

We want an overall production budget of $10,000 for our spring show. We are looking to raise $5,500 in order to reach that budget and have been fundraising since late summer to get there! As you can see, we're so close, but we need a little more to hit that magic number.

August

We held a garage sale in the Maple Leaf neighborhood. It was a huge success! Our community rallied to help donate items to sell and also come out and support us by buying up our treasures! We raised over $1,000 and it was a great kick start to our fundraising.

September

We opened Reboot U, an educational series of classes aimed at helping artists brush up on their skills or to try something entirely new! We offered four classes that included monologue work, song selection, a musical theatre dance class, and culminating in a special audition panel where local working directors and music directors volunteered their time to critique students' audition work. It was tremendously successful outreach into our community and got a lot of positive feedback. We'll definitely be doing this again!

October

We hosted a sold-out Halloween party fundraiser! Guests bought tickets and danced the night away while sampling from our unlimited open bar and delicious snack table. We also had a costume contest and a drawing for prizes, which included donated gift certificates to local theatres, movies, and restaurants.

November

Admittedly, we're taking a bit of a break in order to prepare for our Big Kahuna event in December, but we are encouraging our fans to purchase anything on Amazon through Amazon Smile and use Reboot Theatre Company as their charity, especially on Black Friday and Cyber Monday.

 

THE TELETHON!

The event you've been waiting for! We are hosting a 12 hour telethon that we will be broadcasting LIVE online 10am-10pm Tuesday, December 12th! (Yes, seriously!)  Programming will include astrology readings, soap opera serials, ineptly done Pinterest crafts, kamikaze karaoke, drinking games, painting landscapes a la a certain dulcet toned painter with a fro, and so much more. The telethon will culminate in a variety show chock full of talented Seattle performers including sketch comedy groups Maple Daddies and Villains, burlesque artists Kia Puckett, Anya Knees, and Smokey Brown, genderqueer drag artist Harvey Gent, special performances by Reboot alum Jesse Calixto and Kit Lascher, and the list keeps growing!

To buy tickets to our variety show to witness the magic in person, tickets ($10) are on sale here!

More Ways to Help!

  • Spread the word about Reboot! Follow us on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram! Share this fundraising campaign to your friends!
  • Use Amazon Smile when you shop on Amazon and choose Reboot Theatre Company as your charity!
  • Come see our shows! Sign up for our newsletter and find out what we're doing next!

 

We are a 501(c)(3) non- profit, so all donations are tax-deductible!

Spread the word about Reboot! Follow us on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram! Share this fundraising campaign to your friends!

Come see our shows! Sign up for our newsletter and find out what we're doing next!

story:
CCYT Cabaret opens August 4, 2017

About Curtain Call Youth Theatre

CCYT is an award-winning teen theatre group based in Agoura Hills, CA. We've dedicated over a decade to theatre arts education. CCYT strives to foster well-rounded performers well-versed in theatre etiquette, discipline, teamwork, and camaraderie in addition to the acting, singing and dancing aspects of live theatrical performance. We are challenging our students with chair choreography and for that, we need chairs!

What We Need & What You Get

Please donate to our fundraiser to support current and future Curtain Call Youth Theatre productions!

In return, you will receive a signed caricature of your favorite CABARET character illustrated by the talented West Maatita (@sadienjacksdad), complimentary tickets to our show, and a photo-op with the cast member of your choice!

We have a flex goal of $1000, all proceeds from the fundraiser will go into the Cabaret production fund and Curtain Call Youth Theatre's general operations fund.

About the Show

CCYT’s production of the Tony Award-winning musical, based on Christopher Isherwood’s Berlin Stories with music by John Kander, lyrics by Fred Ebb and book by Joe Masteroff, is directed by Jeff Wallach. The show takes audiences to 1929 Berlin, Germany, and tells a fun, rigorous story about human nature during political turmoil.

The show itself features the weaving narratives of a cabaret singer, a writer from America, and the inhabitants of Berlin, led by the enigmatic and dazzling Kit Kat Klub Emcee. CCYT’s production brings immersive theatre to the Agoura Hills arts community by transforming Playhouse 101’s black box theatre into the seedy nightclub where the musical is set. The show will be presented in-the-round and feature tables where audience members get a one-of-a-kind experience of memorable songs such as “Cabaret,” “Don’t Tell Mama” and “Maybe This Time” as part of the nightclub’s crowd.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to contribute at this time, we ask that you share this campaign with your social networks and invite you to see the show in August!

For more info please visit http://curtaincallyouththeatre.com

story:
Our Story

The Eleventh Hour!  was first developed as a fifteen minute musical as part of coLAB Arts' first annual 48 Hour Musicals in 2015 in New Brunswick, NJ. TEH!  struck a chord with audiences for its humor, musical hooks, and familiar (yet strange!) cast of characters. coLAB Arts' commissioned the creative team to take the original story and turn it into a full length musical which was workshopped and performed in June and December of 2016. In January 2018, TEH! will be making it's NYC debut as part of NY Winterfest, where we will be presenting three performances at the Hudson Guild Theatre before moving into an open-ended New York run!

The Eleventh Hour! celebrates the punks and misfits of the New Brunswick, NJ basement music scene. It will be the first time the city is featured on stage, excluding its brief mention in the musical, 1776 (I can't quote it here, trying to keep this page PG!).

Your contribution means everything here. We've been working on this for years, patiently honing every lyric and musical bar, and now we're ready to share it with you and the world!

WHAT IT GETS US

We're looking to raise $10,000 to help us cover all of our expenses for our first NYC production! And to thank you, we'll be sending you cool merch, cast recordings, and original artwork inspired by the production ... maybe even a private performance???!!!

A donation between $1 and $15 dollars will help us buy all of the props that we need for The Eleventh Hour! Our intent is to use mostly recycled objects and props for the production (it is the Apocalypse after all!) but we anticipate needing at least 10 strings of Christmas lights in order to light the space. We are also in need of several chairs and other set dressing. Every single dollar helps!

$20 will cover the cost of renting our rehearsal space for one Saturday rehearsal. We rehearse every single week to bring this show to the stage for you, and we need a place to do it!  

$25 covers the cost of one ticket. Your contribution allows us to bring industry professionals and producers in to see the show and potentially invest in its future!

$50 buckaroonis will cover the cost of renting one mic pack for the show to make sure that everyone in the audience can hear our actors over the sounds of the #RockApocalypse. In total, we will be renting 8 mic packs.

One Benjamin Franklin will cover one of our musician’s travel for the entire rehearsal process!  We currently have three musicians working on The Eleventh Hour! in order to bring our writer and composer Dave Seamon’s vision to life. Making sure they’re at rehearsal gives the actors a true sense of what their performance will be like and lets them feel out how they can best deliver the story to our adoring fans.

A donation of $250 will cover our rehearsal supply expenses for the production! We rehearse every single week in order to bring The Eleventh Hour to life.

$500 -  Winterfest does not advertise for the shows that perform in the festival, so it’s up to us to spread the word about how awesome our show is--and we can’t do that without your help! $500 will cover our entire marketing and advertising costs for this run and allow us to bring this show to people from all over the Tri-State Area.

$1,000 - If we are able to reach our fundraising goals, ONE THOOOOOOUSAND DOLLARS will cover the cost of getting you, our supporters and fans, a CAST RECORDING of The Eleventh Hour! The cast recording will feature all of the songs you know and love

$2,000 - Covers all of the transportation costs for our New Jersey cast, musicians, and creative team!

$50,000 GETS US OFF THIS ROCK! Just kidding, but it WILL cover the ENTIRE cost of this production, plus enough for us to extend our run and bring the Rock Apocalypse to the rest of NYC!

Other Ways You Can Help

We totally understand that not everyone can give. But there are ways to help! Sharing information with others about this fundraiser and the production is just as important. Please like and follow us on Facebook (@eleventhhourmusical), Twitter (@11thhourmusical), and Instagram (@rockapocalypse).
story_txt:
Our Story
The Eleventh Hour!  was first developed as a fifteen minute musical as part of coLAB Arts' first annual 48 Hour Musicals in 2015 in New Brunswick, NJ. TEH!  struck a chord with audiences for its humor, musical hooks, and familiar (yet strange!) cast of characters. coLAB Arts' commissioned the creative team to take the original story and turn it into a full length musical which was workshopped and performed in June and December of 2016. In January 2018, TEH! will be making it's NYC debut as part of NY Winterfest, where we will be presenting three performances at the Hudson Guild Theatre before moving into an open-ended New York run!
The Eleventh Hour! celebrates the punks and misfits of the New Brunswick, NJ basement music scene. It will be the first time the city is featured on stage, excluding its brief mention in the musical, 1776 (I can't quote it here, trying to keep this page PG!).
Your contribution means everything here. We've been working on this for years, patiently honing every lyric and musical bar, and now we're ready to share it with you and the world!
WHAT IT GETS US
We're looking to raise $10,000 to help us cover all of our expenses for our first NYC production! And to thank you, we'll be sending you cool merch, cast recordings, and original artwork inspired by the production ... maybe even a private performance???!!!
A donation between $1 and $15 dollars will help us buy all of the props that we need for The Eleventh Hour! Our intent is to use mostly recycled objects and props for the production (it is the Apocalypse after all!) but we anticipate needing at least 10 strings of Christmas lights in order to light the space. We are also in need of several chairs and other set dressing. Every single dollar helps!
$20 will cover the cost of renting our rehearsal space for one Saturday rehearsal. We rehearse every single week to bring this show to the stage for you, and we need a place to do it!  
$25 covers the cost of one ticket. Your contribution allows us to bring industry professionals and producers in to see the show and potentially invest in its future!
$50 buckaroonis will cover the cost of renting one mic pack for the show to make sure that everyone in the audience can hear our actors over the sounds of the #RockApocalypse. In total, we will be renting 8 mic packs.
One Benjamin Franklin will cover one of our musician’s travel for the entire rehearsal process!  We currently have three musicians working on The Eleventh Hour! in order to bring our writer and composer Dave Seamon’s vision to life. Making sure they’re at rehearsal gives the actors a true sense of what their performance will be like and lets them feel out how they can best deliver the story to our adoring fans.
A donation of $250 will cover our rehearsal supply expenses for the production! We rehearse every single week in order to bring The Eleventh Hour to life.
$500 -  Winterfest does not advertise for the shows that perform in the festival, so it’s up to us to spread the word about how awesome our show is--and we can’t do that without your help! $500 will cover our entire marketing and advertising costs for this run and allow us to bring this show to people from all over the Tri-State Area.
$1,000 - If we are able to reach our fundraising goals, ONE THOOOOOOUSAND DOLLARS will cover the cost of getting you, our supporters and fans, a CAST RECORDING of The Eleventh Hour! The cast recording will feature all of the songs you know and love
$2,000 - Covers all of the transportation costs for our New Jersey cast, musicians, and creative team!
$50,000 GETS US OFF THIS ROCK! Just kidding, but it WILL cover the ENTIRE cost of this production, plus enough for us to extend our run and bring the Rock Apocalypse to the rest of NYC!

Other Ways You Can Help
We totally understand that not everyone can give. But there are ways to help! Sharing information with others about this fundraiser and the production is just as important. Please like and follow us on Facebook (@eleventhhourmusical), Twitter (@11thhourmusical), and Instagram (@rockapocalypse).

story:
Short Summary

Director, Choreographer Krista Leigh Pasini believes we are all dancers, performing a contemplative choreography for each other each day – through movement, pattern, and gesture. “These often unconscious patterns reveal a subtext built within our cellular memory. Memories held in the body. All this feeds into a physical language that reveal more about ourselves than often our words might. It’s as though we each have an unspoken language lending to a richer subtext of our psyche. Within these patterns, our subconscious unfolds a tenuous dance of our deepest thoughts and family stories. And. If we listen we will hear it, if we observe – we will witness it. The stories of each life held within our bodies; stories held closely within each person as we shapeshift through the day, performing happiness for one another. By listening, observing, and honoring the rich subtext of our body’s narrative we can learn so much from one another; we can find empathy, love, and reflection.” ~ Krista Pasini

All Together Now first premiered as a one act submission for Sacrifice Cliff Theatre’s New Works Festival in 2015. Pasini collaborated with sound artist Matt Taggart on the drifting gaps in Montana families as sons and daughters pick up new occupations and leave the farms, ranches, and towns they were raised in. Without dialog the piece depicts a family at dinner communicating through action and gesture. A secondary narrative evolved, how a family bonds and fractures within grief. Taking the original work and expanding upon the family dynamics, All Together Now premiered as a 90 minute one act in April 2016, as part of Sacrifice Cliff Theatre’s season. It received overwhelming praise and an additional weekend was added. Through the development process, Pasini worked collaboratively with the cast to create unique and nuanced characters in the throes of some of their darkest hours.

“I still can’t quite articulate the level to which I was touched. An incredibly thoughtful, complicated, and realistic depiction of what [does and doesn’t] happen inside a family in the aftermath of tragedy. A whole lotta scar tissue was loosened for many, I’m sure.” ~ Cass Sullivan | Audience member

The Big 'Ask' 

Our full budget is $8000.00. This covers the full project and we'd like to make that goal through crowdfunding, individual donors, and organizational sponsors. 

Artist Fee: A lot of miles separate the communities of Montana and prepping a project of this size and travelling to Helena Montana (4 hours) away requires a lot of support. It's important that the cast and crew are compensated for their time and their craft. They'll be dedicating large spans of time to rehearsals in their home community and another week rehearsing and performing in Helena. 

Theater Rental + Technical Staff: Carroll College's new FLEX Black Box is a top of the line theater space we'll be living in for nearly a week. This time will include cross training with faculty as well technical rehearsals with the cast and crew

Promotion: We are fortunate to have support from community artists to help us get the word out about this important project. Furnace Filmworks will produce a film trailer and Font & Figure provided poster and print material. Artists often barter, but it's important to support those that can lend their artistry to help this project grow. In return they deserve monetary compensation so they too can grow.

Rehearsal Space: It's important that rehearsals take place in the same location the project was first performed in and we'd like to secure a considerable amount of time in May to be in the space and work through the show methodically. The owners of 2905 were and are supportive of this project and we want to recognize their efforts to create a performance space that made a home for All Together Now. 

Fiscal Sponsor: All contributions towards this project will go through Montana Arts, a 501c-3. Having the support and services of Montana Arts will allow sponsors and donors assurance that their investment in this project is tax deductible and has credible oversight from a state wide organization. A small fee applies to this service and we're grateful to have the Montana Arts' support.

Stretching the Definition of Community

Why Helena? A Montana artist based out of Billings Montana, Krista Leigh Pasini’s early inspiration came from training and performing under Sallyann Mulcahy, a former artist in residence at Carroll College. Mulcahy blended performative storytelling in ways that captivated Pasini. Re-connecting with Carroll College and Helena, a community that helped shape Pasini’s craft as a performative artist, is a ‘homecoming’ of sorts.

Montana is separated by vast interstates and highways, in any direction, communities are distanced by an hour or more drive. Why not foster collaboration through performative exchange? Independent artists benefit from multidisciplinary engagement, collaborative opportunities, and a wider net of peer support. Creating a richer embedment among artists in this unique part of the Northwest.

The Risk of Trying

Bringing an original and important project like All Together Now to another community requires trust in the work, but it also requires diligence. The risk of raising the needed funds places constraints on how independent artists produce and share new work in and around the state.  The risks are many, but so are the risks of not trying.

Other Ways You Can Help

Support isn't always financial and in many instances having someone share our work and our story is just as vital. We encourage you to like, share, and comment on this campaign and project as it progresses. The cast and crew will greatly appreciate any kind words and support you can share. 

We also would like to document this project, film & photography. If you, or someone you know, is able to carve out some time we'd love to hear from you.

story:
Sea-change Theatre Company formed in 2016 to take an all-female production of Shakespeare's The Tempest to the International Women's Festival at Skala Eressos International Women's Festival on Skala Eressos on Lesbos in Greece.  In June 2017 the show will be performed at The Rose Playhouse on Bankside, and in July at L-Fest in Loughborough. 

A  teasing gender-bending feast for the senses from the all-female cast, promising a night of sea-shanties, calypso and decadent gaiety.  A celebration of the spirit of romance and reconciliation, Sea-change theatre bring their boldly comic adaption of Shakespeare’s most musical play to the haunting setting of the Rose Playhouse.

We are thankful for all the generous support we have received so far from Queen Mary's College London, Riverside Studios,  Grow in Hackney, and Arena Ariel. 

We still need your help to make it happen.

All donations will go towards: 

  • Hire of lights and technical equipment. 
  • Technical team to work the technical equipment. 
  • Rehearsal space. 
  • Costumes for new company members.
  • Advertising and printing of publicity material. 
  • Expenses for the cast and crew. 

Your contribution will make an enormous difference to the production and the company itself. Sea-change Theatre believe it is important to make art accessible to everyone, Sea-change Theatre is inclusive of disability, age, nationality and sexuality. With your assistance will help us:

  • Promote a vibrant, feminist and LGBTQ theatre. 
  • Give female actors the opportunity to play Shakespeare's strongest characters. 
  • Allow professionally trained artists to live, work and create theatre. 

 

Please help us get the word out and share this campaign.

story:
Who We Are & What We Do

  • Peter Zachari and Joey Mirabile have been producing independent theater in New York City since 2011 starting with their production of Parker & Dizzy's Fabulous Journey to the End of the Rainbow at the New York International Fringe Festival. The show was selected as part of the Encore Series and remounted at The Players Theater. The show returned yet again at Theater for the New City in 2014. 
  • We have found the most wonderful artistic home at Theater for the New City. In the past five years we have presented a bevy of original shows: Fat Asses: The Musical, Under the Knife: A Farce, One Love, a freshly reimagined production of Parker & Dizzy's Fabulous Journey to the End of the Rainbow and the premiere of Anne Marilyn Lucas' From Silence.

  • Peter Zachari and his writing partner Damon Maida wrote Fat Asses: The Musical. We had a two week run in 2011 and played to sold out audience. The show was a hit. We have the opportunity to bring this show with a refreshed score back in 2018 at Theater for the New City. But we need help to make this happen. 

How You Can Make a Difference

We got into New York Musical Festival...and didn't have the funds to participate.

We got into New York Fringe Festival...and didn't have the funds to participate.

The world wants this show. And we want to make it happen! And we will if you help us. We need to raise $25,000. That funding goes for:

  • Payment for Equity actors, director, musical director, musicians stage managers, set designer, costume designer, lighting designer and sound engineers 
  • Sets, props, costumes, projections, video equipment
  • Publicity and Marketing, printed materials, mailings, ads, email blasts

The Impact

  • The world needs this show. It's time that all shapes and sizes are fairly represented in the world and this show blasts that message. But it's not just about bigger people. It's about ALL shapes and sizes. You will be contributing to an original piece that send a positive message to the world. And it's fun. It's funny. And it's poignant. I think you would be proud to say you were a part of this production team.
  • Because of people like you we HAVE been producing original works. Six original Peter Zachari plays and musicals have been produced in New York City from the generosity of friends, family and participants of crowdfunding efforts.
  • Not only does the audiences of New York City get to see the show but tens of New York artists, actors, designers and staff get to participate in this work of passion and contribute to the landscape of the New York City theater scene.

Let's Do This!

We can't let another opportunity like this slip by. It's important that we present shows that challenge the status quo and represent those voices who aren't being heard. Without your help, we could be at risk of not presenting this show next year. And that would be a shame!

Take a listen:

Here is the song, "Loving You Is A Dying Art" from the FAT ASSES: THE MUSICAL, sung by Kelly Teal Goyette from the original run. When Margaux discovers her husband has cut her off without a cent she discovers she still has mixed feeling for him. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Please help us spread the word about our show. Tell everyone about the Fat Asses!
  • Join our Facebook group: www.facebook.com/fatassesthemusical
  • Join us on Twitter: www.twitter.com/fatassesmusical

So what are you waiting for? Join us!

story:
Hey everybody! Here’s a little story for you!

One summer day in Juneau, Alaska, high school seniors, Aaron Badilla, James Raymond Rosales, Phil Derbesy, Franz Felkl, many of their friends, and Christopher the Cat, got together in Aaron’s small bedroom studio and recorded the song “I Am The Fling”. 

They couldn’t have known it at the time, but they had just recorded the first of many songs that would be written and recorded that summer. The songs never made it into the Top 40, or really even made it out of Juneau, but, for the people who wrote them, they became treasured musical memories and formed the basis of close, enduring friendships.

Ten years later, motivated by the lasting impact of the music, the relationships, and life in Alaska, Aaron Badilla would sit down and write The Fling LP, a musical play centered around the songs that were written during that pivotal summer and the love, loss, and grumpy old cat that inspired them.

After bringing on co-writer Molly Shimko and submitting the play to a couple of theaters and festivals, The Fling LP was chosen to be part of the New York Theater Festival Summerfest 2019! 

This campaign will help us bring to life this story of friendship, flings, and the power of music!

For more information and to listen to some of the original demos check out our website at www.theflingmusical.com!

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise $7,500!

All the money raised here goes straight to making every part of The Fling LP happen! 

Parts of the production that the campaign will be funding:

Cast: It’s going to take a team to bring this production together! A portion of our funding will go to paying our talented actor-musicians; we believe very strongly in supporting our artists and paying them for their hard work! 

Crew: The same goes for our designers and ops! They are going to play an integral role in making the music come to life and bringing the Northern Lights to mid-town Manhattan! And, of course, nothing comes together without a brilliant stage management team! 

Nitty Gritties: There is a lot that goes into producing a show and our funds will also go towards just such necessities as renting rehearsal space, marketing materials, programs, sound/lighting equipment, and more! 

Christopher Puppet: The band is not complete without its resident cat and part of this dough will be going towards creating a fantastic puppet that does the leading cat himself justice! 

And we’ve got perks! We’ve got all the Fling related goodies that your heart could desire at our very own digital “merch table in the back”! Every donation gets you some sweet Fling gifts, special Christopher inspired swag, and ways to show our everlasting gratitude! 

Other Ways You Can Help

Thank you for stopping by our page! Be sure to check out our website at www.theflingmusical.com & our IG: @theflingmusical and stay tuned for updates!

Our best form of advertising is word-of-mouth so if you dig what you see here, help us spread the word and share our campaign or website on your digital platforms!  

Shoutout: Junnie Chup for taking those Christopher band pictures all those years ago!

story:
We as independent theatre-makers want to diminish the fear and preconceived idea of the classical text being non-accessible language because of its heightened nature here in Turkey. We want to bring something new to the table that is authentic, ethnic, and has tremendous traditional value. A minimal representation of this magnificent living memory will not just become relatable because of its cultural context but will hit home. 

We are mostly casting students that are graduating or still in conservatory training. It was astonishing to see that Open Calls in Turkey are not a thing. And most people, even older actors, who auditioned never even experienced an audition before. Without being famous, we want to create an opportunity for young theatre artists to be involved in a fully rounded professional production. 

You cannot be involved in an independent theatre production in Turkey unless you have a great network and this to me is extremely ridiculous. I am realizing what a big step it is for us and for the artists who auditioned to be involved in full production with people they never met before. On top of that being involved in a theatre production just by auditioning and not by ear. 

By the end of June 2019 auditions, casting will be finalized, and the rehearsal process will begin.

To direct and dive into this text has been a huge dream of mine I am beyond thrilled for this journey we are about to begin. 

 

Cast

Antigone // Sonya Dicle Çetin

Ismene // Gözde Türker

Kreon // Veysel Sis

The Guard // Dila Yağcı

Haimon // Mertcan Semey

Messenger // Diyar Karadaş 

Teiresias // Ezgi Koçer

Chorus // Ezgi Koçer, Gözde Yıldırım, Gökçe Uygun, Tara Melissa McMillan, and Asena Yıldırım

Production Team

Director and Translator // Cemre Su Salur

Stage Manager // Şevval Arslan

Costume Designer // Buğu Pala

 

The breakdown of 10.000$

Monthly Total Payment for Each of 12 Actors Rehearsal Process: 3080$ (18000 TL)

Set Design: 1370$ (8000 TL)

The license of the Play: 1500$ (8700 TL)

Costume: 890$ (5200 TL)

Rent of Large Scale Rehearsal Space for 1 Month: 515$ (3000 TL)

Rent of Preview Venue: 855$ (5000 TL)

Promotion: 430$ (2500 TL) 

Production Team Rehearsal: 340$ (2000 TL) 

Light and Sound Designer: 515$ (3000 TL)

Emergency: 600$ (3500 TL)

As young theatre-makers and lovers, we ask your helping hand to simply create, make art, and be able to showcase it and share it. 

 

Director's and Translator's Biography //

Cemre Su Salur grew up in Istanbul. She’s an actor, dancer, choreographer and a director.

At the age 13,  she auditioned for her first musical Moulin Rouge. Since then she has been in school productions of The Miser, Across the Universe and was the choreographer for the production, Lüküs Hayat (Lead), Fame and also was the choreographer for the production. In her senior year of high school, she directed and choreographed Chicago played Velma Kelly (Lead), the same year she was in Oh, oh Juliette!  and assistant directed the play.

She got awarded the Performing Arts Special Award at her high school graduation diploma ceremony. This was the first time in Hisar School’s history that ever was given such an award. 

She received her Acting BFA from California Institute of the Arts in 2017. Right after school, she debuted her first ever European tour with an original play called Fore! as the lead character Anna. The play was written by Aleshea Harris and directed by Arnaud Meunier.  

She recently performed her performance art piece Foam at Mamut Art 2019 and choreographed Culter's production of Kafka's Investigations of a Dog. 

https://www.cemresusalur.com/
story_txt: We as independent theatre-makers want to diminish the fear and preconceived idea of the classical text being non-accessible language because of its heightened nature here in Turkey. We want to bring something new to the table that is authentic, ethnic, and has tremendous traditional value. A minimal representation of this magnificent living memory will not just become relatable because of its cultural context but will hit home. We are mostly casting students that are graduating or still in conservatory training. It was astonishing to see that Open Calls in Turkey are not a thing. And most people, even older actors, who auditioned never even experienced an audition before. Without being famous, we want to create an opportunity for young theatre artists to be involved in a fully rounded professional production. You cannot be involved in an independent theatre production in Turkey unless you have a great network and this to me is extremely ridiculous. I am realizing what a big step it is for us and for the artists who auditioned to be involved in full production with people they never met before. On top of that being involved in a theatre production just by auditioning and not by ear. By the end of June 2019 auditions, casting will be finalized, and the rehearsal process will begin.To direct and dive into this text has been a huge dream of mine I am beyond thrilled for this journey we are about to begin.  CastAntigone // Sonya Dicle ÇetinIsmene // Gözde TürkerKreon // Veysel SisThe Guard // Dila YağcıHaimon // Mertcan SemeyMessenger // Diyar Karadaş Teiresias // Ezgi KoçerChorus // Ezgi Koçer, Gözde Yıldırım, Gökçe Uygun, Tara Melissa McMillan, and Asena YıldırımProduction TeamDirector and Translator // Cemre Su SalurStage Manager // Şevval ArslanCostume Designer // Buğu Pala The breakdown of 10.000$Monthly Total Payment for Each of 12 Actors Rehearsal Process: 3080$ (18000 TL)Set Design: 1370$ (8000 TL)The license of the Play: 1500$ (8700 TL)Costume: 890$ (5200 TL)Rent of Large Scale Rehearsal Space for 1 Month: 515$ (3000 TL)Rent of Preview Venue: 855$ (5000 TL)Promotion: 430$ (2500 TL) Production Team Rehearsal: 340$ (2000 TL) Light and Sound Designer: 515$ (3000 TL)Emergency: 600$ (3500 TL)As young theatre-makers and lovers, we ask your helping hand to simply create, make art, and be able to showcase it and share it.  Director's and Translator's Biography //Cemre Su Salur grew up in Istanbul. story:
Menomonee Falls is in need of a live music venue 

The Falls Art Collective, LLC plan to answer this need by opening a music lounge and art gallery in the village center. Serving up wine and beer from local sources to go along with the local talent entertaining the FACT 4 or 5 days a week.

Fulfilling the dream

We need to open the doors and to do that we need some quick cash for security deposits and permits to alter the space to fit our needs. All money will be used to get the doors opened and all donations of $50 or more will be commemorated (TBD) in the space.

The Impact

The village center is currently loaded with excellent bar and restaurants to accommodate the nearly 40000 residents. However, the village is lacking a key ingredient to an amazing night out with friends and family: a live music venue. With your donation we can bring the feature to the villages nightlife. 

Seeing live music is life changing. Experiencing incredible live music is life defining.

story:
From Ryan O'Connor 

"Take your broken heart, make it into art." - Carrie Fisher 

Thank you for visiting our IndieGoGo page! You've already done more than most people will and I am grateful to have your attention! 

In 2015, I was suddenly presented with a slew of life circumstances. Extreme weight loss, sobriety and a divorce. I proceeded to make one of the most bizarre and life-changing decisions of my life. I left my comfortable Los Angeles liberal show biz bubble to go work as a Field Organizer for the Hillary Clinton Presidential campaign in Pontiac, Michigan. What happened next was not only a major milestone in American politics and history, but an experience that fundamentally changed my perception of strength and adaptability. In myself, yes, but more importantly in the stories I got from, and relationships I built with, the women I met working on and volunteering for this historic and world-altering campaign. 

In late 2017, I presented a version of this story with the same title, taken form Elizabeth Gilbert's epic divorce novel, "Eat, Pray, Love," as a one night cabaret performance at LA's Rockwell Table & Stage, featuring stories from this bizarre year in my life and songs featuring myself and special guests, portraying different characters in song only. It was a really special night and what emerged was a story that I was told, and agreed, was worth telling more of.

I took this idea to the generous people at Celebration Theatre in Hollywood, and was given the opportunity to put up another version for 4 performances on their off schedule nights (Sundays and Mondays) and pulled together my resources (financially and, more importantly, favors) and in what felt like a record breaking amount of time, with the help of Tal Fox, incredible direction by Tony Award Winner Marissa Jaret Winokur, vigilant musical direction by Andy Arena, epic arrangements by Emily Rosenfield and the generous time and talent of actors Katherine Tokarz, Lindsay Heather Pearce, Amber Liekhus and Alex Nee, we somehow put up a show in 6 rehearsals that resonated with audiences beyond my wildest dreams and expectations, including winning multiple StageSceneLA awards for excellence in LA theatre! 

At the end of those 4 performances, I knew in my gut that something was here that needed to be cultivated and told even further. The characters had come to life and the story was taking hold, but it still needed to grow before it saw more audiences. It was time to turn this "play with music" into an autobigraphical musical. 

Since then, I've gotten to work. Fleshing out the story, characters and songs and figuring out the intention of the piece. To tell my own story and get lots of attention for it? Sure. I'm not gonna argue there. But also.....to use my story to empower people to walk through fear and shame and regret and be of service and listen and heal and grown and then.....to get active...to volunteer.....and vote. 

What We Need & What You Get

It starts with Los Angeles....

The goal is to set 'Vote, Pray, Love" up for success as much as humanly possible by giving it every opportunity to have a successful Los Angeles run, for a minimum of 3 weekends at a prominent Los Angeles venue, with sets, costumes, paid actors, paid musicians, marketing, publicity, musical arrangements, choreography, sound design, lighting design and that crucial piece of LA theatre success........PARKING! 

  • I can break it down for you, if you want, but here's the major fact. We need $20,000. This is the minimum it will take to make any waves in the complicated Los Angeles theatre scene and set this production up for success and future audiences. 
  • Every single cent of this campaign will go to the funding of this production, which will in turn set this production up for possible (POSSIBLE) profit that will lead to further productions of the show in other cities, in front of new audiences and possibly even more technologically advanced options that can get the piece in front of even wider audiences.....if you know what we mean. 
  • Perks! We've all been around the crowdfunding game for a while now. I'm not gonna waste your time or anyone's money and resources with t-shirts and refridgeator magnets you don't care about. Our perks are specifically targeted to help you feel a part of the process. From the basic but essentials (program thank you's, advanced purchase of tickets you know I'm gonna make you buy anyway, opening night receptions, meet and greets, special social media shout outs) to  the more unique (rehearsal vists, special in home concerts -hey big spenders-and actual participation in the show) we will do everything on our end to make you feel a part of this show which is, at it's core, about community. 
  • The main perk? Absolute heartfelt and undying gratitude. From the deepest, purest part of my heart. 

The Impact

This is a tricky time in history to ask for money for art. I know that. 

It is my earnest belief that "Vote, Pray, Love" has the ability to embolden, empower and educate people to want to not only walk through their own life trials and tribulations, but do it while helping others to help themselves and help the world. It is also my sincere hope that by bringing this show to as broad an audience as possible, we can inspire more people to get active, volunteer and vote in the crucial elections and movements facing our country today and for the future.

By funding this specific Los Angeles production of "Vote, Pray, Love" you will be helping secure the foundation to tell this story to more and more audiences over the next two years as we head in to our next Presidential election.

Risks & Challenges

Theatre is a tough medium, especially these days and especially in Los Angeles. People can watch anything at home, that's what I usually do, But, there is nothing like live theatre to motivate and inspire audiences. Can I guarantee audiences are going to come out and take to this show? No. I can't. That's the magic of theatre. It might fail. It might fail big time.

Something I learned while working for the Hillary campaign is how important community truly is. Not just idealistically, but how we are all just as strong as the weakest member of our community. And it is the responisbility of all of us to use the gifts, skills, strengths and resources we have to lift each other up so we can all thrive and succeed. 

I believe that "Vote, Pray, Love" is a direct product of my purpose and duty to the world we currently live in and I hope that as my community, you will help me fulfill that purpose to the best of my ability.  

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Spread the word. Tweet, Insta, Facebook, Snapchat, Grindr....I don't care! Just tell people! 
  • IndieGoGo has some great sharing tools, so use those or come up with your own! 
  • See something that you might be able to help with that isn't a fincanical contribution? Tell us! We need all the help we can get and aren't afraid of being creative! 

So, that's my pitch. I look forward to having you on this journey with me. I promise to make you proud.

story:
Summary

Hello! Our names are Arianna Wellmoney, Flavia Sgoifo and Bianca Waechter - we are three immigrants from Italy, Greece and Austria.

We wrote a play called "Extraordinary Aliens", which is about being a foreigner in the United States and following your dreams despite the (bureaucratic) hardships that come with trying to stay in the country.

Our play will open in Manhattan on March 15th, at Casa Italiana, and we want to take our show across the world, so we can tell our story and hopefully inspire anyone who is going through personal struggle. 

We plan to take it to the LA fringe festival, San Francisco and Europe. 

We need help funding for venues, staff, travel, accommodation, posters and everything needed to take this show around ! 

 

What We Need 

We plan to use the money for:

  • Theater venue rentals
  • Accommodation and travel 
  • Festival fees
  • Staff (light designers, box office personnel, etc.)
  • Venue insurance 
  • Posters, postcards, ads, etc.

Our ideal goal is of $10,000.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are not able to contribute, fear not! Sharing this page on facebook, posting it in your instastory, telling people about it will help and will be deeply appreciated!
