story:
Short Summary

We are The Terra Femina Collective, a group of Kansas City based theatre artists that, in June 2019, are doing something that has never happened in Kansas City: producing not just one, but two new plays, written by women, directed by women, in rep. Together these plays, MERELY PLAYERS by Katherine Gwynn and VIPER by Lindsay Adams, are re-framing current narratives around sexual assault and survivorship by engaging our audience in the kind of radical empathy that only theatre can inspire.

We've been working on this for nearly a year, planning, fundraising, gathering our artistic team, consulting with the Metropolitan Organization to Counter Sexual Assault, staging developmental readings, and spending countless hours trying to build these two worlds for Kansas City audiences. Now we're just over a month away from opening. And we need your support to make it to the finish line. 

What We Need To Make This Happen

We need $6,000 to help pay for our up-front costs of the production. This includes the space rental, materials for set, props, costumes, printing, etc, and payment for our artists. We are committed to paying our collaborators as much as we can, because art is work and we believe in fair payment.

So far, through a combination of grants and donations, we have been able to raise $3,500. We need to raise just about $2,850 to meet our goal (Indiegogo takes a 5% platform fee, which works out to $150 from $3,000, meeting our goal of $2,850. We are working artists and we want to let you know how much we appreciate your donations!

If you donate $1-$24: you will get our eternal love & gratitude!

If you donate $25: you will get our eternal love & gratitude and a poster signed by the cast and creative lead team!

If you donate $50: you get our eternal love & gratitude, a signed poster, and 1 ticket to each show

If you donate $100: you get our eternal love & gratitude, a signed poster, 1 ticket to each show, and a personal video message thank you from our team!

If you donate $300: you get our eternal love & gratitude, a signed poster, 1 ticket to each show,  a personal video message thank you from our team AND a short piece of commissioned writing from one of our playwrights!

If you donate $1000:  you get everything from the tiers above and, you’ll get to take a prop home from our set!

Why are we doing this? 

These plays were not made per se in direct response to #metoo — but that is because violence against women always has existed. We wish to highlight with these plays — one of which picks up where Shakespeare leaves off, and one of which weaves biblical creationism — how, despite heightened visibility, and discussion, and calls for change, the conversation looks very much the same as it did hundreds and hundreds of years ago. And we want to explore how we can move beyond that conversation. 

That’s why we’re doing these two new women-centered, women-authored plays, in rep. We want to be a part of a nuanced dialogue: about sexual and domestic violence, and intersections of identity,  and the ways in which women survive. These plays interrogate how not just patriarchy, but mental illness , queerness, and class affect rape culture. There is no one survivor narrative, and that’s what these shows, set amongst the wild and fearful, seek to do — create a space for multiple narratives.

I have but a penny to my name, but I want to help! 

We get that! If you are not in a position to make a financial donation, share our campaign! Send it to folks you know who care about theatre, new work, local work, women and queer folks' stories, and telling stories that center survivors. Also follow our Facebook page and Instagram, and invite people to see our show!

story:
Summary:

Terra Alta was founded in 2017 by artist and cultural producer Elisabeth Efua Sutherland. We have  hosted over 200 individual events, 500 students, and 2 university partnerships over our 2 year history. Elisabeth Efua Sutherland has 10 years of arts education and management experience spanning 8 countries on 3 continents. She has consistently demonstrated a deep commitment to the artists and art scene in Ghana.

We have committed to supporting local artists especially those who work in performance, by providing the medium scale infrastructure needed to develop sustainable individual practices in the Ghanaian creative industry. We aim to scale this model across the country, continuing to build our international and pan African partnerships to promote exchange, employment, and knowledge building in the performing arts.

For this to happen, we need your support.

The Project:

We need to raise USD15,000 for the new theatre space, which will measure 40 feet by 40 feet and will feature:

- A roofed area providing shelter from the elements

- A multi functional 100 seater auditorium space for rehearsals, workshops, performance and classroom use

- Additional studio spaces for guest artists which can double as small classroom space

- A floor suitable for dance and for young children to move on without getting hurt

We have also added a small budget for landscaping.

A total of about GHS106,000 (currently about USD20,660) has already been spent on the space, raised through a mixture of the artist’s own income and loans from her family. The plot is family owned and located conveniently on a busy main road with easy access to the rest of the city. We currently have:

- Two outdoor stages

- Washroom facilities

- A small cafe area

- A studio used by Elisabeth Efua Sutherland

- A 40 foot container currently used for dance rehearsals and storage

The Impact

Finishing this indoor facility would allow us to resume our education program for students and young children which was suspended in part due to danger from inclement weather, particularly exposure to harsh sun, insects (mosquitoes!), and rain. 

It also means we can host up to 5 different groups at a time, since it effectively splits the space down into smaller, more intimate rooms that are still interconnected in case someone wants to have a bigger event.

The upstairs spaces will also allow us to host longer artist residencies for local, visiting or international artists.

The Big Push

We are pushing to finish this space by August 2019.

If we meet our deadline, we'll be able to host two resident companies and restart our programs with small children. We'll also be able to offer regular residencies to local performing artists.

We need you to help us make this happen.

Other Ways You Can Help

Thanks for reading all the way through. This project is really special to us and we hope you can support by:

  • Giving. Every little bit helps.
  • Sharing this campaign as widely as you can. Talk to your friends, family, and business contacts about what we're doing. Arrange to visit our space if you're in town and talk to one of the staff or the artists.
  • You can also donate in kind. Please contact us at terraaltagh@gmail.com for a list of our required equipment.
  • Don't forget to share on your social media using the handy buttons provided by Indiegogo!

We appreciate you.
story_txt:
Summary:
Terra Alta was founded in 2017 by artist and cultural producer Elisabeth Efua Sutherland. We have  hosted over 200 individual events, 500 students, and 2 university partnerships over our 2 year history. Elisabeth Efua Sutherland has 10 years of arts education and management experience spanning 8 countries on 3 continents. She has consistently demonstrated a deep commitment to the artists and art scene in Ghana.
We have committed to supporting local artists especially those who work in performance, by providing the medium scale infrastructure needed to develop sustainable individual practices in the Ghanaian creative industry. We aim to scale this model across the country, continuing to build our international and pan African partnerships to promote exchange, employment, and knowledge building in the performing arts.
For this to happen, we need your support.

The Project:
We need to raise USD15,000 for the new theatre space, which will measure 40 feet by 40 feet and will feature:
- A roofed area providing shelter from the elements
- A multi functional 100 seater auditorium space for rehearsals, workshops, performance and classroom use
- Additional studio spaces for guest artists which can double as small classroom space
- A floor suitable for dance and for young children to move on without getting hurt
We have also added a small budget for landscaping.
A total of about GHS106,000 (currently about USD20,660) has already been spent on the space, raised through a mixture of the artist’s own income and loans from her family. The plot is family owned and located conveniently on a busy main road with easy access to the rest of the city. We currently have:
- Two outdoor stages
- Washroom facilities
- A small cafe area
- A studio used by Elisabeth Efua Sutherland
- A 40 foot container currently used for dance rehearsals and storage

The Impact
Finishing this indoor facility would allow us to resume our education program for students and young children which was suspended in part due to danger from inclement weather, particularly exposure to harsh sun, insects (mosquitoes!), and rain. 
It also means we can host up to 5 different groups at a time, since it effectively splits the space down into smaller, more intimate rooms that are still interconnected in case someone wants to have a bigger event.
The upstairs spaces will also allow us to host longer artist residencies for local, visiting or international artists.

The Big Push
We are pushing to finish this space by August 2019.
If we meet our deadline, we'll be able to host two resident companies and restart our programs with small children. We'll also be able to offer regular residencies to local performing artists.
We need you to help us make this happen.

Other Ways You Can Help
Thanks for reading all the way through. This project is really special to us and we hope you can support by:

Giving. Every little bit helps.
Sharing this campaign as widely as you can. Talk to your friends, family, and business contacts about what we're doing. Arrange to visit our space if you're in town and talk to one of the staff or the artists.
You can also donate in kind. Please contact us at terraaltagh@gmail.com for a list of our required equipment.
Don't forget to share on your social media using the handy buttons provided by Indiegogo!

We appreciate you.

story:
In Short...

DETC is committed to growing the art of theatre by producing innovative plays that underscore the complexity of human interaction. We nurture the growth of artists of all ages, on and off the stage, and create an environment that rewards and cherishes them. 

Our theatre internships give high school students the on-the-job experience of working in professional productions. They work in a professional environment, expanding and putting into practice what they have learned in school. DETC awards scholarships to graduating seniors who have completed DETC internships and plan to continue their higher education in theatre arts.

This being said, in order for us to keep up with demand, a new sound and light board are needed. Those boards alone will set us back thousands of dollars; but will propel our program further than ever before. Your donation will also help fund just ONE of our shows this season. Our goal...$10,000. 

What We Need & What You Get

Heres the deal...

  • With your donation you'll get one (or more) of the amazing perks we crafted for each category. They range from free breakfast, to season tickets, to even our sought after Gala tickets this November.
  • You also get to call yourself a producer on some of the perks and get special access that no other theatre angel gets. 
  • The funds will go directly to purchasing a new light and sound board as well as funding ONE of our shows this season. At a bare minimum, it costs about $5,500 just for ONE show. 
  • You might ask why it costs that much to produce one show. Truth be told, we believe in paying everyone that works with us, including a small stipend to our student interns. You are literally contributing to our theatre economy. 

Our Impact

Theatre is truly an amazing art form, not only do our audiences get an entertaining evening but we produce shows that press the boundaries. Giving audiences a chance to see new and established work that speaks to our community; all the while working our student interns.

  • With your help you are ensuring our successful program continues to thrive, especially with new equipment. 
  • For seven seasons we have not only taught our students amazing skills, but served our community as a true professional non profit theatre.
  • Even though we have had our audience size grow year after year; we CAN'T survive off attendance alone. We really need your help in order for us to expand our tech capability as well as help as funding one of our shows. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some times its hard to contribute...we get it, were a non profit theatre after-all. Heres some other amazing ways you can help.

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools to help us spread our message and meet our goal!

Thank you so much for reading this long, really long, probably longer than it should be synopsis of our crowdfunding campaign. Help us reach our goal of $10,000, whether its contributing money, or sharing our story; you'll ensure we continue to serve our community and students for several more years.

story:
DONATE TO ABFAB! 

ABFAB has until Monday, April 18th to secure its lease for The Exit Theatre! 

We are asking our individual donors for $100; in return you will secure a pair of tickets to the performance of your choice in October or November. And think about making a donation as a gift to surprise friends with! We'd make a great birthday present, bridal or stag party!

Since October 2014 the zany actors of the Royal British Comedy Theatre have brought you an astounding 14 episodes of your fave TV sitcom. You've followed us from StageWerx to the Exit to Oasis! Now come back and party with us at the Exit! 

We are calling on our Chanel-suited, booze-swilling fans to help us produce Episodes 15 and 16: SEX & SMALL OPENING! Oct. 27-Nov. 19, 2016!

Sex: Patsy and Eddy plan an orgy while Saffy and her classmates prepare a presentation about "Genetics & Ethics" at college.  And then a videotape... and a drag queen... and hunky rent boys and...

Small Opening: When Saffy writes a play about her family life all hell breaks loose at home. Will Edina show for Saffy's show? And something about a kitten and another drag queen... 


What ABFAB Needs & What ABFABBERS Get!

Your "Fantribution" helps ABFAB secure the lease for the Exit Theater for our first four-week, primetime run Oct. 27-Nov. 19, 2016!

Your "Fanperks" include: tickets to the performance of your choice. And don't forget the bar in the Exit Cafe for your drinks before/during/after the show.

The Impact

ABFAB recently won the 45th BESTIES 2016 award for Best Show in a Club (Oasis). We need our fans to help us continue the laughter. We launched in 2014 with huge assistance from fans donating to our first Indiegogo campaign. We can't do it without you, darlings!

Other Ways You Can Help

Sweeties, if you still want to donate funds you may only without the pair of tickets. 

And...

Darlings, if you can't donate now please spread the word via your social media so that we can raise enough donations in seven days to secure our lease. Just check-out our Indiegogo share tools!

story:
My name is Jon Sue-Ho.  I have BS degrees in mechanical engineering and theater arts, run a website called ScottishPepTalks.com (inspirational and hilarious messages in a Scottish accent)  and my entire life, I’ve been trying to make people laugh and smile.Unbearably Funny is my self-produced stand-up show, where my clean (but by no means squeaky) comedy touches on everything from my ethnic ambiguity, super heroes, how karaoke is like fairy tales, pep talks in a Scottish accent (see above), stuff my mom says, and, most importantly, bears.

This helps me fulfill two big dreams: (1) To do public stand-up in a place other than a seedy bar where the other comics are drunk and (2) To raise enough revenue to make Scottish Pep Talks a real quasi-legitimate business as far as tax law is concerned.  It’s not an illegitimate business.  It’s a business that was conceived out of wedlock but whose parents got married right away.  Read the full story at "A Tale of Kilts and Tax Law."

I have a lot of experience doing stand-up but never professionally.  In addition to writing and performing my material, I am: booking the venue, hiring an opening act/MC (who unfortunately isn’t getting paid enough), hiring a graphic designer (who unfortunately isn’t getting paid nearly enough), arranging presale tickets, making event t-shirts, making teddy bears wearing the event t-shirts, making a website, arranging audio/video recording, audio album distribution costs, and so much more.

Any money left over from the show will be poured back as seed funds for more hilarious enterprises designed to make the world a better place, or at least a funnier one with projects ridiculous as Scottish Christmas albums, suicide prevention walks in a kilt, and something called RussianSadTalks.com (tragically hilarious messages in an Eastern European accent).

Expenses include things we already have like:web hostingdomain name registrationalbum distribution costsPO boxesa kiltand things we’d like to buy:a camerabetter microphonesan awesome Russian hat, a kilt, and so much more.

story:
Short Summary

  • I'm Henry Allen, founding director of what you know and love as The Folklore Theatre Company. I moved to Cape Ann in the summer of 2009 to reboot my life, just a year after losing my beloved son Cameron to brain cancer at age 13. I opened The Cape Ann (lovingly referred to by our community as "The Annie") to be a cultural center for downtown Gloucester, here in the heart of Cape Ann. We partnered with Fractured Atlas as our fiscal sponsor. My mission has always been to hold and care for the place-specific stories, so that the next generations will know and inherit them with pride. After all, how do we know who we are if we don't know where we come from? With our inaugural 2011 production, "Greasy Pole, The Musical," our love affair with Gloucester & Cape Ann began. We are proud to have sustained to this point, entering our 7th season in 2017.  This important work has been recognized by the UN and has taken our little company as far as Fiji! This is only the beginning! 
  • The high rent at the Blackburn was more than we could sustain, and we knew that the magic we were creating was not in the walls, but in the people - both on stage and in the audience. We revamped, re-identified as The Folklore Theatre Company, and became a gypsy company for the next two years, until landing back downtown in the old Empire building at The Floating Lotus, Gloucester's new world cultural center ("The FloLo"). Now, after three successful productions, The LobstahCrackah Ballet, Dogtown Common & Greasy Pole, we are ready to take things to a new level by transforming our studio in to a proper black box theatre. 
  • By contributing to this, our first-ever capital campaign, you will help us ensure that our company can grow and sustain well into the future. Our outstanding shows and programs serve the broad and diverse community of the area, drawing folks of all ages from all over the North Shore of MA. 

What We Need & What You Get

  • We hope to raise $25,000 by October 1st, 2016 (includes 10% in crowdfunding fees: 90% of funds raised will go to the FTC) to get the ball rolling on this project. Lights, staging, risers, paint, equipment... the tools to raise the production value of our awesome shows and develop our space are not cheap. Box office revenue is just not enough to cover these costs. With arts and culture funding being slashed at the State level, we must rely on our community to invest in and support our work.  
  • The perks of supporting this project are magnificent: Season Tickets, Fabulous FTC merchandise (we will be adding show tees and company hooded sweatshirts to the list soon!), sponsorship listing in all our programs, or how about your very own year-round reserved seat with your name on it? 
  • If we don't reach our $25K goal with this campaign by October, we will budget what we do raise in a responsible way that will create a financial runway into our 2017 season. 
  • If we raise more than our $25K goal, we may hire a part-time administrative assistant, create a "scholarship-type" fund to cover the costs of our programs for families in need, create mentorship and cultural exchange programs to broaden the scrop of our creative youth... there is so much we can and want to do in service to our community. 

The Impact

  • Our downtown sorely needs a cultural center that includes a flexible, dedicated performing arts space to serve our local artists, youth through senior. This campaign would easily make this dream a reality. We even have the opportunity to expand into the space next door, which is still under construction. If we can expand our space, our vision will expand as well.
  • Since we opened at the Blackburn in 2011, our track record has been outstanding in consistently providing affordable, innovative productions and programs that reflect the Cape Ann experience, providing outstanding life skills-building programs for youth (including our Conservatory Lab, Young  Mystics Club, Summer Stock  & After SchoolTheatre Clubs), as well as intergenerational programs 18-senior that raise the quality of life for all involved.
  • The Folklore Theatre Company, one of very few year-round theatres in the region, has become a jewel in the Cape Ann crown that shines all over the North Shore. We are actively contributing to Gloucester's global reputation for innovation, and are proud of our collaborations with other service organizations and will continue to build healthy partnerships in the community. We ask our whole community to partner with us now by championing our growth and development through this campaign. 

Risks & Challenges

The Folklore Theatre Company a small, community service-oriented public theatre company with a big heart. We struggle daily to stay open and accessible to all. 

  • We want to keep our exceptional shows and intergenerational programs accessible to all. To do so, we need to grow as an organization. We want to create a strong foundation under us to we can continue to serve our community and beyond. 
  • We need a real performing arts space to make these things happen. All art requires space to dream. Theatre, in particular, needs space to reflect those dreams. It needs a space, a concrete, committed space, for that to occur. We invite you to be part of that process.

Other Ways You Can Help

We are a public theatre. We are committed to making everything we do accessible to everyone in our community, including fundraising. If you are unable to contribute financially to this campaign, that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Ask your Folk to get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Contact local businesses you know to donate materials. That keeps our overhead costs low and they will be listed as a sponsor in gratitude for supporting this project! 
  • Indiegogo has great share tools! Be sure to use them to spread the word for us.

The Cape Ann/The Annie is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of The Cape Ann/ The Annie must be made payable to “Fractured Atlas” only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
ABOUT THE PROJECT

43rd Street is a musical parody of many famous Broadway and Hollywood musicals.  It pokes fun at the persona of screen legend Joan Crawford and utilizes updated and re-worked songs from some of Tin Pan Alley’s greatest composers.  43rd Street features singing, dancing, camp humor and men in drag.  It’s a backstage musical that has been described as "A strange mix of The Carol Burnett Show and a John Waters film."

Douglas Hill, Associate Producer of The Neil Simon Festival, wrote the following about the script:

"The play draws a lot of energy from staples of the traditional drag show: parody, camp, mockery of ​“traditional” values, references to popular culture, and winks and nods at the audience. There is also ​an attitude of fringe theatre in the script -- but where many fringe shows seek to alienate older adults, I found that this script still reached out to fans of classic cinema and early Jazz music."

"The showtunes and the ​movies become a game for the audience ​to play while it’s ​watching the play itself." 

Through this Indiegogo campaign, we hope to raise the necessary funds to continue working on the show.  This includes creating a studio recording of all the songs, with a full orchestra, and producing a series of staged readings of the script before a live audience.

 

A SHAMELESS SOLICITATION FOR DONATIONS
 

HISTORY OF 43rd STREET

I have always loved old movies and Broadway musicals.  This love inspired me to begin 43rd Street, as a way to pay homage to those classics.  My simple objective with the play was to provide a fun evening of escapist theatre.  As Brecht said, “From the start it has been the theatre’s business to entertain people.  It needs no other passport than fun.”

In October of 2015, Three Cat Productions produced a staged reading of the script.  This reading was very beneficial and showed me areas of the book that needed cut, edited and/or improved.

At last, we have a completed the script, and thanks to the talented Donny Walker, we have full orchestrations for all songs. 

Now, it’s time to go into the studio and record the score and to perform a staged reading of the script.  With your help, we can achieve these goals.

 

A SHAMELESS SOLICITATION FOR DONATIONS
 

WHAT WE NEED

To achieve our goal, or any portion of it, we need financial assistance.

It is our desire to hire actors, singers, musicians and an entire production team and this takes money.  This endeavor is quite expensive.  It's amazing how much time, effort and money is required to produce a simple evening of escapist entertainment.

At first glance, I realize that our goal seems extremely high, but feel free to take a look at our proposed budget.  As you will see, our target goal allots less than $29 per day for each person involved in the reading and/or recording session.  On the likely chance that we do not reach of full goal, we plan to use all contributions to continue working on the project in following stages. 

  • Organize and cast a small, closed door reading of the script.
  • Record the full score with full orchestrations and a complete cast.
  • Mount an open-to-the public staged reading of the book and score. 
  • Market the script and demo to theatre companies in the hopes of securing a production.

Remember, If everyone of our friends and family members would donate just one dollar, we would be nowhere close to making our goal.   But, at least we would have something!

 
A SHAMELESS SOLICITATION FOR DONATIONS
 

WHAT’S IN IT FOR YOU?

If you make a donation (in any amount), you can take pride in knowing that you have helped supported the arts.  For less than the price of a supersized, fast food meal, you can help a starving person . . . .  a person starving for an evening of low-brow, unsophisticated entertainment.   The play you save, could be mine.

In case you need a little enticement to donate, we have arranged for a few rewards.  You can check out a sample of them HERE, but remember, it's really not about the reward.  It's all about that bass.

A SHAMELESS SOLICITATION FOR DONATIONS
 
 

CREATIVE TEAM

Mark Ridge (Writer)

As a student, Mark won the U of E playwriting competition for two consecutive years. As a director, his production of THE GREAT NEBULA IN ORION was selected to showcase at the American College Theatre Festival, earning both cast members Irene Ryan nominations. His additional directing credits include BEDROOM FARCE, DICK AND JANE and GRACELAND. A graduate of The Second City Actor Training Program, Mark has appeared in shows with the Shawnee Professional Theatre Company, The Court Theatre and was a founding member of The Griffin Theatre Company in Chicago. Mark is currently an Actors' Equity Membership Candidate, a proud member of the Pee Wee Herman Fun Club and a member of The Dramatists Guild of America. As a playwright, he has been inspired by Tennessee Williams (for his brilliant use of language), Neil Simon (for his brilliant use of humor), and Penny Sycamore (who wrote plays simply because a typewriter was delivered to her home by mistake). Mark's plays include RUSSIAN ROULETTE, OUT WITH A BANG, SOMETHING STRANGE IS HAPPENING AT THE C.C.& C., YOUR CHEATIN' HEART & MY FRIDAY NIGHT BLUES and BESTSELLER. After a nearly 25 year break spent working in the Chicago film industry  (IMDB him here), Mark is excited to resume working in the theatre. His recent works include EUPHORIA and KILLING KITTENS, which was produced by Theatre on the Square in Indianapolis and received a staged reading in New Jersey by La Strada Ensemble Theatre, as part of the 2015 Pride Month Rainbow Reading Series.  Killing Kittens is scheduled to be published later this year by Chicago Dramaworks. 

 

Andrew Souders  (Artistic Director, Additional Lyrics)

Andrew Souders is an award winning Director, who holds a BFA in Directing from The University of Evansville. He is a founding member of The Griffin Theatre Co. and was one of the four original Artistic Associates of Pride Films & Plays Theatre Co., both here in Chicago. Some of his favorite work to date include: THE NIGHT LARRY KRAMER KISSED ME, SOME MEN, BLOWING WHISTLES, PETER PAN, FINIAN’S RAINBOW, THE IMPORTANCE OF BEING EARNEST, EUPHORIA, and THE LADY FROM DUBUQUE…The latter winning him the Sammy Award for Best Direction of a play, and affording him the privilege of meeting the play’s author, Edward Albee. Andrew hopes that all his friends & family give generously to this campaign so that 43rd St. can get the life it deserves. This is a very important work of art, it’s social relevance, and thought provoking story are just what the world so desperately needs right now. Please dig Deeply.

 

Donny Walker (Orchestrations)

Composer, Arranger, Orchestrator & Music Producer Donny Walker has done music editorial/music engraving work with The Chicago Symphony, Chicago Jazz Philharmonic, The Lincoln Symphony Orchestra and The Bari Symphonic Orchestra. He’s composed, arranged, orchestrated and produced hours of musical content for Full Score Chamber Orchestra, Lake Forrest Civic Orchestra, done production assistant work for HARPO and performed with world class talent including: Aretha Franklin, The Ojays, the Dells, and many local Chicago organizations. Studio album production-wise, he’s arranged & produced many studio albums for The Quazi-Exotix and Ron Arden’s The Voice of Love as well as educational content for non profit West Point School of Music for their big band and many other educational institutions, wind ensemble & steel pan ensemble. Film composition & production credits for 2016 already include; The Swim Coach, The Dig, Perfectly Unhealthy, The Percentages and feature length film The Low End, there were many to come before this season. In 2015 he arranged & orchestrated the full length comedic musical 43rd street with playwright extraordinaire Mark Ridge. Donny is a graduate of Interlochen Arts Academy, acquired his associates degree at DePaul University and his bachelor’s degree at Columbia College Chicago, currently he’s a full scholarship student at North Eastern Illinois University, working on a masters degree in music pedagogy and specializes in Trombone(s) of all shapes and sizes. Educational mentors & include CSO, Lyric & Chicago Jazz Ensemble. His music production company is Mind Exchange Music LLC and specializes in music production for any medium.

A SHAMELESS SOLICITATION FOR DONATIONS
 
To learn a little more about the show, to see sample script and sheet music pages, and to hear a few rough music samples, please visit our website.
 

IN ADDITION TO YOUR DONATION, THERE ARE OTHER WAYS THAT YOU CAN HELP

If you are unable to make a donation, you can still help us with the show.

  • If you are an actor, singer, musician, producer, or member of any technical or run crew, you can volunteer your time and talent.  We would welcome the assistance.
  • If you have a rehearsal space that we could use, please let us know.
  • If you have access to copy machines, you can help copy scripts, scores and programs.
  • If you are a member of a local theatre company that would be willing to donate some of their time, talent, expertise or resources, we would welcome the assistance.
  • You could share our fundraising campaign with your all friends and family.  Any social media shares (Facebook, Twitter, Pinterest, Instagram, etc) would be very helpful.
  • You could like and share our Facebook page.
  • You could refer people to our website.  
  • You can take Sondheim's advice and you could drive a person crazy.  
A SHAMELESS SOLICITATION FOR DONATIONS
 

RANDOM NOTES FROM THE AUTHOR

  • There is nothing more gratifying then hearing a group of actors breathe life into your characters.
  • When creative people come together, magic can (and does) happen. 
  • It’s a wonderful feeling to unite an audience in laughter or tears.
  • Often times, I am told that my writing only appeals to a niche, fringe market.   A staged reading is the perfect opportunity to demonstrate the universal appeal of my work.  Laughter unites. 
  • Ever since McDonald’s switched to trans-free oil, I have not liked their French fries.
  • It is a rare opportunity for writers to hear actors and directors interpret their work and a reading is an invaluable tool. 
  • They say “Great plays are not written.  They are re-written.”  I’m not sure mine is a great play, but at least it has been written.  I think that’s half the battle.
  • I think Judge Judy would make an excellent musical heroine.  She practically screams "Jerry Herman."

 

A SHAMELESS SOLICITATION FOR DONATIONS
 
 

Joan Crawford

If you are not familiar with Joan Crawford, there is a great chance that you are very young.  There is an even greater chance that you are straight.

In 1999, the American Film Institute ranked Crawford tenth on their list of the greatest female stars of Classic Hollywood Cinema.  Some of her many films include, Torch Song, The Women, Grand Hotel, Flamingo Road, Johnny Guitar, Straight Jacket and What Ever Happened to Baby Jane? and her Oscar winning role as Mildred Pierce.   Her last feature film was the cult classic Trog.  She died in 1977.  Unfortunately, today Joan Crawford is probably best known as the subject of the tell-all novel Mommie Dearest. You may not have seen this film based on the book, but you’ve probably heard it quoted.  “I told you no wire clothes hangers, ever!”

 
 

A FINAL SHAMELESS SOLICITATION
story_txt:
ABOUT THE PROJECT43rd Street is a musical parody of many famous Broadway and Hollywood musicals.  It pokes fun at the persona of screen legend Joan Crawford and utilizes updated and re-worked songs from some of Tin Pan Alley’s greatest composers.  43rd Street features singing, dancing, camp humor and men in drag.  It’s a backstage musical that has been described as "A strange mix of The Carol Burnett Show and a John Waters film."Douglas Hill, Associate Producer of The Neil Simon Festival, wrote the following about the script:"The play draws a lot of energy from staples of the traditional drag show: parody, camp, mockery of ​“traditional” values, references to popular culture, and winks and nods at the audience. There is also ​an attitude of fringe theatre in the script -- but where many fringe shows seek to alienate older adults, I found that this script still reached out to fans of classic cinema and early Jazz music.""The showtunes and the ​movies become a game for the audience ​to play while it’s ​watching the play itself."  Through this Indiegogo campaign, we hope to raise the necessary funds to continue working on the show.  This includes creating a studio recording of all the songs, with a full orchestra, and producing a series of staged readings of the script before a live audience. A than fun.”In October of 2015, Three Cat Productions produced a staged reading of the script.  This reading was very beneficial and showed me areas of the book that needed cut, edited and/or story:
Putting on a show isn't easy...

New York City is expensive, especially for artists.  Mx. JP Anne Giera believes that all artists working on any production need be compensated because their work and time is worth it.  

Even when included in a festival, a production still requires a lot of funds.  The raised money through this campaign will be used for raw materials for production including costume, set, sound etc., massive rehearsal space costs, PR materials,  and funding for all collaborators.  Then, and only then, does Mx. Giera receive any funding, for without their collaborators, a space to rehearse in, PR to advertise the show and more, the artist would be doing 'solo work' in the truest  most naked sense.

 

The production...

'Blanche On A Winter's Eve' is the product of over two years of hard work by Mx. JP Anne Giera and collaborative director Danny Gorman.  The first workshop was presented as part of the 2015 Planet Connections Theatre Festivity where it garnered an award for "Best Overall Solo Show" for the season.  In the Spring of 2016, the script was chosen to be presented as part of the United Solo Theatre Festival in New York City on  Tuesday November 8th, 2016 at 7:30 PM.  (http://unitedsolo.org/us/blanche-2016/)  This is a great honor and we look forward to sharing the work with you.

 

Describe 'Blanche'....

Ha.  Well, 'Blanche on A Winter's Eve' is a queer Christmas delusion for one performer. After a heavenly vision appears to our anti-hero, the world of America's favorite 'Golden Girl', Blanche Devereaux, and the artist's autobiographical reality become entwined as the search for amazing sex, self-acceptance, and identity drive the story forward.  Part comedy, part Golden Girls homage, part autoethnography, Blanche On A Winter's Eve is a unique evening of theatre.

The piece is very close to the heart of Mx. JP Anne Giera, as it deals with their constant battles with addiction, sexual validation, and the harsh reality that they aren't actually Rue McClanahan.  Additionally, as a gender non-conforming individual, it provides visibility where there might not be otherwise.  Contrary to popular belief, there isn't a lot work out there for a non-binary femme with addiction issues who also holds an MFA in Acting. 

 

I wanna help, but money is tight...

Totally!  We get it, money is tight for everyone.  If you aren't in a place to financially support the show, Blanche still wants you to be one of the many, many, many people who touch their life! Spread the word!  You can share our campaign on social media, check out and share the artist's Facebook page (facebook.com/jpannegiera), or buy a ticket! (http://unitedsolo.org/us/blanche-2016/).  The show appears only once as part of the United Solo Theatre Festival on Tuesday November 8th at 7:30 PM.  Isn't that Election Day you ask?  Why yes, yes it is.  BUT...the show is at 7:30 PM and has a run time of 60 minutes.  By the time the show is over at 8:30 PM the voter returns will barely be coming in.  We can all go to the bar and drink to the show and to the fact that our country is falling apart before our eyes!

Thanks for listening and for your support!

story:
Welcome to StripTix

StripTix is a mobile app that aims to have all competitions, auditions and workshops for the pole, arial and showgirl community in one place!

Our community is a small one but it is growing and with StripTix we're hoping to help it expand, make it easier to know when an event is on and bring more people into the community.

By contributing to this project you'll be helping us bring our idea to life!

What We Need

Currently we need:

  • $350 to register the business.
  • $10,000 to build the application.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Ask your friends to get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Use the Indiegogo share button and see if anyone else is able to help!

And that's all there is to it.

story:
Boxcutter Collective 2020 Fundraiser

Hello! We are the Boxcutter Collective: Joe Therrien, Sam Wilson, Jason Hicks, and Tom Cunningham. We all met while working for The Bread and Puppet Theater, and have been collaborating in various combinations and projects over the last 15 years. In 2016, we formed the Boxcutter Collective to focus our energies on toppling the rotten empire that has grown and grown before our eyes. Since then, we have been making insurrectionary puppet shows at a feverish pace trying to do our part to incite the revolutionary paradigm-shift that we all know our world needs. We believe cultural change precedes political change, and to do that we need to create a wellspring of new art that the public can see, digest, and internalize as a part of the recipe for collective transformation. Your tax-deductible contribution will help us keep our ticket prices very low (usually free), compensate and feed the many volunteer artists who work with us, and support our work logistically with studio and transportation costs. This in turn, will increase the amount of audience who gets to see our shows exponentially and contribute to the cultural transformation of society towards a more just and sustainable reality.

What We've Done, Where We're Headed, and What You Get!

Since the fall of 2016 we have made dozens of new puppet shows that have responded to the needs of the moment. We teamed up with the Sunrise Movement and created a Coney Island Mermaid Parade contingent promoting the Green New Deal with 75 performers. We have worked with formerly incarcerated folks through a partnership with Inside Change to help teach skills and create connections for folks just getting out of jail. We've worked with dozens of other artists in different combinations, helping foster the work of new revolutionary artists, and collaborating with dozens of talented artists to bring a wave of new works to hundreds of people.

We believe this kind of work should be accessible to all people regardless of their financial situation. Almost all of our shows are sliding scale $0-$25. We try to keep our costs low, but we still have to rely on many hours of volunteer labor to make it work. A large part of this fundraiser is intended to be able to compensate the dozens of people who work together with us to make these shows happen. Your contribution will help us pay artists and feed them at our rehearsals and shows. Being able to compensate artists, even nominally, will greatly increase their ability to commit their time and talent to the work and increase the amount of audience who gets to see our shows exponentially. We also are raising money to help with the very real costs of studio rental in NYC, and other logistical and transportation needs that are an inescapable reality of schlepping puppet shows from Brooklyn to the rest of the world. 

But I know what you are asking yourself -what do YOU get out of contributing to this Quixotic quest to flood the free market with a deluge of post-pre-post consumerist existentialist anti-deepfake pro-human propaganda? Well, besides our deepest gratitude and a promise that we will work even harder to convince the world it’s worth saving -we’ll give you puppets! & prints! & shows in your living rooms! Even a lecture on the history of the Beach Boys by Tom! (for real -he knows a lot). Check out our perks for more information.

Other Ways You Can Help

We are hoping to connect with people who want to support our work and are in a financial situation where they feel comfortable to do so. If you are broke -we don’t want you to become broker because of us! But we would you ask you to please share this campaign on your social media accounts, through email, through conversations IN REAL LIFE, and in any other ways you can think to help get the world out. Help connect us with the rich weirdos who want to fund the cultural revolution!

And if you ARE one of those rich weirdos -well, what are you waiting for? Donate now and support the kind of art that is trying to change minds, hearts, and shift consciousnesses in direct defiance of the overwhelming odds against us.

Read What John Bell, Paul Zaloom, &Dick Zygun have to say about The Boxcutter Collective: 

"BoxCutter Collective is making new and exciting theater work addressing the challenging issues we all face, with humor, music, and brilliant puppets, masks, sets, and an activist perspective. They deserve your support!"

-John Bell, America's Puppet Professor and Member of Great Small Works

“It’s rare to find a puppet theater on this planet with the kind of quality, integrity, and absolute hilariousness of the remarkable Boxcutter Collective. Their super creative use of puppets carries on the ancient tradition of irreverent and joyfully rude puppetry that has confronted injustice and tyranny from time immemorial. I wholeheartedly and enthusiastically recommend the Boxcutter Collective and their hilarious puppet shows.”

-Paul Zaloom, Puppeteer Extraordinaire! 

"The BoxCutter Collective is NYC’s Punk Rock branch of world famous Bread and Puppet Theater. They’re always smart, super talented, and as tight as a four piece garage band...They are Anarchist Art Puppeteers and you should give them all your money.”

-Dick Zigun, Mayor and Founder of Coney Island USA

 

If you are in NYC, come to our In-Real-Life Fundraising Party:

We are having an in-real-life fundraising party hosted by Greg Corbino, with performances by Jennifer Miller, Tamar Korn, and us!!

DETAILS:

Friday, Feb 28th from 7-9 pm
At The Henson Carriage House (225 East 67th Street, New York, NY 10065)

FB Event Link: https://www.facebook.com/events/213103216403141/

 

THANK YOU MOST SINCERELY FROM: 

 

Sam, Jason, Tom, & Joe

The Boxcutter Collective
story_txt:
Boxcutter Collective 2020 Fundraiser
Hello! We are the Boxcutter Collective: Joe Therrien, Sam Wilson, Jason Hicks, and Tom Cunningham. We all met while working for The Bread and Puppet Theater, and have been collaborating in various combinations and projects over the last 15 years. In 2016, we formed the Boxcutter Collective to focus our energies on toppling the rotten empire that has grown and grown before our eyes. Since then, we have been making insurrectionary puppet shows at a feverish pace trying to do our part to incite the revolutionary paradigm-shift that we all know our world needs. We believe cultural change precedes political change, and to do that we need to create a wellspring of new art that the public can see, digest, and internalize as a part of the recipe for collective transformation. Your tax-deductible contribution will help us keep our ticket prices very low (usually free), compensate and feed the many volunteer artists who work with us, and support our work logistically with studio and transportation costs. This in turn, will increase the amount of audience who gets to see our shows exponentially and contribute to the cultural transformation of society towards a more just and sustainable reality.
What We've Done, Where We're Headed, and What You Get!
Since the fall of 2016 we have made dozens of new puppet shows that have responded to the needs of the moment. We teamed up with the Sunrise Movement and created a Coney Island Mermaid Parade contingent promoting the Green New Deal with 75 performers. We have worked with formerly incarcerated folks through a partnership with Inside Change to help teach skills and create connections for folks just getting out of jail. We've worked with dozens of other artists in different combinations, helping foster the work of new revolutionary artists, and collaborating with dozens of talented artists to bring a wave of new works to hundreds of people.
We believe this kind of work should be accessible to all people regardless of their financial situation. Almost all of our shows are sliding scale $0-$25. We try to keep our costs low, but we still have to rely on many hours of volunteer labor to make it work. A large part of this fundraiser is intended to be able to compensate the dozens of people who work together with us to make these shows happen. Your contribution will help us pay artists and feed them at our rehearsals and shows. Being able to compensate artists, even nominally, will greatly increase their ability to commit their time and talent to the work and increase the amount of audience who gets to see our shows exponentially. We also are raising money to help with the very real costs of studio rental in NYC, and other logistical and transportation needs that are an inescapable reality of schlepping puppet shows from Brooklyn to the rest of the world. 
But I know what you are asking yourself -what do YOU get out of contributing to this Quixotic quest to flood the free market with a deluge of post-pre-post consumerist existentialist anti-deepfake pro-human propaganda? Well, besides our deepest gratitude and a promise that we will work even harder to convince the world it’s worth saving -we’ll give you puppets! & prints! & shows in your living rooms! Even a lecture on the history of the Beach Boys by Tom! (for real -he knows a lot). Check out our perks for more information.
Other Ways You Can Help
We are hoping to connect with people who want to support our work and are in a financial situation where they feel comfortable to do so. If you are broke -we don’t want you to become broker because of us! But we would you ask you to please share this campaign on your social media accounts, through email, through conversations IN REAL LIFE, and in any other ways you can think to help get the world out. Help connect us with the rich weirdos who want to fund the cultural revolution!
And if you ARE one of those rich weirdos -well, what are you waiting for? Donate now and support the kind of art that is trying to change minds, hearts, and shift consciousnesses in direct defiance of the overwhelming odds against us.
Read What John Bell, Paul Zaloom, &Dick Zygun have to say about The Boxcutter Collective: 
"BoxCutter Collective is making new and exciting theater work addressing the challenging issues we all face, with humor, music, and brilliant puppets, masks, sets, and an activist perspective. They deserve your support!"
-John Bell, America's Puppet Professor and Member of Great Small Works
“It’s rare to find a puppet theater on this planet with the kind of quality, integrity, and absolute hilariousness of the remarkable Boxcutter Collective. Their super creative use of puppets carries on the ancient tradition of irreverent and joyfully rude puppetry that has confronted injustice and tyranny from time immemorial. I wholeheartedly and enthusiastically recommend the Boxcutter Collective and their hilarious puppet shows.”
-Paul Zaloom, Puppeteer Extraordinaire! 
"The BoxCutter Collective is NYC’s Punk Rock branch of world famous Bread and Puppet Theater. They’re always smart, super talented, and as tight as a four piece garage band...They are Anarchist Art Puppeteers and you should give them all your money.”
-Dick Zigun, Mayor and Founder of Coney Island USA

story:
The Adaptations Project is launching an artist residency program in upstate New York. Winwick House (pronounced Win-nick) is a 130 year old farmhouse in the northern Catskills. For the last 2 years, I have been personally overseeing the renovation of all the guest rooms, the kitchen and bathrooms as well as common living areas. The property includes a 700 square foot studio just steps away from the Catskill Creek. This year we will transform this former artist studio into The Studio at Winwick which will serve as an artistic base for The Adaptations Project for the creation of new works. It will also be available as a seasonal residency and unique destination for other theatre and dance artists as a creative laboratory for rehearsals, readings, and company retreats. 

We are at a critical stage right now. As we shift our focus away from the house and to the studio and workspace, professional contractors will take over. We must:

  • upgrade the roof and windows,
  • install a sprung floor
  • build a mudroom extension for prop storage 
  • install a basic sound and lighting system

 

Our intention however is to keep the facility modest and in line with that of the simple environs. Even with the volunteers and in-kind donations we expect and hope to receive to achieve all this, it is absolutely necessary that we must fundraise. All of the money we raise in this $20K for 2020 campaign will entirely go toward the studio renovation. Truthfully, it will take almost double that amount to complete the transformation. And so, it is critical we reach this particular benchmark by the end of March in order to begin work. 

On a personal note:

I've had 20 years of collaborating, creating works, touring and teaching internationally in 8 different countries including Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Germany, Mexico, Puerto Rico, Thailand, and Turkey. Looking outward has been incredibly fulfilling. At this time, I look forward to shifting this energy to create an inspiring oasis where ideas can incubate, where community and collaboration can flourish in an intimate space in a natural environment far away from distractions. 

It's an ambitious endeavor, but I am wholly committed to this labor of love. As Yoko Ono says "A dream you dream alone is only a dream. A dream you dream together is reality." I've made the first leap and I've taken the first critical steps, but with your help we can make this dream a reality. 

Please consider making a contribution. Any level of support now would be greatly appreciated. And we welcome your help in spreading the word to those who might be interested in supporting our endeavor.

Lastly, the format of the residency will be announced at a later date. If you are a theatre maker or dancer or performing artist who may be interested in a residency, then please email residencies@adaptationsproject.org to be kept informed of upcoming application deadlines and info. 

 

- Donnie Mather

story:
Dear Friends, 

It's almost impossible to imagine how far things have come over the last 5 years and so many of you, in one way or another, have been a genuine part of it.  From the bottom of my heart, I simply can't thank you enough.  When I first conceived of Tales from the Trundle back in 2012 it started out as my way of using creativity to deal with getting out of a very toxic marriage filled with unhappiness and abuse. Cultivating and relying on my sense of humor, I created this piece to help and inspire other women. It then, hit the stage at the United Solo Festival, will soon be at a private location in NYC and believe it or not I have the chance to take the show all the way to Paris. Paris! And London! And Paris!!   

As no good deed should ever go unpunished, I am asking for some direct support from you my super generous friends (and anyone else you think would want to make this unbelievable opportunity a reality). If this can come together, this one woman show about surviving from and thriving after domestic violence, women's empowerment, and our innate ability to transform and manifest absolutely everything we dream of and more! "Saying No to what no longer serves us begins to serve All of Us." This story is not about me showing the audience my acting abilities, it's with the hopes of reaching and inspiring a larger audience for a greater cause. This is very much a woman's story, not solely my story. The Tales I tale will start resonating with folks far beyond the cobblestone streets of TriBeCa or Brooklyn! 

So now the icky part. I'm looking to raise $75K. That will cover the costs for 12 shows in 2 cities over the summer. The costs simply cover theater fees, travel costs for me and my director and friend James, light and sound technicians, accommodations, meals, and marketing. I can still pull this off if I raise at least $40,000 but the full amount of the campaign will allow me to bring it back to NYC for a solid theater run in the Fall and then continue onto Los Angeles. My intention is to incorporate and invite women's organizations, such as domestic violence survivors, women's empowerment groups, and the like.

Every dollar counts and while I'll be coming up with a list of benefits that correspond with donation amount, truthfully the real benefit is that you would be helping a dream come true in the most authentic sense.  

Please, please if you have any questions about any of this or just want to hear how crazy the preparations are for the European adventure, don't hesitate to reach out.  And of course whether you can give a grand (or 2) or a dollar, it all means so much to me. Click the link to donate.  THANK YOU!

Warmest,

Francesca
